PROCTEXT.PARA: Mr SPEAKER (Hon. Leo McLeay) took the chair at 2 p.m., and read prayers.

DEBATE.TITLE: DEATH OF VICE-ADMIRAL SIR JOHN COLLINS

TALK.START.PARA: —Vice-Admiral Sir John Collins, the first Chief of the Naval Staff, died in St Luke's Hospital in Sydney on the evening of Sunday, 3 September, following a short illness. His distinguished naval career culminated in appointment to the position of First Naval Member of the Australian Commonwealth Naval Board and Chief of the Naval Staff from February 1947 until his retirement in February 1955. His naval career commenced at the Royal Australian Navy College, Geelong, in 1913. He saw war service in both the First World War and the Second World War and was awarded the Companion of the Order of the Bath following a major naval action in the Mediterranean while in command of HMAS Sydney. Following his retirement from the Navy he was High Commissioner to New Zealand from 1956 to 1962. A naval funeral will be held at St Andrew's Cathedral, Sydney, on Friday, 8 September. On behalf of the Government and the people of Australia I convey to his relatives our sincere condolences.

—I am grateful to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) for drawing the death of Sir John Collins to the notice of the House and to the people of Australia. Vice-Admiral Sir John Collins was a most distinguished Australian, the first Australian to become the Chief of the Naval Staff, a record of service to Australia through the Navy ran-ging from 1913 until 1955, service in both world wars, and service to Australia, as the Prime Minister has mentioned, as High Commissioner in New Zealand. His career was as outstanding as his contribution to this nation. He gave unstintingly of himself for his country and we join the Prime Minister in extending sympathy to his family.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sinclair The Rt Hon I.McC.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Blunt) and members of the National Party I seek your indulgence to also extend my condolences to Lady Collins and their daughter. Sir John Collins' death really marks the end of an era. He was one of those Australians who joined the Navy almost when the Royal Australian Navy began. He was educated, like so many of those naval officers of the period, largely in the United Kingdom, but his service brought great tribute, not just to the Australian Navy but to Australia itself. He was a remarkable man. I met him on a number of occasions at Defence Force functions and I found him a person who really brought together a great deal of experience as a fighting sailor and as a peacetime sailor. He has really reflected the best of the traditions of the senior service and I know that all of those who served with him would share in the message that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) are extending to his widow and his daughter today.

SPEECH.PARA: The Royal Australian Navy has, since the days when the late Sir John Collins joined it, established its own traditions and those traditions of course are now more and more becoming part of an integrated Australian Defence Force. But none of that in any way reflects the fact that during World War II it was men like Sir John Collins who contri-buted so much to enable the Allied cause to defeat that of the Nazis and the Japanese during the 1939 to 1945 period. On behalf of the members of the National Party I join in the message of condolence to Lady Collins and their daughter.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Beazley The Hon K.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, I very much appreciate the remarks that have been made about Sir John Collins. It is a very sad day for the Australian Navy. One cannot have been a Defence Minister of this country without having had drawn to one's attention at some time, indeed frequently, by serving members of the Royal Australian Navy, particularly among its senior ranks, what a figure they regarded Sir John Collins to be. He was very much seen as a man who was in on the creation of the Royal Australian Navy, very much a man setting traditions.

SPEECH.PARA: I think one or two things ought to be said about his war record and the period immediately after that. At the outbreak of World War II he was Assistant Chief of Staff and Director of Naval Intelligence at Navy Office, Melbourne. In November 1939 he began his command of HMAS Sydney, which played a significant part in operations against the Italian fleet in the Mediterranean in 1940. Here we come to an action which I guess every Australian has come across in readings of World War II history. In the most spectacular action of the Sydney's Mediterranean deployment, she sank the Italian light cruiser Bartolomeo Colleoni and forced the Giovanni delle Bande Nere to retreat. For this the then Captain Collins was awarded the Companion of the Order of the Bath. In June 1940 he was appointed Chief of Staff to the Commander-in-Chief, China. By 1942 he was commanding the British Far Eastern Squadron, which was responsible for escorting convoys through the Dutch East Indies and Malaya during the Japanese offensive.

In 1943 he commanded the cruiser Shropshire during its Pacific operations. By June 1944 he was given command of the Australian squadron operating with the United States Navy Seventh Fleet. He was seriously wounded during the Allied landings in the Philippines in October 1944. For his service in the South West Pacific the US Government conferred on him the Legion of Merit. In August 1945 as Australia's naval representative he attended the surrender of Japan aboard the USS Missouri. On 7 January 1947 Commodore Collins, along with Commodore Farncomb, was appointed a rear admiral. They were the first graduates of the Royal Australian Naval College to attain the flag rank. On 24 February 1948 Rear Admiral Collins was appointed First Naval Member of the Australian Commonwealth Naval Board and Chief of the Naval Staff, a position he held until 1955.

At about the time Sir John Collins joined the Royal Australian Navy we had only just concluded a decade's debate in this country on whether or not Australians were fit to command ships or whether they ought to provide simply the seamen to essentially a British-commanded squadron; and, when found fit to command ships, whether or not they ought to be commanding them in discrete Australian squadrons or as part of the British Far East Fleet.

I suggested that senior figures in the Royal Australian Navy today see Sir John Collins as being very much a man in on the creation, the foundation, of the real Royal Australian Navy. From the record I read out I think honourable members will see why they would so regard him. His death is appropriately recognised in this chamber, and I join in expressing condolences to his family.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Prime Minister and I ask: Has any attempt been made by the Government to ascertain whether the pilots, who have now indicated that they are prepared to negotiate, would also be prepared to return to work under pre-existing terms and conditions while negotiations take place?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question by the Leader of the Opposition continues the totally unfortunate incapacity he has displayed to understand the essential nature of this dispute. The fact is that in regard to the employers and their former employees, the union has no place in that position. What they do not understand, and what they will not face up to, is that there is a situation now where the employees who were engaged in and members of the union have undertaken in this country the pursuit of the industrial relations policy of the Opposition.

ANSWER.PARA: Opposition members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The House will come to order.

—I understand, Mr Speaker, and it is not surprising, that the Leader of the Opposition took a ballocking in his party room this morning on his handling of the dispute. No wonder! No wonder his spokesman from the party room would not hold his press conference, because his own members in his party room gave him the ballocking he deserves. I join with them in the concern they expressed at the Leader of the Opposition's ineptitude. It is an ineptitude founded on ignorance. The fact is that the pilots have been following the industrial relations policy of the Opposition: that is, opt out of the system and then, having opted out, they are saying to the Government, `Now, you solve the dispute'. Can you imagine anything more ridiculous?

ANSWER.PARA: Of course, we on this side of the House are not bound by their insanities. What we have been doing is dealing with the situation as it is. What have we been doing? We have been doing these things. Firstly, we have been encouraging the employers in question to negotiate in the only way they can. They have no employees, so they are talking to their ex-employees, and what they are doing, assiduously and with a mounting degree of success, is signing contracts with individual former employees. Opposition members should not be worried about that. That is the sort of thing that flows from their policy, and, as the days go on, so will more of the former employees, who put themselves outside of the system, sign up and within a relatively short time the two domestic airlines will be flying aircraft in their own right.

But, while that is happening, we have done everything we possibly can in two ways. Firstly, we have provided the facilities of the Royal Australian Air Force, which facilities are being gratefully used by those members of the public who can get access to them. Secondly, we have taken steps to accelerate the availability of both aircraft and pilots from overseas. These are the things which a government can do in these circumstances. I notice that there is some report in today's media that Mr-because he can no longer be `Captain'; he is no longer an employee-McCarthy is making noises. His captaincy does not carry on with him after he has left employment. Mr McCarthy, I understand, is making some noises about what the pilots would like to do. It is quite clear what they can do. They can make up their minds that their previous stance is, as it is, totally unacceptable, not only to their employers, to the Government and to the Commission, but also to the Australian people. If Opposition members want to go on identifying themselves, as they have continuously, with the pilots, all I can say is, `Good luck to you; you keep on doing it'-because the Australian people are saying that they will not condone a situation where an already highly paid group of people is holding the Australian community to ransom to get an increase, which increase is equal to the average salary of the ordinary Australian person.

The Australian Government stands ready to do all it can to resolve this. There is no more that we could have done. What I am saying is that the airlines are doing the right thing now in trying to sign up these pilots and, as each day goes on, more of their former employees will be signing up, and, as I say, there will be additions to those services already there, which additions will constitute the actual flights by aircraft of the two domestic airlines.

TALK.START.PARA: —Will the Minister for Housing and Aged Care inform the House of the action the Government is taking in response to the recent decision of the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal (PBRT) concerning the fees paid to pharmacists under the pharmaceutical benefits scheme (PBS)?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Staples The Hon P.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Government recognises that the PBRT's decision cannot be overthrown by the Government, the Pharmacy Guild of Australia or any other body. The Tribunal was set up in 1981 by the now Opposition, the Liberal and National parties, and the honourable member for Warringah-the Minister for Health at the time-told this House on 29 April 1981:

ANSWER.PARA: First, it will remove from the political arena the question of the level of fees paid to chemists for the dispensing of pharmaceutical benefits. Both the chemists and the Government will be bound by the tribunal's decisions.

That is the situation, but it appears that again there has been a conflict of policy within the Opposition, and that it wants to overturn that. Last week when I met with representatives of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia and other bodies, I raised with them the PBRT's decision. I also indicated to them that, apart from the decision on the dispensing fee, the Tribunal made two major recommendations which the Government wants to talk about with the Guild and other bodies. These are primarily to ensure the maintenance of essential and isolated pharmacy services through the essential pharmacy allowance. If honourable members opposite were really serious about pharmaceutical services in their electorates-particularly those in rural areas-I would hope that they would be encouraging pharmacists to talk to the Government about this matter. But they are encouraging pharmacists to close. I would hope that they would take a responsible line and encourage pharmacists to talk with the Government about this important matter.

We also want to talk with the Guild about an inquiry into the restructuring of the pharmaceutical industry and, very importantly, to discuss the professional role of pharmacy in the community. The Government is committed to ensuring that all Australians continue to have access to pharmaceuticals under the PBS. We are still awaiting the Guild's response to the Government offer to discuss these recommendations. There are a number of questions which need a serious answer from the Guild. Firstly, why would the Pharmacy Guild urge its members to close their doors on the public while the Government's doors remain open for discussion? We have made the offer; so far it has not been taken seriously.

The Government wants to look at ways in which it can deal with other issues in terms of pharmacy remuneration in areas that have not been dealt with before, particularly in the area of the professional role of pharmacy in the community as a health care provider. Why is the leadership of the Pharmacy Guild of Australia continuing to delude and inflame its pharmacists into thinking that the PBRT decision can be overturned?

The Government accepts the umpire's decision, as it has in the past, even when decisions have gone against it. The Guild today, and members of the Opposition, are running the line that the Government did not accept the Tribunal's decision in the twelfth inquiry. The fact is that it was not the Government but the Guild that challenged the PBRT's decision in the Federal Court. The Federal Court initially supported the Guild's challenge. The Government is appealing against the Federal Court decision-not challenging the PBRT decision.

In 1981, when the Liberals set up the PBRT, the pharmacists had not had a rise since 1977. The history of the PBS and remuneration shows that there has been continual friction and hostility on the issue of remuneration. That is why this legislation is like it is. But the bottom line is protecting people's access to the pharmaceutical benefits scheme, and that is the Government's commitment.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is to the Prime Minister. In view of the announcement that the pilots are willing to negotiate with the airlines on a productivity basis, has the Government, as the owner of Australian Airlines, given any direction or conveyed any attitudes to the airline about commencing negotiations with the pilots?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Under the existing guidelines the capacity has always existed for the pilots to pursue negotiations involving productivity within the system. That capacity has always been there. It is being used by other organisations within the system. In this country one does not have to have some special arrangement, some direction from government to one of its enterprises, to enable a situation whereby a group of employees through its union can successfully negotiate on a productivity basis. You simply get driven back to your anomaly, to your paradox, to your dilemma. The Opposition is saying to individual organisations quite consistently in this matter, `Reject the system'-a system which provides the opportunity for negotiation about productivity increases which can be negotiated by employers and unions within the system.

ANSWER.PARA: A strategically placed organisation-the pilots organisation-has said, `We will adopt the Opposition policy. We will opt out of that system which provides the opportunity for productivity negotiations. We will opt out and hold the community to ransom'. The Opposition is saying, in regard to that system, `That's right. Let them opt out'. When they have opted out, the supreme paradox is that the Opposition now says to the Government, `They are following our policy; you should hop into them and resolve the dispute'. The simple, inescapable facts are these: if the pilots previously employed by Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines want to negotiate with their employers about any claim for an increase in remuneration, an increase based upon possible increases in productivity, the system is there for it to be done. Every other organisation in the country uses it and is prepared to use it, but this organisation of pilots is not prepared to do what everyone else is prepared to do. The Opposition encourages them and condones their action. As far as Australian Airlines is concerned, we are totally satisfied with the way in which that independent body is conducting itself in this dispute.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can the Prime Minister inform the House whether there is any information available to the Government to suggest that the forthcoming elections in South Africa will see any change for the better?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hawke The Hon R.J.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —The question addressed to me by the honourable gentleman is indeed a question of fundamental importance. The honourable gentleman will know, by way of background to the specific answer I will give him, that the attitude of my Government from day one has been that we want to see a peaceful resolution of the tragedy in South Africa. We want nothing more or less than a situation in which each citizen of South Africa, in a totally free and democratic framework, will have the right to vote and be a full participant in the determination of his or her destiny. We have done everything that we possibly can within the Commonwealth and outside it to plead with the Government, with successive regimes in South Africa, to go to the negotiating table.

ANSWER.PARA: Along with others in the Commonwealth, we have taken a lead, where there has been a refusal to follow that course, to try to use sanctions, not as an end in themselves but as an instrument to get the regime in South Africa to the negotiating table. In that, we have fortunately been joined by other members of the Commonwealth and by many countries outside the Commonwealth. The only significant body as far as Australia is concerned which has not joined in that totally admirable objective is the Opposition. The violence that has occurred in the days leading up to tomorrow's South African election is a clear indication of the attitude of the South African Government to its black majority. De Klerk has claimed that it is-and I quote him:
. . . an outright lie that whites want to dominate South Africa's political life in perpetuity.

He has said that the future lies in consensus without the domination of any one group. Let us measure that claim against the events of the last few days. The first overwhelmingly salient point is that the black majority of 23 million has no vote in tomorrow's election. That is the overwhelming, salient and unavoidable fact, and that is what the current protests are about. One may well ask: How have the authorities responded? I will give just a few examples. Students were fired on at Durban University after a meeting, declared illegal, was broken up by police. About 20 students were injured. In a separate incident leading church people, including Archbishop Tutu and Dr Boesak, were detained after police attacked with bull whips people attending a meeting in the Methodist Church in Cape Town. Can you imagine anything more disgraceful, Mr Speaker?

The Australian Broadcasting Corporation's Peter Cave was one of a number of journalists detained in the course of covering some of these events. We have seen the disgusting sight of baton-wielding police beating and arresting blacks protesting the fact that they cannot enter the water on a whites-only beach. Listen to these interruptions and interjections of support for that intolerable situation--
Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!
—They do not like it; of course they do not like it. Now, I hope, may I say in regard to those Australian--

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. Where I was sitting I did not hear and I am sure no other member in the Opposition heard any interruption and I ask the Prime Minister to withdraw those remarks immediately.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—Let me make it quite clear that of course in regard to the observation that I made I do not embrace everyone on that side of the House. There are people on that side of the House whose attitude on this issue is acceptable, and indeed admirable, but the whole course of my response to the question is in line with the policy accepted by the whole of the Commonwealth of which we are a member. During a response to the question in which I was giving a position of the Government which is totally accepted by the whole of the Commonwealth, we had from some members of the Opposition, particularly that corner up there, interjections-

ANSWER.PARA: Honourable members interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! Honourable members on both sides will cease interjecting and the honourable member for Menzies will cease interjecting.
—I warn the honourable member for Menzies. Honourable members on my left and right will cease interjecting.

—I am simply making the point that those interjections, coming as they did during the answer to the question I was giving, were not something new from those sources. They were a continuing reflection of an attitude which has been consistently expressed inside and outside this House and which has given aid and comfort to the apartheid regime in South Africa. Those honourable members ought to understand that they have been doing that and that the interjections they have been making today are nothing new. They are a continuation of that aid and comfort which they have consistently given to the regime in South Africa.

ANSWER.PARA: I hope that those Australian sports players-the rugby players and administrators-who visited South Africa against the advice of this Government took note of these developments that have been occurring in South Africa while they were there. Unlike black South Africans, they live in a country which extends human rights to all its citizens. In exercising their freedom to travel, a right which this Government will always respect, they might have spared a thought to the denial of elementary human rights which is the daily lot of millions of South Africans. It is far too early to be optimistic about the prospects of sufficient change after the election on 6 September. We will be, of course, as I hope all reasonable people will be doing both here and elsewhere, watching the situation carefully. But it is depressing that the soft words emanating from South Africa are being accompanied by the harshest and most brutal of police repression. The ultimate challenge is the abandonment of the apartheid system and there is to date, very regrettably, no sign that the Government there is contemplating this.

While apartheid remains, so must international pressure, unfortunately, including sanctions, because there is only, as I have said on many occasions, one of two possible ways in which that tragic situation in South Africa will come to an end. Either it will come to an end by peaceful negotiation, or it will come to an end by bloodshed. Everyone should have a vested interest in trying to ensure that, by all appropriate forms of pressure, it is the former and not the latter which sees an end to the abhorrent regime of apartheid.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. In its White Paper on higher education issued in July 1988, the Government committed itself to rolling triennial funding for colleges and universities. At that time the institutions welcomed the rolling triennium because it would provide unprecedented surety of funding with which each year they could plan for the next three. What funding can the higher education system expect for 1992? Is the Minister aware of any alternatives to this funding approach for higher education?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Dawkins The Hon J.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question and his continuing interest in this matter, particularly on behalf of Queensland, where higher education funding has been a matter of very great public importance, to ensure that we can accommodate the large number of young Queenslanders who want to participate in higher education. It is my pleasure to announce to the House that today the Government has announced that we will be allocating some $3.4 billion to higher education in 1992. This is the first time for very many years that we have had a proper system of a rolling triennium to underpin the expansion and the maintenance of higher education in this country. The new funds to be provided in 1992 will not only provide a continuation of a considerable building program but also fund an additional 14,000 new student places in that year. This, of course, is on top of the $9 billion for higher education that we will expend during the 1989-91 triennium.

ANSWER.PARA: The importance of this decision is not only that it reveals that we are prepared to continue the growth and expansion of the higher education system but also that it provides for individual institutions a stable environment in which they themselves can plan for their future and their future growth. Between 1988 and 1992, higher education expenditure will have increased by a very significant $1.3 billion. During the period from 1988 to 1992, we will see the expansion in places of some 63,000 bringing to 150,000 the total number created since 1983. That is a 60 per cent expansion in the higher education system during the period of this Government.

The honourable member asks whether there are any alternative policies for the funding of higher education. In the context of the Government laying its cards on the table and indicating what it is prepared to do for the next three years, it is appropriate that we should look at alternatives that have been revealed from the mishmash that has come from the other side. What we hear from the current and most recent spokesperson for education is that Opposition members will encourage institutions to fund in their own way, that is, through fees, any expansion in the system. They will also encourage the expansion of private universities. In other words, they will starve the public institutions of funds so that either they will have to charge fees or private institutions will spring up charging fees in order to try to provide for the increasing demand in this country for higher education opportunities.

What we know from the Opposition's policies is that it will not increase expenditure in this area, which means that, on the basis of the policy which has already been announced, to the extent that it is at all intelligible, there will be something like a $500m hole in the higher education budget by the time we reach 1992. The only way in which that hole can be filled is through the imposition of high, upfront fees. Particularly at a time like this, it seems to me that we ought to have a clear exposition so that the higher education system understands what its clear choices are. Yet during the course of the last two years, when we have seen such an imaginative rewriting of higher education policy in this country, I have been confronted by no fewer than five shadow Ministers in various combinations. Following the appointment of each one, various policies have been floated. I point only to the author of the most recent policy, the honourable member for Deakin, whose optimism about the coalition's prospects at the next election is such that he had to scurry off to a safer seat. It must be remembered that we were at one stage offered the prospect of the honourable member for Bennelong making an appearance as the shadow Minister for education. He would have--

—The Minister is answering the question.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order. There is an accepted mode of raising points of order in this House, and that is to raise a point of order. It is not part of the process of raising that point of order to direct the Speaker. That is a reflection on the Chair. —The only reason for drawing attention to this occurrence is, of course, to measure the commitment that the Opposition has to this vital area of policy. I do not really believe that the honourable member for Bennelong thought that this post was a trivial one. After all, even in the terms of the coalition, it is a post that has been held by Gorton and Fraser just before they became Prime Minister. I think it is not so much that the honourable member for Bennelong thought that this task was trivial; rather, I think he felt daunted by the prospect of having to make sense of the policy that he would have inherited from his colleagues; or, perhaps more to the point, the newly candid member for Bennelong can find no fault with the Government's policy.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Social Security. The Government announced in the April economic statement that the income test free area for married couples would become 100 per cent tax free in this financial year. In view of the different treatment of married couples under the taxation and social security rules, can the Minister inform the House how the Government will give effect to this commitment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Howe The Hon B.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —There is no doubt that the relationship between the social security free area and the treatment of income for tax purposes, particularly small amounts of income, has been a matter of considerable confusion and concern to pensioners. That became very clear during the consultations that were carried out by the Prime Minister's task force on retirement incomes. The consultations also confirm that taxing modest amounts of non-pension income acts as a disincentive to pensioners to maximise their income. The Government has a three-stage reform of tax and income test arrangements for age and service pensioners which will overcome these difficulties.

ANSWER.PARA: There is, however, the question which was raised by the honourable member of the different treatment of couples under current taxation and pension rules. These differences arise because the social security system treats couples as a single unit but the Taxation office treats them as separate individuals. This different treatment creates a potential difficulty in giving effect to our commitment that a married couple can receive income of $70 a week combined without losing any pension or paying any tax. In cases where one partner, usually the husband, receives most of the couple's income, a pensioner's tax rebate that allowed each to receive half the combined free area would not be sufficient to free such a couple from tax. The Government has therefore decided that where both of a couple are pensioners, they will be able to transfer to their spouse any unused portion of their pensioner tax rebate or shade-out threshold. For 1989-90 this will mean that a pensioner couple with a combined taxable income of around $15,140 or less will not pay tax regardless of the distribution of income between husband and wife. Even more generous arrangements will apply in the case of pensioner couples living separately due to illness. Superannuants who are pensioners will particularly benefit from this initiative. Like other components of our retirement income policy, it has certainly been welcomed by pensioner organisations.

I think if some value has come out of the Social Security Review it is that as a Government we have been able to address-not simply from the recommendations of Professor Cass but as a government in an integrated way-quite complex and difficult problems that often rob incentive and create inequities. I do not think there is a clearer example of a reform long overdue than this reform or cleaning up of the relationship between social security and tax as it affects pensioners and superannuants with small amounts of income. I am sure that the honourable member's electors, as would aged people across Australia, welcome particularly the changes that have occurred in this area.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs. Was the Minister informed by Charles Perkins on the Saturday night a week before the Adelaide meeting of the Aboriginal Development Commission of 10 October 1988 that Mr Perkins was proposing to move for resolutions against the Chairman and the General Manager of the ADC?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly let me say that I answered a similar question to this some time ago. I have read the story in today's Australian in which Mr Perkins makes a number of comments, and I stand by my answer to this Parliament on 13 October last year that I had no prior knowledge of the events which occurred at the ADC commissioners meeting. Mr Perkins has had a lot to say about me in recent weeks, and about the Government's policies on Aboriginal affairs. I have noted, for instance, his comments on the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission in recent days, which I find rather curious and certainly in stark contrast to what he told both the Prime Minister and me in 1987 when we were first discussing ATSIC. I recall very clearly that, when asked by the Prime Minister whether ATSIC would work, Mr Perkins gave a very clear and strong assertion that it would-an assertion that he repeated right across Australia during our consultations beginning in 1988, and an assertion heard by members of this House and of the Senate.

ANSWER.PARA: Let me return to today's article and the thrust of the question. Firstly, Mr Perkins did not ring me prior to the ADC commissioners' meeting in Adelaide to inform me that the ADC Chairman and the ADC General Manager were to be removed. In the article Mr Perkins is said to have called me at Marla Bore on Saturday, 1 October, at about 7 p.m. Honourable members might recall that on that particular Saturday the Victorian State election was taking place and I was in Melbourne. On the evening which Mr Perkins was supposed to have called me at Marla Bore I attended three functions in the Melbourne Federal electorate. The first was a function for Mr Barry Rowe, the Minister for Agriculture and Rural Affairs and member for Essendon; the second was for the new member for Melbourne, Neil Cole; and the third was for Demetri Dollis, the member for Richmond, held in the Collingwood Town Hall. After that I went to the tally room and members of the press gallery, members of this House and a whole lot of people saw me at that function, and I point out that I received no call at the tally room.

The next day I flew to Marla Bore and arrived there at about 5 o'clock. I checked into my motel and then went across to the departmental office. While I was there a call came through and the then South Australian State Director of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, Miss Dawn Allen, answered it. Just for the record, Dawn Allen is now on my personal staff. She then hung up and advised me that Mr Perkins had just called from Alice Springs and was extremely angry that no car had turned up for him in Alice Springs. Dawn Allen then told me that Mr Perkins had asked her to pass on a message to me that he would not be able to get to Marla Bore that night as arranged, and I did not speak to Mr Perkins at any stage on the Sunday. The article in today's Australian quotes Mr Perkins as saying that he spoke to me as I was departing for Indulkna. I did not go to Indulkna. The next day I left Marla Bore and went to Mimili via Mintibie. That night I camped out just outside Mimili. I did not speak to Mr Perkins on that day either; there was no phone in the creek bed.

On the following days I visited a number of communities, including Ernabella, where I camped out; Amata and Nypari, where I also camped; and finally Kalka and Pipalyatjara-and I did not speak to Mr Perkins while I was at any of these places. Mr Perkins also claimed that he spoke to my senior private secretary, Mr Geoff Pryor, about the intended resolutions. This is also wrong. For the record, Mr Pryor was travelling with me through South Australia along with other senior officers. In short, the claims in the article in today's paper, the Australian, are absolutely false. At no time did he discuss the matters with me.

TALK.START.PARA: —Has the Minister for Employment and Education Services seen the recent reports in which a Victorian car manufacturer is critical of the Government's Newstart program? If so, would he inform the House whether there is any basis for this criticism?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Duncan The Hon P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the honourable member for his question. I know of the keen interest that he--
—What about Jobstart? What did the Auditor-General say about Jobstart?

—I will get to some of your comments in just a moment or two. I know of the keen interest that the honourable member takes in the employment situation in the south-east of Melbourne, where the car factories referred to in that article are situated, and I did see the article. The gravamen of it was that there were criticisms of the fact that Newstart participants were unsuitable employees in the automotive industry. I thought it was interesting, in passing, also to note that, on the Sunday following the appearance of that article in the Melbourne Sun, the Sunday Sun contained an article which indicated that individuals under the Newstart program had started in automobile factories, particularly Toyota, I think, and had proved themselves to be very satisfactory employees.

ANSWER.PARA: Newstart is the Government's program to assist long term unemployed people in this nation, people who have been unemployed for 12 months or longer, people who are disadvantaged in the labour market. The program has now been operating for some months and the whole purpose of it is to seek to assist long term unemployed people to become job ready and get back into the labour market. It is particularly notable that a number of employers and unions, union leaders, employer leaders, including Mr Brian Noakes, have endorsed and supported the program as an important part of the Government's fight to assist long term unemployed people to get back into the work force. It is also interesting to note that the program to date has been pretty successful. It is too early yet to make fine judgments about how successful, but early indicators are very encouraging. Almost 11,000 people in the Newstart target group have returned to work since the program began, and almost 7,000 have received the employment entry benefit of $100. Those figures are very encouraging and certainly this Government can be pleased with the results that we have achieved.

As to the car manufacturers, I simply make the point that the solutions to some of the problems are in their hands, because in Melbourne, particularly, where the unemployment rate across the conurbation is about 3 per cent, they may well have to review their employment policies and decide whether it would be in their interest to lower the standards that they require from new employees. One is not going to find that people who have been unemployed for 12 months or longer have a good employment history over the past three or four years. Such people, obviously, are not going to be able to provide the checkable references which are being required by the car companies. I think it is fair to say that most Newstart clients do not meet those sorts of requirements.

We have sought to involve Nissan, Toyota and Ford in the Newstart program. We have not had a lot of success to date. I have asked the Department to invite, at the local level, Toyota, Nissan and Ford to become more closely involved in the programs. I would like to see the car companies in their local areas become involved by putting representatives on to the Newstart advisory committees. I hope that they will take up those invitations because it is important to the long term unemployed and to the car companies that need employees for these people, who have been unemployed for a long time, to have the opportunity to get into the work force.

I conclude by saying that the Government's policies in this area of assisting long term unemployed people to get back into the work force have seen some quite dramatic results in the past 12 months. The number of long term unemployed has fallen dramatically. In the year to July those people unemployed for 12 months or more fell by more than 22 per cent; 36,500 people fewer than twelve months previously. Those unemployed for two years or more declined by 14 per cent, or 13,000, over that period. I think it is fair to say that that record is unsurpassed. It is part of our overall excellent employment record which is, undoubtedly, the best of countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.
