DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr SPEAKER

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith) proposing that a definite matter of public importance be submitted to the House for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The Government's disregard for Parliament and proper accountability in the administration of Aboriginal affairs.
I call upon those members who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of members required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith Mr W.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) is not leaving the chamber. This matter of public importance is motivated, obviously, by the article which appeared in the Australian today and which I think all honourable members in this place would recognise makes a very important point, that is, that the former Secretary to the Department of Aboriginal Affairs (DAA) makes public by the leaking of a letter certain allegations with regard to his discussions with the Minister. In the answer the Minister has just given he relies on a date. The date is 1 September. The question is whether or not he received a phone call from Perkins on that day. We either take the Minister's word or take Mr Perkins's word.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out that when one reads the letter one finds no reference to a date. So I do not think this matter is closed yet-not by any means. There is still every possibility that a call took place. The Minister says that he was not there on the relevant day that Perkins says that he was there. But Perkins does not say which day. He does acknowledge that he was in Marla Bore on the following day. He does acknowledge that Perkins was in Alice Springs; a call could well have taken place. The matter is not closed.

This whole issue revolves around what happened with regard to the meeting of the Aboriginal Development Commission (ADC) on 10 October. The question we asked two days after that meeting was: `Did the Minister have prior knowledge of the intention of the Secretary of his own Department to take action in his capacity as Acting Commissioner of the Aboriginal Development Commission against the Chairman and the General Manager of the ADC at the meeting of the Commission in Adelaide last week?' In response the Minister emphatically answered, `No'. On 14 October, Senator Tate was asked a similar question in the Senate and he said:
I . . . confirm that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs did not have prior knowledge of any actions taken by the Aboriginal Development Commissioners at their meeting this week.

Both answers are starkly at variance with the letter that has been published in the Australian, which was a letter to his biographer that gave rise to the leading article that all of us I am sure have read. In this letter Mr Perkins makes a number of important and significant disclosures that clearly contradict the advices given to the Parliament. Mr Perkins makes it clear that the Minister appointed him to the ADC Board to monitor developments and keep him informed of them, to quote his letter. He continues:
As secretary of the department I always felt obliged to heed his request for information.

Is the Minister therefore prepared to stand up and say that he had no communication at all from Mr Perkins prior to that vital ADC meeting? Will he do that when he responds to this matter of public importance? Mr Perkins states:
Before the Adelaide meeting which passed resolutions against the chairman and general manager, I ensured that the Minister knew what was about to happen.

There was no reference to a date. The Minister therefore has to answer: did he know or did he not know prior to the meeting? His answer today does not satisfy that question. On this matter of having kept the Minister fully informed before the ADC Board meeting of 10 to 14 October, Mr Perkins also notes:
. . . I had numerous conversations with Geoff Pryor (his private secretary) re these resolutions.

There are people on both sides who have been Ministers, and I note that the honourable member for Parramatta (Mr John Brown) has been through this process before. Surely a private secretary relates to a Minister in detail all sorts of matters relevant to his administration. Is the Minister trying to tell us that his private secretary, whether it be Geoff Pryor or someone else, did not advise him of this major undertaking by the Secretary to his Department, whom he appointed to be his eyes and ears on the ADC Board? I find that hard to believe and so do honourable members on this side and so do many who saw these events back in October.

The resolutions referred to were those which resulted in the censure of Mrs McPherson, the ADC Chairman; the removal of Mr Mick O'Brien from the position of General Manager of the ADC; and the appointment of Mr Cedric Wyatt to that position. Mr Perkins then goes on to state:

I clearly recall informing Gerry Hand on the Saturday night a week before the Adelaide meeting of what resolutions were being proposed against Shirley McPherson and Mick O'Brien. I left him in no doubt that those resolutions would be passed.

It is clear from this statement that the Minister knew well before the ADC Board meeting of the matters that would be placed before the ADC Board and of the action which would be taken by it, information the Minister denied having prior to the Board meeting of 10 to 14 October. Also in his letter Mr Perkins records in relation to the Minister:
He was pleased that we were going to do something to meet the resistance from the ADC towards our proposal for ATSIC . . .

One only has to hear the answer to the question to know that the core of the motivation for all these issues has been the position Mr Perkins has taken on ATSIC. Is it not ironic? Yesterday National Aborigines and Islanders Day was launched by none other than the former Secretary and the remarks he made that were published in the media were `that he no longer had any faith in the concept that is being put forward by the Minister'-that is, ATSIC. He saw it as a revolutionary proposal that did not have the full support of Aboriginal people. That is the point that Charles Perkins has constantly made. This is a man that spent 20 years in Aboriginal affairs-a lot longer than you or I-and his view was that your proposals for ATSIC were not worth following, that it needed far more time, that the mechanism proposed was something that he could not lend his support to. He was loyal; he did not say a word about any conversations he had with the Minister prior to that ADC meeting until he retired from the Public Service. He has more to lose than anyone else by coming out and saying what he thinks, and I will quote to you in a little while what the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) said.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before the honourable member for Bass continues, I am keen to see that he refer to the Minister as such rather than as `you' and `your'.
—Oh, for goodness sake.
—Do I have to remind the honourable member for Gippsland of the Standing Orders? The Standing Orders require that honourable members refer to other members by their seats or by their positions.

—Thank you for your guidance, Mr Deputy Speaker. I remind the House that in making these disclosures Mr Perkins has nothing to gain personally. Indeed it might be felt by some that these revelations could place at risk his hopes of continuing to contribute to Aboriginal affairs through consultancy engagements, a subject on which the Prime Minister has recently commented favourably. Now these disclosures are supported by related matters which were widely known at the time, that is, in October last year.

SPEECH.PARA: I remind the House that a week before the Aboriginal Development Commission Board meeting it was common knowledge that a subject of discussion by DAA and ADC executive staff was that moves would be made against Mrs McPherson and Mr O'Brien. I am further informed that five days before the meeting the then Deputy Secretary to the DAA, Rob Winroe, telephoned Mr O'Brien and warned him of these moves. Further, on 6 October or thereabouts, Mr Jackomos, who was Secretary, interestingly, of the Woden Town Club and was also on the Minister's staff, told ADC officers of these moves and the actions which would and did follow. Now these and other matters known at the time are entirely consistent with and supportive of the disclosures made by Mr Perkins in correspondence with his biographer, Dr Read of the Australian National University. These disclosures are not a figment of the imagination. They are the truth and they are an indictment of the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs.

I also spoke with Charles Perkins over a period of time and he explained to me that he did keep the Minister advised of all matters, as was the role of a secretary to any of the departments of state. I find it very difficult to now stand here and hear the Minister say that there was no conversation on a particular date. I would think, and I am sure my colleagues believe, that the Minister was advised prior to that ADC meeting and, therefore, we come to the crux of the issue: did the Minister or did not the Minister mislead the Parliament? The evidence is very heavily against him. He will have to do far better than he did in Question Time to deny the allegations that are made by Mr Perkins.

I know that some time ago the honourable member for Parramatta resigned from his portfolio because he quite unintentionally and unwittingly misled the House. It was the honourable and proper course of action to take to comply with the high standards set and expected in this chamber. That is what this issue is all about because honourable members would be aware that this is not the first time that there have been motions from this side of the House alleging that this Minister may have misled the House. He has escaped two such motions. He may or may not escape this one, but it is quite clear that there is a systematic pattern of administration which indicates that this Minister is wanting in the administration of this Department. If we have a look at the Aboriginal Affairs portfolio we will find that during the time that this Minister has been Minister it has been subject to more inquiries than any other in recent times.

I think that we now should look to see what the Prime Minister had to say. It was only on 15 August when the Prime Minister came into this House and, in the summing up of the report of the Menzies Inquiry into Allegations as to the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs, which was the final report into the allegations that had been made about certain things in relation to Charles Perkins, said:
It is true that he has occasionally been a controversial figure; but only, I believe, where he saw this as important to his continuing effectiveness as a leader of his people.

That is important. The Prime Minister recognised what all of us recognise, that Charles Perkins spoke out in many controversial circumstances, but when he did he spoke out in defence of his people. Do not tell me that this letter to his biographer, which is going to be the sum total of 20 years work in the Aboriginal affairs area, is such that he is motivated by something other than defending his people and defending his record obviously, but primarily he is defending his people. Is the Minister going to ascribe to Mr Perkins some other motive, some other reason for making these statements? I think that he wants the record to be correct as it states in his letter, and the Minister is trying to rewrite history in his answers here in not admitting that he did have that prior information. What about the Prime Minister? He went on further to praise Mr Perkins. He said:

It is time this House and this Parliament put those matters behind it and instead expressed its recognition of the substantial contribution Charles Perkins has made throughout his working life in the interests of advancing the cause of the Aboriginal people.

That has been his motivation, that has been his lifelong commitment and he has been totally frustrated. When he was Secretary he was not appointed by the present Minister. He was appointed by the former Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, the honourable member for Melbourne Ports (Mr Holding), but he has been totally frustrated by the direction in which this Minister wishes to take Aboriginal affairs with this revolutionary exercise in establishing a black parliament, this ATSIC legislation. Charles Perkins has come to believe sincerely that this legislation is something that is not good for his people and so he is prepared to stand up and say so. The Minister wants to criticise him for it. I think that the Minister is neglecting the role that he plays in this place, and that is being the spokesman for Aboriginal people within his Party. That is my role on this side of the chamber-to be the spokesman for Aboriginal people; to put their views across. A Senate select committee went off and took evidence all over the country and the vast majority of submissions were against this proposal that the Minister is putting forward. Now the man who was chosen to be the one to launch National Aboriginal Day has come forward and said he does not believe in this proposal. He does not believe in the Minister who is currently in charge of Aboriginal affairs in this country. That is significant. He is defending his people and the Minister is trying to discredit him.
But let me turn to the Prime Minister. What did he say on August 15? He said this:

I express, on behalf of the Government, regret that his services as a full-time officer will be lost to the Government, and I hope honourable members will join me in wishing him well in his future career. For the Government's part, it will be actively seeking appropriate opportunities to engage Mr Perkins in appropriate part-time activity so that the wealth of his knowledge and experience is not totally lost to the Commonwealth.

Charles Perkins was in here that day. I sat here and I saw him sitting up there in the gallery, and he was pleased to hear the Prime Minister of this country say that about him. He was pleased to hear the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) echo similar sentiments. What happened on that day? The Minister vacated the chamber. This Minister has conducted a vendetta against Charles Perkins. To this day he has never explained to this House why it was that Charles Perkins was removed in the way that he was. Honourable members should remember that they have to make their judgment about which man they believe, because at the end of the day that is what this issue is all about. Do they believe this Minister or do they believe Charles Perkins?

It is all right to dissemble the facts and say it was this day or that day, but the base allegation is there. The Secretary to the Department says, `I advised my Minister of all activity that was proposed'. The Minister says, `No. Contrary to all accepted public administration principles, I was not advised'. I cannot believe that they cannot believe it upstairs and we cannot believe it over here. I know that many on the Minister's side of the chamber do not believe it either. He ought to hope that there are no Telecom records that perhaps would reveal telephone calls or any written evidence because if there are the Minister is history because he would have been shown to have misled the House. It will be the final time for him, because a cat cannot continue to be as lucky as he has been. He has been flying very close to the wire. His whole pattern of administration of this portfolio has been seen to be wanting and many people believe that his proposals for the future of Aboriginal people in this country will take this nation backwards. That is what this debate is about. It is all right for the Minister, as he will in a moment, to accuse Charles Perkins of having a vendetta against him; he is defending his people and the Minister ought to have listened to what he had to say.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hand The Hon G.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, we have just had a bit of an outburst from the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), in his first performance. He tried to suggest that in my answer to the House I was attempting to run away from the facts. In the letter that he quotes from, Mr Perkins says quite clearly, on page 2:

SPEECH.PARA: I was at Alice Springs at the time at my daughter's place . . . and my wife was with me. The Minister was in Marla Bore . . .

Well, I was not in Marla Bore. I was in the Exhibition Buildings in Melbourne. He says to me that it is no good my getting up here and denying it. I cannot help it if I was not where somebody said I was. The fact of the matter is, quite clearly, that I stand by my position of saying I was not informed about the activities being proposed by the then Secretary to the Department and acting commissioner of the Aboriginal Development Commission, Charles Perkins. But, the shadow Minister says that it could have taken place. It could have taken place, but it did not. It did not take place in that he never spoke to me prior to that meeting about what he intended to do. If honourable members are half reasonable, they will think about where Marla Bore is, they will think about where Alice Springs is and they will think about where the Exhibition Buildings in Melbourne are.

I find it extraordinary that some of those opposite are the very people who pilloried Charles Perkins day after day, in this place and in the other chamber, and who went after him in an unmerciful way-in a way in which people from their side came and saw me about. People over there were ashamed of what was going on. I defended Charles Perkins, along with his family, in here from those attacks when the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) wanted to go into the dungeons in the old Parliament House and drag out information given under privilege to a committee and to have it tabled, to smatter it across the pages of the newspapers in order to denigrate Mr Perkins. I find it extraordinary that the honourable member for Bass comes in here with crocodile tears to suggest that he is sympathetic to Charlie Perkins. The fact is that my answer today is factually correct.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I do apologise to the Minister but I find it very difficult to hear with the continual interruptions from the honourable member for O'Connor. I wish you could do something about it.
—There is no point of order. The Chair is in charge of the debate.

—The travel arrangements of me and my staff will clearly indicate that I was not where Mr Perkins suggested I was. I regret that he has made a mistake. The shadow Minister said that I was going to come in here today and pour a bucket all over Charlie Perkins. Well, I am not going to do that. I am just going to make a couple of points and then move on to what the second part of the matter of public importance deals with.

SPEECH.PARA: Firstly, to anybody who thinks that I got a big kick out of what happened to Charlie Perkins, I say that I did not. I regret what happened and I found it probably one of the saddest or most difficult days that I have ever been involved in in politics. The fact is that there is a unique relationship between a Minister and a Secretary to his Department. In the last few weeks I have been referred to as acting in a racist way. People in the Opposition know me; I am not a racist. Does anybody here think I am a racist? I do not tell lies. The proof is there. Why would I say `no' to an answer that clearly was designed as a bit of a trap. What did I have to gain by saying `no'? What was in it for me? There was absolutely nothing. To be fair, the way things were flowing out of the Aboriginal Development Commission in those days, I would have been a bit adventurous to have pretended that it would not get out.

Let us clear the matter up. The fact is that Charlie departed the scene in terms of his relationship with me over a specific issue which I outlined in the Parliament. I do not resile from that situation. It was intolerable. He knows that. I did not use him as a black scapegoat or some other colourful term that has been bandied around in the media. I resent that. A few articles have been written that I might do something about, for the first time in my life. I do not like being called a racist; I do not like being called a liar and I do not like people printing that.

The day before Charlie Perkins left the job, I was defending him and his family and I will continue to defend them and all those other Aboriginal people that were named here and in the Senate during that terrible period with no shred of proof. Names were flung around at random, day after day after day; I defended all of them too. I will defend the officers of my Department. The other day we had the spectacle in the Senate of a senator standing up and saying, `Isn't it interesting? Hand has no Aboriginal advisers in with Senator Tate today'. Why would I? Every single one of them has been battered and pilloried all through the Senate chamber because they happen to work for me. Honourable members can read the Hansard reports and the press cuttings about anybody who is black and who has worked with me.

The fact is that this is really all about the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission (ATSIC). It has been all about ATSIC right through 1988, when the Opposition went after Charlie, after me and after all those other decent people, and attempted to destroy them. Not once do we get a debate from the Opposition on policy. Not once does the Opposition talk about the issues. Opposition members put out mealy-mouthed press releases every day which no-one runs, thank God, but they never put up a proposition, an amendment or whatever, in this chamber. Opposition members never came to talk to me about ATSIC, when I offered them the olive branch. When I met with members of the Senate Select Committee on the Administration of Aboriginal Affairs a day or so after they were appointed. I said to them, `Look, let's see if we can work it out. Let's see if we can reach agreement'. What did I get? Not one approach, except Senate inquiries, privilege committee inquiries and millions of dollars being wasted. You could have talked to me about the issues.

I will tell you what, there is one thing about the mob of National Party members over in the corner; when they have a beef, they come and see me. I do not agree with a lot of their politics-I have said this before-but they know how the system works. They know the damage that can be caused in their community when one goes off half-cocked in the media. Other members know that, too. There are horrendous results for black and white people living in these communities when one goes off half-cocked. I remind the House that when a senator was asked, `Why do you use the words `black mafia''?', he said, `I use it to get you mugs there to listen'. He was referring to the press gallery. He said, `The only way you'll come along and hear me is if I use an outrageous claim that there is a black mafia in existence'. That is why he used it, and that is a disgrace in this country. It is a disgrace that it is allowed to happen.

The point is that I know that the current Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) and the shadow Minister are wrong. Unfortunately, I gave the shadow Minister a bit of a rap yesterday on a radio program as being a reasonable person, one with whom I hoped I could work; I have no doubt that I can. The fact is that he is wrong. I happen to be a little proud. I do not want to get the flick out of this joint for having lied to it. I am a bit old fashioned about that. Take it from me, I am not going to tell you any lies. What I am about is trying to rectify the problems that you have talked about in a few of your press releases and the problems that you and other members opposite have talked about. The text of the matter of public importance that the shadow Minister has proposed is as follows:
The Government's disregard for parliament and proper accountability in the administration of Aboriginal affairs.

Look at what has happened in terms of the second part of the proposal, which you did not address. I have been doing virtually nothing else in this portfolio except working with the officers within it, and the Aboriginal people, trying to make the system work better. It is fair to say that I could score a lot of points by dragging out the odd blue that somebody before me made, but that does not serve any purpose. We have had an exciting period, action packed if you like, in Aboriginal affairs. One could say it has never been dull. When I look around the chamber at some of the grey-headed members, I reckon I will be like them at the end of the next six months or so. The fact is that we have reviewed nearly all areas of the portfolio, setting up systems for better administration and better accountability. I am sure that when honourable members on both sides of the House visit Aboriginal communities, they are always told, `Don't set us up to fail', because they have been set up to fail so many times. What we have tried to do in terms of ATSIC is make it work.

There have been many reports. Interestingly, when we amended the Bill relating to the Australian Institute of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Studies, Opposition members never came to see me. I had to go to them and say, `Look, they're not bad ideas. I think I will accept those; the Government will accept them', but they never came to see me; no, they are too thick to do that. They hoped I would oppose it. We accepted all of your amendments regarding the Institute. Just think what you could have done about ATSIC if you had got off your backside and come to see me about it. We might have agreed on a few things in that regard, too.

I return to the matter of the article in newspapers today. It is regrettable that it has happened but maybe one day I will get the opportunity to write my book and I will have to dream up a few ways in which to get a bit of publicity. By golly, I tell you what, it will be a ripsnorter when I drop a few things that I know about. I make the point again: there was never any criticism of me in regard to those issues during the course of the lead-up to those inquiries on Charles Perkins or his family. I kept saying to people in this chamber and other places, `Put up or shut up and let the processes that the Government has put in place be the judge'. I made no judgment. In terms of the Woden Town Club, I do not move back one inch-not one inch-from my views. I, like you, have to travel around this country seeing people without shelter, people without water, sick kids with crook ears and crook eyes, and all the associated problems that we read about in the newspapers. The last thing on my priorities is poker machines and the Woden Town Club. So I resile not one centimetre from my view on that.

Now Mr Perkins has an equally strong view in the other direction, and that is his right. But while I am running this portfolio I said I would do everything to stop the money going to the Woden Town Club. As a consequence of that we fell out. I ask the honourable member to read my answer regarding the reason why Charles Perkins left. Honourable members would have to agree that it was not a very good relationship for me or for him, and the best thing for both of us was for him to leave. I also point out that Charles Perkins approached both the Prime Minister and me quite some months before seeking a way in which he could vacate the position and retire. There are a lot of things I could talk about, but I am not going to go on with any more.

TALK.START.PARA: —Did he advise you at any stage about the ADC meeting?
—I am going to say to the honourable member that at no time prior to the ADC meeting did Mr Perkins discuss with me those matters that he proceeded with at that meeting.
—No time?
—At that point-I am trying to get it through to you--
—No time?

—Let me finish. You are not in a court now. I am only a scrubber from a textile mill; I am not a lawyer like you. The point about it is that it was impossible for him to tell me. I was not available to be told in that period he referred to.
—Any time?

—Any time. He never spoke to me prior to the meeting about what he intended to do at that meeting. The point about it is-and you must be a bit dense or something or you have not been in the job long-that at no time did he discuss, as your question said, what he intended to do at that meeting. Now that is about the fourth time. However, at times, as he says, he did talk to me about activities of the ADC. So did the other commissioners. There are a number of them and they met with me, together. Sometimes I bumped into them all around Australia and they spoke to me then too. If you read all the reports and all the inquiries that were taking place in the Senate you would see that the motives for the actions they took against Mr O'Brien and Mrs McPherson were not, according to the evidence given by Mr Perkins, related to ATSIC, they related to other matters, so I resent the imputations of your comments.

—Order! The Minister's time has expired. Might I say, before I call the next speaker, that I am keen for honourable members to make their remarks through the Chair. I am keen to avoid the use of `you' and `your' because I think that introduces an element into the debate that is not helpful. I draw that to the attention of those who have spoken.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I suspect you knew the point of order I was about to take. I wanted to emphasise the importance of that matter because you interrupted the shadow Minister when he was speaking. I did not propose to interrupt the Minister but I think there should be complete and utter even-handedness in the way in which these matters are addressed.
—There is no point of order.
—If I was offensive to the honourable member for Dundas in any of my comments about `you' and `your', I apologise.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Miles Mr C.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —People who have been observing the affairs of Aboriginal people in Australia and its administration over the last two years would be absolutely horrified by the way in which this Government has treated Aboriginal people in Australia. Never since the Commonwealth became involved in Aboriginal matters have Aboriginal Australians been treated so shabbily and dismissively and superficially as they have by this Government and by this Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). He may well talk about how he has great compassion and understanding of the Aboriginal people, but the simple reality of it is that there has been very little action at the grassroots level. Little is done and only a small amount of the money actually gets through to the Aboriginal people at the grassroots level.

SPEECH.PARA: We are discussing a matter of public importance which concerns proper accountability to this Parliament in the administration of Aboriginal affairs. Today, in a major newspaper, an issue has been raised which we are concerned about. That is not because it is not the first time that it would appear that this Minister has misled the Parliament. It is not we who have made the judgment that he has misled the Parliament. He got up here a few minutes ago and said, `I don't want to go out of here because I lied to the Parliament'. I say to the Minister, and to the people who are listening to the broadcast of these proceedings, that not only on our part but also on the part of many journalists and many observers there is no doubt that people believe you have already misled this Parliament, abused the truth, at least three times. If today we are not satisfied with your answer, and it is actually proven to be otherwise than what you have said to us, it is clear that you will have misled the Parliament at least three more times. For you to get up here and to say that you have a unique relationship--

TALK.START.PARA: —On a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker: I regret to interrupt the speech of the honourable member, but he keeps referring to `you'. This has been referred to by you and by another member on the opposite benches, and I would ask you to remind the speaker to refer to the Minister by name.
—I note the point of order of the honourable member for Moore. I am sure that the honourable member for Braddon is aware of my earlier remarks and that he will work within those arrangements.

—For the Minister to refer to his unique relationship with the Secretary of his Department is absolute bunkum, nonsense, ludicrous, and again is misleading this Parliament-because that was not the situation. People know that. In fact, sometimes it went three months and the Minister of the Department never spoke to his Department head. That is a unique relationship for sure! It is a unique relationship that the Minister would not even spend time talking to his Department head. That is the sort of unique relationship that the Labor Party has, that the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs had with his former head of Department. That is an incredible situation.

SPEECH.PARA: For the Minister to say that we launched an attack on Aboriginal Australians, that we launched an attack on Charlie Perkins's family or on Charlie Perkins himself, is absolute nonsense. The whole debate over the last two years in this Parliament in regard to Aboriginal affairs has not been about the Aboriginal people themselves; it has been about the incompetence of this Minister and the lack of strength on the part of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to sack him. The debate has not been about the Aboriginal people themselves. In fact, we have mentioned many, many times their need for health, education and housing facilities, and so on. Nobody in this Parliament resiles from that. They know that it is very important to the Aboriginal people that they have those facilities, that they are treated equally with other Australians in those matters. We do not back away from that. In fact, it is a very firm commitment of ours.

But the situation with which we are faced in this Parliament is that on several occasions the Minister has spoken here and it has been subsequently proved that he misled this Parliament. Today we have a letter from the former Secretary of his Department which is very clear, as the shadow Minister stated. It gives a very clear indication that he discussed matters with the Minister prior to that meeting. The Minister says that he never discussed those matters. Obviously, the truth lies somewhere, and it does not appear to be clear at this stage to this Parliament.

Over the last two years there have been four major investigations into the administration of Aboriginal affairs, totalling 337 pages. The Minister regards himself as being a good Minister in regard to the ATSIC legislation, yet there have been 92 amendments already to a new piece of legislation. That does not seem to be competent administration. Over 100 questions have been asked in this and the other place in regard to the administration of Aboriginal affairs and over 800 questions asked in Senate Estimates committees. That has been generated by poor administration of the Department of Aboriginal Affairs through this Minister. It is an absolute disgrace that that has occurred to those people who are culturally recognised as the most disadvantaged group of this nation.

Today the Minister indicated to us that he does not believe the letter that we have received is an accurate record. The shadow Minister gave a very plausible argument that it will not rest there. If we had not had two years of discussion on Aboriginal Affairs; if this had come up only now-if we had not had the report on the National Aboriginal and Islander Health Organisation (NAIHO) and the discussions about that when the Minister misled the Parliament, this House and the other place; if we had not had the audit report on NAIHO where he misled the Parliament again, and if we had not had-- Mr Hand-I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. I have not misled the Parliament. That has not been proven. The fact is the organisation the honourable member is referring to is still not funded. I ask that that be withdrawn.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister has no point of order.
—I ask that it be withdrawn because it is not true.
—The Minister has no point of order.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, the very fact that he wants to limit the debate in here indicates that the Minister is scared of our raising this issue in the Parliament. I have already mentioned the NAIHO funding and the NAIHO report. He also said that the Australian Aboriginal Affairs Council made unanimous decisions when it did not. It did not make unanimous decisions. It is absolute bunkum for the Minister to indicate that there were unanimous decisions. I refer people back to what he said at the time that question was asked. This is just one illustration. This was his explanation to the Parliament:

SPEECH.PARA: There was a tied vote. Therefore the vote lapsed. There was a unanimous decision that I would write to them and I would communicate with them. Therefore it is unanimous.
What a lot of bunkum. It is nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's true.

—Nonsense. The Minister knows that the Minister responsible for Aboriginal affairs in Queensland said that it was not unanimous. The situation today is that we are not sure of this Minister. We do not trust this Minister when he comes into the Parliament. We are uncertain of the future of administration of Aboriginal affairs in a very major way. I seek leave to table a letter from Charles Perkins dated 3 August 1989.

SPEECH.PARA: Leave granted.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —Once again we have seen an erroneous attack upon the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand). What this irrelevant matter of public importance raised by the Opposition demonstrates is the paucity of policy by the Opposition and the repugnant opportunism of the shadow Minister, the honourable member for Bass (Mr Smith), and the previous shadow Minister, the honourable member for Braddon (Mr Miles)-a discredited previous shadow Minister who was dumped by the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) but who has come in here and argued against the bona fides of the Minister. We all know about the honourable member for Braddon. Let me tell honourable members a bit about him. He is the man who was shadow Minister at the time that his colleagues in the Senate attacked Mr Charles Perkins and other leading Aboriginal people. He knows who they are: Pat Dodson, Rob Riley, Charles Perkins, Peter Yu, Cedric Wyatt. The honourable member was the shadow Minister at the time. I would like to refer the House to some of the unsavoury comments and malevolent attacks which were made upon Aboriginal people by the honourable member's colleagues, and in particular the malevolent attacks which were made upon Charles Perkins.
—You attacked Senator Collins.
—I quote Senator Collins from the Senate Hansard of 31 August:

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Tambling has accused this individual Australian-
referring to Charles Perkins-
of-
and remember, the honourable member for Braddon and the honourable member for Bass were both members of the Opposition when these attacks were taking place-

nepotism and cronyism; associating with criminals; lousy and inefficient administration; suspicious behaviour; being in control of a black mafia; being responsible for scandals and rorts; a confidant of unsavoury persons; running a network of mates and cronies; appointing his crony to be manager of the ADC; setting up gangs of lefties around Australia and suspicious networks; disgraceful administration; poor administration; conducting a lot of funny business at the crossroads; suffering from amnesia; and running an unguided missile of an administration.

Those were the comments made by your colleagues, shadow Minister, when this person, the honourable member for Braddon, was the shadow Minister. On not one occasion did you or your colleagues repudiate those remarks because you tacitly agreed with them. You connived with them. You knew what Tambling was saying in the Senate and you agreed with what he said in the Senate, because that is what you want.

TALK.START.PARA: —The honourable member must refer to the member by his seat.

—Well, he will not have it for long. I refer to the honourable member for Braddon and, indeed, the honourable member for Bass. It is unfortunate because I gave the honourable member for Bass more credit than that. Indeed, when he was appointed shadow Minister, I said-as did my friend the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs-on a radio program, `I look forward to a fruitful working relationship with the shadow Minister. He showed some commonsense, something the previous shadow Minister did not have'. It seems, unfortunately, that the present shadow Minister shares the same lack of commonsense that the previous shadow Minister had. Had he any commonsense either then or now he would have repudiated every one of those remarks which were made by Senator Tambling in the Senate about Charles Perkins. We have not yet heard an apology being made to Charles Perkins by the shadow Minister, the previous shadow Minister, or any other member of the Opposition with regard to these attacks made by their colleagues in the Senate. They are the people who represent Opposition members' interests. They placed on notice 800 questions to the Estimates Committee. They all related, almost certainly, to these sorts of scurrilous attacks made upon individuals, organisations and the Government by Senator Tambling, Senator Short and his other accomplices. Are you telling me that in the party room you did not sit down together and discuss which questions would be asked and who would be embarrassed?
—No, I didn't.

—You did not? How do you run the shadow ministry? No wonder you are on the back bench again because it seems to me you have just shown why you are a fool. You do not understand the nuances of Parliament; you do not understand the relationship between yourself and the back bench.
—I suggest to the honourable member for the Northern Territory that he withdraw the previous reference to the honourable member for Braddon and refer to him by his seat.
—If the honourable member for Braddon is concerned that I called him a fool, I apologise for calling him a fool.
—No, the Chair is asking you to withdraw. It has nothing to do with the honourable member for Braddon.

—I withdraw, Mr Deputy Speaker. I cannot be held responsible for the lack of commonsense, the outrageous behaviour or the malevolent remarks made by the honourable member for Braddon or, in this case, the honourable member for Bass. Let us go to the point of today's matter of public importance. It seems rather strange to me that Opposition members did not check their facts in the first instance. I would have thought they would have at least referred to the Senate Hansard, because in the Senate Estimates Committee Hansard of 25 October 1988 Senator Tambling asked Mr Perkins about discussions that might have taken place between the Aboriginal Development Commission, the Department of Aboriginal Affairs and the Minister's office. I refer the honourable member for Bass to his statements about arguments or conversations that may have taken place between the Minister's staff and Mr Perkins or Mr Perkins's office. Let me tell him what Mr Perkins's reply to this question was. Senator Tambling asked:

SPEECH.PARA: So there were no discussions with Mr Rob Riley or Mr Andrew Jack in the Minister's office in the week prior to the ADC meeting?
The shadow Minister might like to listen to the answer:

Officers never discussed any matters, if you are referring to the ADC. We were over there, now and then, but I do not think I was over there because I was travelling most of the time, I do not recollect any officers having those discussions with the Minister's office, certainly not about the ADC.

There it is on the record by Mr Perkins at an Estimates committee meeting. Is the honourable member telling me that Mr Perkins, as the permanent head of a department, was not aware of his responsibilities as permanent head? Is he telling me that Mr Perkins, who was the permanent head of a department, was not aware that if the Minister had in some way erred in his response to this Parliament-he had not-Mr Perkins had a responsibility to remind the Minister, to tell the Minister, that he had erred in his response to the Parliament or, if he did not want to go and see the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs, that he could use the power he had and go and see the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke)? Is he telling me that he would not have done that?

Mr Perkins has a very special position in this community and Mr Perkins had the ear of the Minister, the Prime Minister and several other senior Ministers. There is not on record in this place any evidence that Mr Perkins went to see the Minister or the Prime Minister to suggest to either of them that he had erred in what was said in this House, or in what Senator Tate said in the Senate. I think that demonstrates-I take it the honourable member would agree with me-that Mr Perkins took his job seriously.

TALK.START.PARA: —That's why he didn't say anything until he retired.

—Is the honourable member saying, therefore, that Mr Perkins deliberately misled the Minister and the Prime Minister by not going to them and telling them that the Minister had erred in his response to the House? Is he saying that? If he is, he should go outside this House and accuse Mr Perkins of misleading the Minister. I do not think Mr Perkins ever misled the Minister in this respect and I do not think Mr Perkins misled the Prime Minister. The honourable member accepts, does he not, Mr Perkins's bona fides as the permanent head of the Department? He said so. In fact during his speech he said, `Mr Perkins did keep him advised of all matters as befitting his position as permanent head'. Now, if Mr Perkins kept the Minister advised of all matters, as befitting his position as permanent head, given his responsibilities as permanent head of the Department he had the responsibility to advise the Minister on the answers he gave to this House in relation to issues which dealt with his portfolio for which Mr Perkins had some responsibility.
—Was he the Secretary then?
—Yes, he was Secretary then, just for your information. Do not ask the clown behind you because he would not know.
—Order! That does not help the debate. I would ask the member for Northern Territory to withdraw the reflection upon the honourable member.

—But he makes us laugh, Mr Deputy Speaker. I cannot find another word to describe the laughter he brings to us. There is no doubt that this is the sort of repugnant opportunism which is a symbol of this Opposition's tawdry performance in opposition. Opposition members sink so low as to make the sort of statements they have made about Charlie Perkins and other Aboriginal people, and about this Government and this Minister, yet they know they have been wrong time and time and time again. They do not have the good grace to accept that they are wrong. They are wrong again on this occasion and they have never taken the opportunity, which is freely available to them, to apologise to those people they have attacked and attempted to undermine.
—Order! The honourable member's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I wish to make a personal explanation.
—Does the honourable member claim to have been misrepresented?
—I do.
—The honourable member may proceed.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, during the speech by the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs (Mr Hand) he made a reference to me and suggested that I had moved a motion in the Parliament to provide in camera evidence for general release to the public. I think he used words to the effect of `spreading the evidence all around the place'. The motion referred to is contained on page 2234 of the Daily Hansard dated 2 November 1988. That motion reads:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the standing and sessional orders be suspended as would prevent the member for O'Connor moving:

That this House authorises the release of all in-camera evidence provided to the Standing Committee on Expenditure Inquiry 1984-85 into the Aboriginal Development Commission and all documents, proceedings and reports of this Committee to the Minister for Aboriginal Affairs and to all other persons directly associated with such inquiries into the Aboriginal Development Commission or the Aboriginal Affairs Department as the Minister authorises.

I put it to you, sir, that that in no way was the motion aimed at spreading evidence all over the place-unless the Minister, of course, had that intention. His allegation is simple. He said I was going to spread it all over the place, and that is not the case. It is typical of his Goebbels attitude.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The member for O'Connor has concluded his personal explanation.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. First of all, `Goebbels' and not `Gurbells' is the correct pronunciation. The point is that the effect of the honourable member's proposal was that it would--
—Well, only if you were not going--
—That is all right; you have had your point of order. You might be able to get away with stuffing up things at Question Time. He is the Liberals' answer to Squizzy Taylor.
—Order! I ask the Minister to speak to the Chair.
—I will speak to the Chair. The point about it, Mr Deputy Speaker--
—You set out to tell a lie.
—The honourable member for O'Connor is not assisting the Chair.

—I did not set out to tell a lie at all. The point is that the honourable member for O'Connor knew full well at the time of the debate that adopting his proposal would enable that information to be circulated widely. That was his intention. It was his intention to get it spread as widely as he could, and that was the proposal I rejected.
—Order! The Chair has heard the point of order.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, I again seek leave to make a personal explanation.
—You are trying the Chair. Do you mean a personal explanation or a point of order? Do you claim to have been misrepresented?
—Yes.
—The honourable member for O'Connor may proceed.

—The Minister just said it was my intention to have the matter spread all over the place. He is repeating the argument which I have just completely rebutted. The motion moved, as I have read it, was to give the information to the Minister and to such other persons as he authorised. If he believed he was going to pass it to the press, that was his business.
—The Chair has heard the point of order and you have now put your position on record as the honourable member for O'Connor in relation to that motion.

—I raise a point of order, Mr Deputy Speaker. The honourable member for O'Connor, in a very clever stunt, is trying to misrepresent what I have said. All I have said is that the intention of his proposal-that is, to give me, the Minister, the information for distribution to those people that I saw fit-was to have made available the information given to the Parliament in camera. That was the point. He knew at the time that it was given to the Parliament, in camera, through a committee which he served on. He proposed that that would be breached and distributed to other people.

—Order! The honourable member has no further point of order. I say to the honourable member for O'Connor and the Minister that it is a question of intentions. The Chair is in no position to make a judgment about that; however, to let you put the record straight, the Chair has exercised its indulgence.

DEBATE.TITLE: JOINT COMMITTEE ON THE AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Langmore Mr J.V.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, on behalf of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory, I present the Committee's report on proposals for variations of the plan of layout of the City of Canberra and its environs-variations 1989/1, items 2 and 3, 1989/2 and 1989/3 and move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the report be printed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Fischer Mr T.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Very briefly, I simply say that this report involves the lingering efforts of the Joint Committee on the Australian Capital Territory (ACT). We set up self-government. I understand that in May of next year this particular nonsense will depart the Federal Parliament and revert to the ACT Assembly. There are four very minor items involved, such as the upgrading of the Isabella Drive-Monaro Highway intersection. I will not detain the House further but I do say that, as we have gone through the agony of setting up the ACT Assembly, it should be getting on with its job and taking over this particular responsibility.

SPEECH.PARA: Question resolved in the affirmative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hollis Mr C.

TALK.START.PARA: —On behalf of the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works, I present the thirteenth and the fourteenth reports of the Committee for 1989 relating to:

SPEECH.PARA: Construction of Commonwealth Offices at Logan City, Queensland.
Fitout of Civil Aviation Authority headquarters building, Canberra.
Ordered that the reports be printed.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-The reports I have tabled propose the construction of an office building of 6,990 square metres of accommodation to provide accommodation for several Commonwealth agencies at Logan City, Queensland, and the proposed fitout of the Civil Aviation Authority headquarters building in Canberra. The first report proposes the construction of a three-storey office building to provide accommodation for the local offices of the Department of Social Security, the Commonwealth Employment Service, and several other Commonwealth agencies. The Committee inspected the existing offices of the Department of Social Security and the Commonwealth Employment Service and found both offices to be of poor standard and inadequate to meet the needs of the agencies. With respect to the proposed building, the Committee recommends that public toilets be provided on the ground floor additional to those previously proposed by the Department of Administrative Services, and that measures be introduced to ensure the security of staff and records.

SPEECH.PARA: Two particular issues have, in recent times, kept reappearing before the Committee when it has been considering proposed government building projects. These issues concern the provision of car parking spaces and the provision of child-care facilities. The Committee notes in the report that the Department of Administrative Services is to review its existing policy where parking facilities are generally provided only for official vehicles at government buildings. With respect to the provision of child-care facilities, the Committee recommends that the current policy, which is that child-care facilities not be provided in Commonwealth offices, be reviewed. The estimated cost of the building is $9.6m at April 1989 prices. It is expected that construction will commence in November of this year, with completion scheduled for January 1991.

The second report proposes fitout works for the Civil Aviation Authority headquarters building in Canberra. The fitout is 16,500 square metres of floor space and will provide a suitable standard of accommodation for the majority of central office staff. The Committee believes that relocation of Civil Aviation Authority staff into a central location will result in a more efficient use of resources and will improve staff morale. The estimated cost of the proposed work is $13.4m at July 1989 prices. I commend these reports to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I seek to make a statement on behalf of the citizens of Logan City and to commend the members of the Public Works Committee on their foresight in recommending the construction of the Commonwealth Offices at Logan City, which is adjacent to my electorate office. Whilst one certainly does not wish to see an expansion of services in relation to social security and Commonwealth employment services within the Logan City area, one is also mindful of the very difficult situation in which people work, and the services that are provided. These are very people oriented programs and we have had very successful back to work programs and very successful programs-in particular, the jobs, education and training adviser, and the return of sole parents into the work force. Indeed, beneficiaries from the Woodridge social security office have decreased by 20 per cent in the last 18 months due to some very active work in the work force planning areas and in targeting people with special needs. However, despite that reduction, the office is still far too small, and the new office, which will also house a number of other government agencies, will meet the needs of the people and demonstrate that this Commonwealth Government has a commitment to the people in Logan City and is prepared to make infrastructure developments which will support them, provide long term services, and provide work, not only in the building and construction of such an office but also in providing facilities for work in the very much longer term.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-Whilst the Opposition does not oppose the recommendations of the Public Works Committee on these two matters, and they were before the House at the time they were referred, it is worth making two points. The Civil Aviation Authority, no doubt, could do with these improved office facilities at this very time as its staff must be working around the clock fast-tracking the Government's proposals for the proper ticketing of foreign pilots, whom it is using to break the pilots strike, and certifying foreign aircraft from all over the world, which is apparently necessary to carry Australian passengers and which, according to its own statement, normally would take some months.

SPEECH.PARA: So, as has been pointed out, a proper working environment for the workers at the Civil Aviation Authority is essential as the Government is putting them under considerable pressure in regard to the programs it has embarked upon in its strikebreaking. I do not say that critically at all. I just want it recognised that it must be a considerable extra workload for the work force of the Civil Aviation Authority. It is a pity, therefore, that they do not now have these new and more acceptable facilities in which to do all this extra work. If they are doing their job properly, they would be working around the clock compared to the amount of time they would normally take on these matters.

No doubt the honourable member who spoke before me, the honourable member for Forde (Ms Crawford), is delighted that a bit of the pork barrel has arrived in her electorate. I made the point the other day that, notwithstanding the Government's demand that the economy be cooled, that the private sector spend less and the terrible pressure that has been placed on home owners and the home building industry, the Government continues in the twilight of its term of office to rush around announcing new projects for office buildings built with taxpayers' dollars. The Minister some day might explain to the House how that is not reheating the economy, which his Treasurer (Mr Keating) tells us is supposed to be hosed down.

One cannot have one's cake and eat it too. If it is time for restraint, it seems a peculiar time for honourable members opposite to be running around from electorate to electorate announcing new projects. We will have the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) get up in a minute and tell us about the grave necessity of all these improvements he is getting-I have been in his airport a few times and he is probably right-but it does not alter the fact that the Government is embarking on a major construction program. We have the Minister in here nearly every day, either telling the Parliament about some program that has been referred to the Public Works Committee or having that Committee come back and say, `Spend the money-pork-barrel the member for Forde'.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is not pork-barrelling.

—The honourable member can call it what she likes but there is a strange coincidence; all of these projects are popping up in the twilight of this Government's term and, of course, they are in total conflict with the Treasurer's demand that we have constraint, particularly in the construction industry which has been overheated to heck, as the Treasurer is fond of saying. He attacks members of the general community and tells them it is all their fault. Of course, it is always someone else's fault. They are the people who want a Hills hoist in their backyard, but they have to constrain themselves from that desire. The Treasurer tells them that they are paying too much for houses and attacks the housing construction industry, the banks and any other industry that puts its head above the trenches. He tries to hose down the economy. Yet here we are again discussing major expenditures recommended by the Government in marginal electorates. As I have said, we are not objecting to this project; we are just making the point that there is considerable hypocrisy in the Government's stance regarding who should bear the burden of economic restraint. It is clearly not to be the Government; it is to be the home owners, who are really struggling.

—Mr Deputy Speaker, I raise a point of order about what the honourable member for O'Connor was saying. I hope he was not directing it at the Public Works Committee. He said that we come in here every day recommending certain things, and then he went on to talk about pork-barrelling. I make the point that the Public Works Committee is a joint statutory committee- Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Blanchard)-Order! The honourable member will resume his seat. There is no point of order, as he well knows.

DEBATE.TITLE: REDEVELOPMENT OF TERMINAL FACILITIES AT ALICE SPRINGS AIRPORT

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Reference of Work: Public Works Committee Act

SPEECH.SPEAKER: West The Hon S.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That, in accordance with the provisions of the Public Works Committee Act 1969, the following proposed work be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works for consideration and report: Redevelopment of terminal facilities at Alice Springs airport.

On 1 April 1989 the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC) assumed ownership of Alice Springs Airport. As part of the transfer arrangement the Corporation agreed to develop new terminal facilities on the site. I might digress and say to the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) that I do not, nor does the Government, consider in any way that we are in conflict with the macro-economic policy of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) in following a planned program--

TALK.START.PARA: —Your faction is in conflict all the time.

—We are not in conflict with macro-economic policy in any way in following a planned program of necessary public works in this country. If the Opposition wants to say to the people of the Northern Territory that they should not have a new domestic terminal at Alice Springs Airport, the political consequences will fall upon them in the Northern Territory. I just hope that the honourable member for O'Connor keeps saying that.
—We are not saying that, clearly.

—I am making it clear, too, that this public work that I am referring to the Public Works Committee today is a component of a planned public works program which can continue despite the exigencies of the macro-economic policy of the day. It is necessary because the existing terminal building was built back in 1963, I understand by a Liberal government. It has already been extended twice and now stands at just 1,460 square metres of covered space. Have honourable members ever heard anything so ridiculous? Yet the Opposition is canning this public work that we want to proceed with. There is excessive overcrowding due to the high sustained growth over many years, as the terminal now handles 960 passengers in a peak hour. This has resulted in airline passenger handling areas operating well below acceptable standards. The Corporation is simply proposing a new terminal and surrounding infrastructure at an indicative cost of $20m at July 1989 prices. The proposed terminal is designed to handle 1,500 passengers in a peak hour rate made up of something like 511-odd arrivals, 513 transfers and approximately 445 departures.

SPEECH.PARA: The conceptual design takes into account the forecast passenger and aircraft movements and the space requirements requested by both Ansett Airlines of Australia and Australian Airlines, along with the forecast aircraft parking requirements in the mid to late 1990s. The work comprises a new terminal of approximately 9,000 square metres, a new access road system and associated landscaping, vehicle parking areas and the upgrading of engineering services. I anticipate that construction would start towards the end of this year with works to be completed by mid-1991, that is, less than two years away.

The proposal was referred to the Northern Territory Conservation Commission, the Australian Heritage Commission and the Aboriginal Sacred Sites Authority and has been judged environmentally acceptable by all those authorities. The proposal will be funded from non-Budget sources by the FAC and will incorporate measures to maximise commercial returns to the Federal Airports Corporation. It will greatly assist the Northern Territory by boosting construction activity and by providing a more attractive gateway to the many internationally renowned and famous tourist attractions in northern Australia, in this case around Alice Springs and at Yulara and Uluru. I have great pleasure in tabling the drawings of this proposal, and despite the rantings of the Opposition. I commend this motion to the House.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey Mr C.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I hope that the honourable member for the Northern Territory (Mr Snowdon) hears me say that the Opposition does not oppose the recommendation that this matter be referred to the Parliamentary Standing Committee on Public Works. I had said in my previous aside-I was addressing the office construction in Logan City-that, having been in the Alice Springs airport on numerous occasions, I recognised the need for a new facility. Let me get that straight. But that did not stop my raising the general question of the Government's macro-economic policy. I am pleased that the Chairman of the Public Works Committee, the honourable member for Throsby (Mr Hollis), is present, because I hope he takes these remarks on board.

SPEECH.PARA: The Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) has made available to me a copy of the plans proposed and I thank him. I am very impressed with the innovative design. It is unique in many ways and seems at a glance to have quite a lot going for it. Nevertheless, there is one important factor of the design that is relevant to a current situation confronting Australia. It relates to a facility for Australian Airlines and Ansett Airlines of Australia. I cannot identify one area-I have studied it very carefully and I hope the Minister is able to correct me-where another airline operating under the deregulated system could independently operate. The Government can get down on its hands and knees to Ansett or Australian and be treated in the way that we know it will be treated at all the other major airports where the Government, prior to its handing over the major airports to the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), was at pains to guarantee almost a complete monopoly of the airport facilities available, and--

TALK.START.PARA: —Forced them to lease them.
—It forced them to be leased before the FAC, which is supposed to be some sort of independent authority, could get into the business of making some proper and reasonable arrangements.

SPEECH.PARA: This is the problem that faces this Government in the pilots strike, and the Government knows it. We are not talking about an ordinary industrial relations system. We are talking about a system that is operating for another 14 months under regulation-a two-airline policy-which gives huge industrial power to pilots, flight attendants, refuellers and the rest. With deregulation, which will come into force about the time our Party opens this building, we will have a situation where other airlines will want to compete and create an environment allowing voluntary contracts.

We know very well that the new airlines that will be operating under voluntary contracts will not be trapped into this Government's industrial relations system and accord. They will have the sorts of bonus systems and incentive systems for their work force, whether for pilots or aircraft cleaners, that give people the incentive to be productive and lift Australia out of this mess. The Government is making sure that those locked into its system through history will have such a massive privilege in terms of airport facilities that the others will be in the situation that poor old East-West Airlines Ltd was in at one stage, having to run a baggage collection service from a vehicle on the footpath. We saw it out here at Canberra Airport. There is a bit of history that makes that difficult. Here we are-I address myself to the Chairman of the Public Works Committee-looking at a proposal for a brand new airport. What are the Government and its Federal Airports Corporation doing about deregulation? They are doing nothing-not a thing.

TALK.START.PARA: —It's a sham.

—It is an absolute sham because the Government will give such a huge advantage to the two established airlines that deregulation will be a myth. We know why that is-because the Government does not believe in deregulation. It has been forced by community attitudes. It has been sneaking around the back trying to get a little bit of micro-economic reform past this Minister and a few others.
—What they are doing on the waterfront.

—If we ever want evidence of what will happen on the waterfront, we get it in this drawing. We will have a lot of words about it. Under the proposed Waterfront Industry Reform Authority-the process by which the Government puts Dracula in charge of the blood bank-it gives two groups of people, namely, the stevedores and the Waterside Workers Federation, the total responsibility for this.

SPEECH.PARA: This building is another example of the Government's genuine approach to micro-economic reform. Those opposite go out there and give lip service to it, but when we get down to the printed word, the draftsmen's efforts, which are before us here, what do we find? A two-airline policy, in a building that is going to be open about the time that deregulation occurs. That is a wonderful situation! There is nowhere that an independent operator can work in this system. One side is for Ansett check-in and Ansett administration; the other side is for Australian check-in, Australian administration. There are two baggage claim areas. In other words, there are two areas for Ansett and Australian to come in.

The honourable member for the Northern Territory is likely to stand up in a minute and defend the Government's action on this. He is telling the tourist operators in his electorate, `We, the Labor Party, don't really want you to benefit in any way from half price fares coming in to Alice Springs, as might occur in a deregulated airline system. Yes, you will have to go around to the hangar or somewhere like that to get out of your plane'. Those are just the sorts of things to impress American tourists and others when they get on to domestic airlines. It is too bad if Qantas Airways Ltd wants to go there. Perhaps the honourable member is so confident about the amalgamation of Qantas and Australian that he does not think that is a problem. If we are going to have genuine deregulation, it is possible that Qantas will want to go into Alice Springs. There will be no room for it, no room for others such as United Airlines, who may want to fly in there. We have these brand new jets that fly huge distances now and just might want to come into Alice Springs. There will be no opportunity.

We have the perfect evidence in this proposal of the Government's true attitude to deregulation. It is a farce. That means more of the same in terms of industrial relations. The Government is trying to keep the lid on the pilots, who have such massive industrial power because of the way the Government has organised the two-airline system, and this is the evidence that the Government sees that system going on in perpetuity. It is not really getting out of it. It has given lip service to it. Its intention is to make it so difficult for new entrants that they will give up and die and go away or try flying in some other country or whatever. They will not be able to make it. They cannot operate an airline without equal treatment on the ground. They are not going to get it in Melbourne; they are not going to get it in Sydney; they might get it in Brisbane, because there is some spare space up there.

TALK.START.PARA: —We built that.

—Yes, we designed that. The reality is that, on this drawing, they are certainly not going to get it in Alice Springs. The honourable member should say, because he says he likes to speak up for his constituents, whether that is acceptable to him. I challenge him to say whether this design, which confines the activities at Alice Springs Airport to all intents and purposes to a two-airline system, is satisfactory to him. We will get a real test of his commitment to the electorate if he says that is so. He had better not dodge the question because he likes throwing a bit of advice around the place. He had better tell us whether that is satisfactory. If it is, let us get that around in Alice Springs. I hope the first press release is that he is dissatisfied with the Government and with the FAC's proposal in this regard.

SPEECH.PARA: It is a very concerning matter that has been brought before the Parliament today. Here we are with the nation stopped and heaps and heaps of tourist operators, small businesses and large, in the electorate of the honourable member for the Northern Territory struggling like mad. The Northern Territory Government is doing more about it than the Federal Government. It at least has the Brunei people in there to give a bit of a hand. The reality is that his Government is doing nothing about solving the problem. We know that at the bottom of this problem is the two-airline policy, and here he is just about to stand up and tell us about this wonderful improvement that his Government proposes for the Alice Springs Airport.

I will tell the honourable member what the improvement is. It is a message that says more of the same-more pilots strikes in the future, more high air fares, loaded up with staff and feather-bedding-all because this Government does not genuinely believe in the two-airline policy, any more than this Minister believes in the selling of Australian Airlines, the Commonwealth Bank or any of those other things. At heart those opposite are regulators. Nobody is more of a regulator than the Minister who has brought this proposal to the Parliament, and if we ever wanted a better demonstration as to how he is going to get around the decision of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to deregulate the airline industry, we have it in these drawings. It is quite outrageous that we see that in such a small centre, where it is so important to have a clear opportunity for independent airlines to operate, the Government proposes a two-airline airport facility. I sincerely hope that the recommendation to this Parliament from the Public Works Committee is that that is not acceptable and that the Government must do something about it. Considering the factional connections of the Chairman of that Committee, I doubt that he really wants that to happen, either.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Snowdon Mr W.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am extremely gratified to be able to speak on this important matter. It is important in a number of respects. As the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) belatedly but at last acknowledged, a public works project of this type is extremely important, not only to the Northern Territory but also to the Australian travel industry and to the airlines in particular. It seems to me that he has completely ignored the facility that exists within the Public Works Committee structure to seek out information from the Federal Airports Corporation (FAC), the body that is responsible for building this facility. This is an FAC project. It is not a project of the Department of Administrative Services.

SPEECH.PARA: The honourable member for O'Connor should at least learn the procedures of the House and of this Government, and understand how these matters are discussed and dealt with by the Public Works Committee. He might also acknowledge to the Parliament that he has at least some trifling understanding of the plans that were put in front of him. I do not have them in front of me.
