There is no clear evidence that another airline will provide services to Alice Springs or, indeed, Darwin once deregulation comes about.

What he also ought to acknowledge is that there is scope within the plans which have been put before the House for expansion, for change, to allow for the incorporation of further operators. The honourable member for O'Connor is trying to have a lend of us because he does understand the processes of the Public Works Committee. He does understand the processes which allow for people to put in submissions to the Public Works Committee and to argue their case in front of that Committee. He also understands the planning that goes into providing capital works of this type and the fact that it is impossible at this point to plan for further operators who may use Alice Springs airport. He does not acknowledge it because it is convenient for him not to.

He does not show any understanding of the economics of the airline industry. If he had any understanding or any knowledge of the economics of the airline industry he would know that it is very likely, in terms of passenger numbers carried at present by aircraft in the Northern Territory, that if another operator or operators wish to enter Northern Territory air space and use Alice Springs and Darwin airports-in this case, Alice Springs airport-they will need to have a very low cost structure.

I suggest that the honourable member for O'Connor might like to get a bit of advice on the potential impact of deregulation of the airline industry on northern Australia. I do not think he understands it. I do not think he has any knowledge of it. Instead of coming in here and crowing about what knowledge he does not have, he ought to go out and find a bit and then tell us what he knows, instead of what he does not know. Today he has expressed very clearly to the House his ignorance on the subject of deregulation of the airline industry, and the economics of the airline industry in northern Australia after deregulation.

The subject of this reference is an extremely important and vital development in the Alice Springs area. It has been something which, despite what the honourable member for O'Connor has had to say, was on the Government's agenda prior to the last election. As the Minister for Administrative Services (Mr West) quite correctly pointed out, on transference of the responsibility to the FAC on 1 April he made it plain at that point in time that it would be building a new airport at Alice Springs and that the value would be around $20m. The existing terminal-the honourable member for O'Connor at least acknowledged the need in this instance, previously when he has spoken in debates in this place or on matters like this in relation to public works in the Northern Territory he has not even deigned to acknowledge their need-was built in 1963 and had two subsequent additions.

The terminal, as the honourable member for O'Connor and every other honourable member in this House who has used that terminal knows, is subject to excessive overcrowding. The airline passenger handling areas are well below acceptable standards and the transportable buildings used as departure holding lounges for security streaming belong in a zoo not at an airport. The working conditions of airline employees are, to say the least, not so much out of date as antediluvian. They have no appropriate recreational areas and no service facilities for staff. It is something which is quite outrageous and something which this particular project will remedy.

The Alice Springs airport is one of the busiest in Australia outside the major metropolitan areas. Indeed, in 1980 passenger movements were 210,000. By 1988 that number had increased to 509,000. It is, I understand, the ninth or tenth busiest airport in Australia. It is busier than Darwin. Approximately two-fifths of the air travellers through the Alice Springs airport are tourists and we get 192,000 of those visitors to Central Australia for a short duration as a result of using the airport. It is true, as others have indicated, that the action by the pilots in their outrageous decision which seems to be tacitly supported by the Opposition, has meant, as the honourable member for O'Connor pointed out, an attack on the ability of the airlines industry and the tourism industry to cope. Let me make very clear what the impact of this has been on Alice Springs air travel and indeed on the air terminal. It is not being overstretched at the moment because last week the number of passengers carried to Darwin and returned to Alice Springs was 4 per cent of the norm.

TALK.START.PARA: —What was it? Four per cent of the normal rate?

—Four per cent of the normal average. Now that is a result of the outrageous pilots' action, an action which unfortunately, as I have indicated, seems to have the tacit support of the Opposition. The facts are that this is a very important construction for Alice Springs. It is important not only because of the need of the tourist industry, and the airline industry in particular, but because it has quite significant community input. If one looks at the plans one sees-and the honourable member for O'Connor quite graciously referred to the nature of the plans-how attractive they are, and indeed they are, because of the community input. There is a theme around the landscape design of the place which will give people an impression of Central Australia as soon as they alight from the aircraft. This is something which is quite unusual in terms of the provision of airport facilities anywhere else in Australia, not only because they are not in Central Australia but simply because they do not, in normal circumstances, accommodate the immediate physical environment. But the Central Australian environment is unique and something which this plan has taken account of. I am happy to support the reference of the Minister for Administrative Services to the Public Works Committee and I applaud the action of the Minister in expediting this reference.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macphee The Hon I.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —As this will be my last speech in a Budget debate, I turn to my maiden speech which was given 15 years ago-on 26 September 1974. I said then that I was proud to represent the then electorate of Balaclava. Indeed for the next 10 years I was very proud to represent it. Subsequently, for the last five years, I have been extremely honoured to represent the electors of Goldstein and very gratified by the many demonstrations of support and their desire to have me continue as their member. I regret as much as they do that that will now not be possible. On that occasion-I quote from page 1918 of Hansard-I also said:

SPEECH.PARA: I anticipate that during my political life expectancy in this Parliament, the Parliament's greatest problem may well be to raise its own standing in the eyes of the community and to review its role in the decision making process.

I think it goes without saying-and I regret to say this-that the Parliament has not done any of those things. It has not lifted its standing in the eyes of the public. It has not, in fact, made itself effective. It has not given itself adequate resources. The only remotely effective part of this Parliament in terms of being a guardian of the people's interests lies in Senate committees and they are underresourced. The Auditor-General's report is not properly made use of because of the lack of resources. The same goes for the Ombudsman. The House of Representatives is nothing more than an electoral college for the Ministry and a rubber stamp for the Executive. If ever any government gets control of the Senate, then the same will be true there.

It is very sad, because this year is the 300th anniversary of the signing of the Bill of Rights in Westminster which proclaimed the sovereignty of the Westminster Parliament, particularly the House of Commons, over the Executive-at that time the King-but it was not very long really before the factions of the day, who could persuade each other on the floor of the chamber, became formulated into parties. Party discipline arose and Cabinet government followed from the time of Queen Anne onwards. So really the sovereignty of parliament-the supremacy of parliament as the representative of the people over the Executive-was very short lived indeed. I am very sad about that in my own way. Compromise though I did most of the time, I must say that I resent the fact that the party discipline and the aspirations of the Executive became so great that we now see elected people overworked and too busy as Ministers representing the non-elected Executive.

We see a situation in which pressure groups in the community must arise to assert themselves to overcome the strength of the Executive and to demand of the Executive certain statutory rights which the Executive then introduces into this Parliament and ultimately gets rubber stamped. They are, of course, the minimum which can be tolerated by the Executive but the ray of hope-if there is one-is that the courts will interpret what statutory minimum rights are tolerated in ways which may just help the sovereignty of the people. The courts may indeed be prepared to examine the actions of this Parliament, not just in terms of its proper constitutional power vis-a-vis the State parliaments, but whether measures that it passes under an undisputed constitutional power really are serving the peace, order and good government of the people of Australia. So, it is with regret that I say that parliamentary sovereignty over the Executive is now virtually non-existent and the people cannot look to the Parliament to be adequately represented. Having said that, I think that I tried to stay here in the hope of again being a Minister and again helping to produce some influence of sovereignty on the role of the Executive. But anything that rests tenuously upon busy Ministers is not a very satisfactory situation.
I also look at what I said in 1974 about inflation. I said then:

Inflation will continue making a mockery of the so-called tax concessions . . . Without an overall adjustment to our current tax structure the Government really increases its revenue each time inflation reaches new dizzy heights.

We now find in 1989, 15 years later, that those words are true. In spite of some attempts to provide tax cuts there has not been any serious restructuring of the tax system. Over the past two decades our rate of inflation has averaged 9.1 per cent per annum and between 1980-81 and 1987-88 our inflation rate was 8.3 per cent, whereas the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development average for the same period was 4.91 per cent; so we are very well ahead of the OECD average, and that is not something to be proud of. The 1988 Budget forecast for inflation was 4.5 to 5 per cent, yet the inflation rate for the financial year was in fact 7.7 per cent. Even the President of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU), Mr Crean, was quoted in the Australian of 16 August as saying that the biggest fault with the Budget was a lack of an anti-inflationary strategy. He said that there was no anti-inflationary strategy beyond trying to contain wages.

So we find in the present Budget that the forecast for the inflation rate, the rise in the consumer price index, is 7.5 per cent. We also find that bracket creep in respect of taxation made a significant contribution to the surplus that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) is boasting about in this Budget. In 1988-89 tax revenue was up 9.7 per cent, although real government expenditure fell. In fact, the $9.1 billion surplus is also boosted by businesses having to pay 85 per cent of their tax within 15 days of the end of the financial year. Firms will have to borrow, of course, to meet this commitment. Perhaps they will borrow from overseas. If they do so, they will aggravate our foreign debt level and it could have negative consequences for investment. An article in the Age of 16 August stated:

Total collections from individuals are expected to jump by 8 per cent, accounting for well over half the Government's revenue in 1989-90 and continuing the trend for individuals to carry an ever-increasing proportion of the burden.
At the end of the speech I made in 1974 I said:

. . . I wish to make an observation of a long term nature regarding inflation. It is that our materialism may need to be curbed. Perhaps we will need to search for a happy medium between economic growth for its own sake and the goal of no growth at all . . .

We have not done that as a country. I do not suggest that we all try to reduce our living standards totally consciously, but we should have a much better national appreciation of our material resources, the need to conserve them and use them sensibly, without going to the extremes of some people in the environmental movement. Of course, if we did not have them putting their more extreme arguments we would not have any debate at all about the nature of materialism in our society and its contribution to our inflation rate. I also said in that speech that in order to have an effective industrial relations machinery, we should have fewer unions and employer organisations. I said:

We have over 300 trade unions and many more employer and trade associations. We need more amalgamations on both sides of the industrial fence and a greater centralisation of authority in the hands of persons elected to carry out the democratically ascertained views of the members.

Nothing has changed, except that the ACTU, under the quite imaginative and courageous leadership of its Secretary, Mr Bill Kelty, is in fact now setting out to try to reduce those 300 unions to 20 federal national unions which ultimately will be capable of being single unions at different work places, thereby reducing demarcation disputes. I hope he can achieve it; I suspect that if I were here for another 15 years I would see some progress, but progress inevitably must be slow. The Government and employers must do all that they can to assist it. I also said in that speech:

My final observation is that when sufficient individual employers and unions give practical application to job re-design programs aimed at bringing the overall quality of working life into line with the quality of life outside the working place, and when more managements recognise that affluence and education have created expectations which cannot be satisfied by traditional systems of work, there will be a better chance of some reduction in the level of wage demand relative to productivity improvement. There should be less job turnover, less plant disputation, less absenteeism and more productivity. The wage-cost element of inflation ought therefore to be less than at present. Union leaders would not cease claiming a larger slice of the cake but they would at least be more likely to co-operate in building a larger cake to share.

Sanity will only return to industrial relations when management recognises that its most important asset is people and when unions recognise that `profit' and `productivity' are not necessarily dirty words. These observations, however, in no way relieve the Government of its duty to control inflation by its own fiscal, monetary and taxation policies.

Again, what has changed? I am pleased to say that in that respect a little has changed, and only recently has it been manifest. But I had the privilege in the period 1976 to 1979 of being the Minister for Productivity, and I jawboned, as it were, continually upon the multitude of ways in which we could reduce our unit cost of production at the place of work. I am pleased to say that, by the end of that period and certainly when I came back to that situation after three years as Minister for Immigration, I found as Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations that the message had got through to the trade union movement. The message of actually involving people in the way they do their jobs, what we called employee participation or what the unions call industrial democracy, had not proceeded quite as rapidly in the eyes of management, however. So the single biggest factor still is, as it always has been, the willingness of management to be modern, enlightened and to work with its people. But there are signs of that happening too, and all around us there are seminars being held on people performance and on the moves now being made in what was the Arbitration Commission but is now called the Industrial Relations Commission for both award restructuring and union restructuring. There is now developing slowly, but significantly, an employee relations concept, not a confrontationist industrial relations concept, but an all-embracing concept in which the way people do things, the way they communicate, is now being developed slowly as an ethos and it is only by that that we will get effective working relationships and we will get improved productivity.

To its great credit, under the equally inspired leadership of Mr Justice Maddern, the Industrial Relations Commission has introduced a concept called the structural efficiency principle. If one looks carefully at the criteria outlined there, one sees that that is the best hope yet for award variations or over-award agreements at the work place on a productivity basis. It is better late than never, and we will all need to show great patience because we are transforming entrenched attitudes. There is a huge onus on management to do precisely that.

In the last five years investment has increased by 10.6 per cent. The Government has spoken of record levels of investment and the benefits that should accrue as a result. But how is industry restructuring faring? It is not faring very well. David Clark, in the Australian Financial Review on 16 August, said:

While capacity utilisation in manufacturing was higher last year than any time since the early 1970s the Australian Bureau of Statistics estimates showed that the average age of the capital stock in manufacturing has increased, not decreased, from 9.9 years in 1966-67 to 12.8 years now.

How can we take on the rest of the world and how can we really compete with our Asian neighbours when our machinery in our factories is getting older and older? If we look at the Economic Planning Advisory Council's Paper No. 39 of April of this year, called `Productivity in Australia: The results of recent studies', we will see that precise international comparisons are not possible, but EPAC's general impression is that growth in multifactor productivity in Australia was below the OECD average of the 1960s, while the underlying growth in multifactor productivity has remained close to the OECD average since 1973. In manufacturing there may have been some relative deterioration in the first half of the 1980s and the reasons for that are, of course, that we are well ahead comparatively in productivity in agriculture but we are behind in the micro areas that we now identify, the key sectors, notably coastal shipping, port activity, rail transport, and power generation. In all of those areas productivity is below average, and of course it impacts desperately on our competitiveness in manufacturing industry.

These poor figures highlight the urgent need for action on the overdue micro-economic reform. The data is there; there are reports galore. There needs to be a political will and a leadership capacity, and so far the Government has not shown those. All employers must make the most of the opportunity of the new Industrial Relations Commission wage fixing principles. They present them with a golden opportunity to take the initiative, to get productivity improvement outcomes at the place of work, and to have a capacity to work with instead of against their employees and the unions which represent them. The challenge for manufacturing industry remains about as great as it did in 1974, and arguably it may even be greater.

A report on exports by a committee chaired by Professor Helen Hughes was released last week by Senator Button. It really is as dismal to read as was the report of the Jackson Committee to Advise on Policies for Manufacturing Industry, which was released when I first entered the Parliament. Attitudes in manufacturing industry are not changing fast enough. Most of the things that I said in those three years as Minister for Productivity-and, indeed, in my time as Director of the Victorian Chamber of Manufactures-need saying again and again. The fact is that local industry in Australia supplies 73 per cent of the requirements of our manufacturing industry. That is similar to the ratio in the United Kingdom, Canada and other medium sized developed economies. But compared with similar sized countries Australian manufacturing has a very low export orientation, and manufactured exports make a relatively small contribution to total exports. In fact, if we look at elaborately transformed manufactures, they account for a little over half of Australia's manufactured exports whereas in comparable economies they are 80 per cent of manufactured exports.

To build an enduring comparative advantage we have to have much more than just price competitiveness because of adjustments in the exchange rate. We must have areas which require more flexible and adaptive industry structures, management and work force attitudes. Beyond that we must look to comparative advantage in the areas of non-price performance such as quality, design, innovation, marketing and after-sales service. Progress has been made in some structural areas but it is not fast enough, and I regret to say that the Budget before us does nothing to accelerate the pace of reform.

SPEECH.PARA: The 1989-90 Budget, which is what we are here to discuss today in this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1), is designed to protect the social and employment gains of the past six years by easing Australia's overheated economy down to a more sustainable pace. That is not as easy as it sounds. The Budget also furthers the Government's program of economic reforms and meets the challenge of Australia's ageing population by establishing a comprehensive policy to encourage working Australians to save now for their retirement. Furthermore, the Budget recognises that Australia must increase its production so there is less pressure to cut its rate of spending. Our strategy as a government has been to bring about the economic reforms necessary to achieve this objective in the longer term. Australia can anticipate a better future but it must be based on an efficient and productive economic base.

This Budget contains many important initiatives. For instance, all pensioners, not just the aged, will receive the extra $2 weekly increase in April next year, which will lift them above 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. As most people in this House would know, that has been an objective of the Labor Party and this Labor Government for some time, and I personally am very pleased to see it achieved and in fact exceeded. This increase is over and above indexation. Rent assistance will increase by $5 a week in December 1989. An additional $5 a week will be granted in June 1990 and a further $5 in September 1990. From March 1991 these rent assistance increases will be indexed in line with the CPI.

A four-year, $100m package for youth was also included in the Budget. It will cover increased housing assistance, major improvements in income support, important means to improve the participation and education of disadvantaged young people, and an upgrading of labour market assistance and community-based health services.

An element of the Budget which I support very strongly is the extra $15m to be distributed under the existing mortgage and rent relief scheme administered by the States. There is also a $40m package to improve the health of Australian women, which is a very important proposal and one which I think most people in the community would view as essential. An increase of more than $40m over the next two years was also granted for sport and there was a 64 per cent increase in funding for environmental programs, bringing it up to $118.4m.

Along with other members on this side of the House and, undoubtedly, members on the other side of the House, I have received a number of representations from students in schools in my area about environmental issues. I think that young Australia as well as older Australia will welcome these initiatives on environmental issues, especially things like soil conservation and the one billion tree planting program which have been envisaged.

As was pointed out by the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), there has also been a $1.3 billion allocation for roads. A major restructuring of the Commonwealth Employment Service has been budgeted for, including a special $10m program to improve income support and work opportunities for unemployed people aged over 55. That too is an important initiative, as these people are often discriminated against in the community and have a great deal of trouble getting work.

The Budget forecasts an increase in real household disposable income of 4 per cent, the highest increase since 1983-84. Household disposable income will also be boosted by the 1 July tax cuts. The tax cuts and the family allowance increases have been fully funded from this Budget. Assistance ranges from around $15 a week for a single taxpayer on average weekly earnings to $30 a week for a family taxpayer with the same income.

The Government is totally committed to reducing Australia's foreign debt and has already established an impressive record in this area. It is worth noting that we have used all of the last three surpluses to pay off debt, that is, $2.1 billion in 1987-88, $5.9 billion in 1988-89 and every cent of this year's $9 billion surplus will be used to pay off debt. The Government has tackled the national savings issue in the most responsible way by lifting government-or public-savings and by encouraging the development of superannuation. Last year superannuation assets grew by $15 billion but our retirement package will ensure that that increases further to a pool of $60 billion a year by the turn of the century. I would like to read into the record part of the Better Incomes Retirement Income Policy into the Next Century document, put out by the Minister for Social Security (Mr Howe) in conjunction with the Budget. It says:

The Federal Government will implement a three-stage reform of the income test and tax overlap. The first stage which was announced in April 1989 will make the income test free area for pensioners 100 per cent tax free by July 1990. This will eliminate tax payable on non-pension income within the pension free area and simplify the way in which the social security system interacts with the tax system. The free area for a single pensioner is currently $40 a week and $70 a week for married pensioner couples.

The second stage of the Federal Government's reform is to index annually the income test free area, for social security and veterans' pensioners, from 1 July 1991. The free area will continue to be 100 per cent tax free. The free area has never before been indexed by any Federal Government. Maintaining its real value will give pensioners greater certainty in organising their finances.
The third stage of the Federal Government's reform will address the position of pensioners who have income above the income test free area-that is, part rate pensioners.

The Federal Government is committed to introducing from 1995 a better integrated system of social security and tax administration for age and service pensioners and to reducing combined pension withdrawal and tax rates.

I believe that is a very important quote and I want to make sure that gets into the record because many people do not yet realise the impact that those changes will have on their retirement living standards. Without wanting to point to you in particular, Mr Deputy Speaker, we have to thank for some of these changes the input and contribution of the Prime Minister's task force on retirement incomes, of which you were a member. Your involvement in the seminars in our electorates was very helpful and I believe the people in those areas were extremely grateful for the opportunity of input into the Government's policies. Of course the retirement incomes task force built upon the work undertaken by the social security review group headed by Professor Bettina Cass. All of these things have contributed to an excellent outcome in this Budget.

The housing assistance decisions in the Budget were very good. Together with decisions taken at the Premiers Conference, the housing package announced in the Budget amounts to a record $1,290m for direct housing assistance. The restructured Commonwealth-State housing agreement will enable 650,000 Australians to be offered public rental housing over the next five years. Home ownership assistance under the Commonwealth-State housing agreement will increase, with up to 40,000 home loans expected to be made available in 1989 and 1990. Furthermore, as foreshadowed earlier this year, additional assistance will be provided to subsidise the operation of State government approved rental housing trusts, up to $13m in 1989-90 rising to $65m in 1993-94. There has been a special allocation of $15m for a safety net to assist low to moderate income earners who are facing default on their mortgage repayments as a consequence of the effects of high interest rate levels and house prices. As I have said, this assistance will be administered by States through the State mortgage and rent relief schemes. The Commonwealth Government does not anticipate the States having the dollar for dollar input that they normally have. Although the criteria for these schemes vary they generally relate to the size of mortgage repayments as a proportion of total income. More people ought to be looking to see whether these schemes would assist them in their circumstances at present.

To conclude I believe this to be a very responsible Budget which takes account of Australia's current economic circumstances in terms of its surplus and simultaneously addresses the needs of particular sections of the community, such as pensioners, young people and older people saving for their retirement. As most members in this place are aware, economics is not an exact science. Choices must be made between competing needs and wants when allocating scarce resources. With this Budget the Government has once again made the right decisions for the nation and I commend the Bill to the House.

TALK.START.PARA: —On my way into the chamber I glanced at the speakers list and I noticed that I am to be the last Government speaker in this long debate on the 1989-90 Budget. I was struck by some of the company I am keeping on the speakers list. On the Opposition side the honourable member for Goldstein (Mr Macphee) spoke a while ago and I am to be followed by the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter). Both of these gentlemen have lost pre-selection. I understand that later this afternoon the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) will join the debate. These people, of course, four months ago lost the leadership of their parties.

SPEECH.PARA: I want at the outset to express some sympathy to these people and, indeed, some sympathy to the whole of the Opposition because, since those changes in leadership on 9 May, nothing has really gone right for the Opposition. The new leaders promised a new leadership style. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) was elected by his Party as somebody who could function as a better salesman than his predecessor. Members of the Liberal Party made a conscious decision to exchange substance in John Howard for style in Andrew Peacock, in search of a desperately needed new image for their Party. The problem is, of course, as subsequent events showed, that that image was one of deceit and backroom conspiracy. It was compounded by the deceivers parading their deceit on national television and by having those deceivers rewarded with front bench positions.

Unfortunately for the Opposition, nothing has gone right since then. Its performance over the last four months has been marked by confusion and conflict. Oppositions are supposed to stand for something. They are supposed to offer the public an alternative. But after four months we do not know where this Opposition stands on expenditure cuts or taxation. The Opposition has three major problems. Let me deal with the difficulties it faces on spending cuts. Only in June the Leader of the Opposition very proudly told the Australian people that impressive progress was being made on a program of spending cuts. Let me quote from the Sydney Morning Herald:
Mr Peacock said . . . that the Opposition's expenditure review process was well advanced and `was cracking through options at an impressive pace.'
But he again refused to outline any specific area to be cut, saying only that reductions would be bold and would be outlined `at a time of our own choosing'.

That impressive progress, of course, commenced the month before, in May, when the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), targeted health, education and welfare for the axe. Let me quote again from the Sydney Morning Herald:
The Federal Opposition will cut spending on health, education and social welfare if it comes to office, and has urged the Government to do the same immediately.
The shadow Treasurer, Dr Hewson, repeated yesterday earlier calls for cuts in social welfare with the words `I mean, how many genuinely needy people are there?'
He added that education and health expenditure would also fall under a Liberal Government.

The shadow Treasurer was immediately contradicted by the shadow Ministers for education and health. The honourable member for Flinders (Mr Reith), the shadow education Minister, told the Herald the day after that the Opposition remained committed to its announced policy that no school would be worse off and that it would maintain the existing number of tertiary places. The shadow Minister for health, the honourable member for Tangney (Mr Shack), said that under a Liberal government Medicare would concentrate on the aged and disadvantaged, and that the changes would not cost anyone more. The honourable member was not talking about any savings in his area, as is so keenly promoted by the shadow Treasurer. In July, the ever helpful Federal President of the Liberal Party, John Elliott, weighed in on the shadow Treasurer's side. He supported the attack on welfare. On 27 July, the Australian reported:
A future Peacock government would take tough decisions on welfare cuts, the federal president of the Liberal Party, Mr John Elliott, said yesterday.
Mr Elliott said the Liberal Party's position was that there were probably too many people dependent on the welfare system, and `that'll have to be changed'.
About 30 per cent of the population received some form of government hand-out and people had the mentality that `basically we deserve a piece of the welfare cake'.
Free health care and dole payments without the requirement of work were evidence of `this malaise that government knows best'.

In August, John Elliott was joined by the ever helpful Senator Stone who spoke of the `shackles of welfare'. Senator Stone complained that the growth of the welfare state has eroded Australia's level of savings. Senator Stone said that 20 years ago Australia had a very high level of savings. What had changed since then, he said, was that Australia had become a welfare state. Senator Stone claimed that people did not need to save for retirement because of the age pension, did not need to worry about unemployment because of the dole, did not need to put away a nest egg for the rainy day if they got sick because of Medicare and did not need to save to educate their children unless they wanted to send them to private schools. Senator Stone obviously wants to cut out all of those important benefits provided by government.

And so the charade went on during the winter break. On 2 August, shortly before we resumed for the Budget session, the Opposition social security spokesman was subjected to some questioning on the AM radio program on the proposed social welfare cuts. Peter Thompson of AM said to the honourable member for Bradfield (Mr Connolly):

Let's turn to social welfare cuts because it's been suggested by a number of sources in your party, including Senator Stone who talks about shackles of welfare, and by Mr Elliott, that there will be substantial cuts in welfare if the Liberals are elected.
The honourable member for Bradfield replied:
Well, I can assure you they will not be substantial, but of course that's a value judgment as to what you mean by substantial.

So there is the answer from the straight-talking honourable member for Bradfield. What a mess the Opposition is in on the subject of spending cuts. On the one side we have the cutters: the shadow Treasurer, the Federal President of the Liberal Party and Senator Stone. On the other side we have the shadow Ministers for education and health defending their areas. Somewhere in the middle, sitting on the fence, is the shadow Minister for social security. What was the response of their new Leader to this dilemma? How would he resolve that and sort his people out so that the public would know what the Liberal Party stands for? His answer was, basically, to con the public. It was revealed at the end of July that, in fact, the Leader of the Opposition had two lists of expenditure cuts, one public and one secret. Let me read from the Sydney Morning Herald of 26 July an article by Milton Cockburn:
The Federal Opposition has decided not to release all its proposed spending cuts when it outlines its taxation and expenditure policies after next month's Budget.
It has decided, instead, to draw up two lists of spending cuts: one for public release and another, detailing more severe cuts, which will be kept secret.
The decision is likely to be controversial-
which is an understatement-
since the Opposition has consistently called on the Government to make further cuts in government spending in order to reduce interest rates.
But the Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, is prepared to weather criticism that the proposed cuts do not go far enough and do not match its rhetoric.

Key shadow ministers have decided this is preferable to the Opposition revealing all its cards now and finding itself the target of disaffected interest groups which will be hurt by the proposed cuts.

That is the response of this new Leader who was elected by his Party on 9 May to offer the Liberal Party a new image. The Opposition plays the same game with the public as the honourable members for Ryan (Mr Moore) and O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) played with their former Leader. They play the same game with defence spending. The Liberal Party Federal Council was quite happy to vote for an additional $9 billion of defence expenditure, at the same time as its leadership was calling for cuts of a billion dollars in total government spending, and hopes to get away with it. The Opposition cannot come clean on spending and it cannot come clean on tax, the second of its major problems.

In June the Leader of the Opposition promised a flatter, two-tiered tax scale and a mortgage relief scheme. By 3 August he had backed away from the mortgage relief scheme. An article in the Sydney Morning Herald of 3 August stated:
The Leader of the Opposition, Mr Peacock, said yesterday he had dropped an earlier commitment to announce some form of mortgage relief scheme after the Budget.

Those opposite cannot decide on their tax policy. Under the Liberals, in the unlikely event that they might be elected some time this side of the year 2000, we do not know whether we will be looking at a top rate of 49, 47, 39 or 30 per cent. The Leader of the Opposition in his reply to the Budget said, `We will ensure that the top rate for individuals is not higher than the company tax rate', but a day after that he was backing away from that proposition.

It is a similar story with his ill-fated inflation adjustment scheme for savings and for borrowings. This scheme that was run around the country by the Leader of the Opposition as part of the mock election campaign has vanished without trace. Quite correctly it has vanished without trace because it is a dishonest proposition that clearly has not been thoroughly thought through by the Opposition. On the question of taxation, the Leader of the Opposition is trying to win with waffle. But the Australian public knows better than that and will demand better than that.

The third problem faced by the Opposition is a problem of timing, because not only do we not know what the Opposition stands for; we do not even know when it will know what it stands for. We do not know when its policies will be released. Let me read briefly from the transcript of AM on 1 August to give an idea of the confusion that the Opposition is suffering on the question of timing. This is an interview by Peter Thompson with the shadow Treasurer. Peter Thompson asked:
When will you be ready to announce this one way or the other, whether this is going to be policy?
They are talking about inflation adjustment. The shadow Treasurer said:

Peter Thompson asked:
But how soon is that?
The shadow Treasurer replied:
Well, I can't put a date on it, I'm sorry.
Peter Thompson asked:
Why not?
The shadow Treasurer replied:
It depends when the costing process is complete. We are not far away, and it is in that context that it's been raised.
Peter Thompson said, `All right'. He was obviously not going to get anything out of him on the question of timing, so he moved on. He said:
I want to raise again the issue of fairness. It seems to be central to the Liberal Party campaign for this next election.

It certainly is. The Liberals are campaigning on the slogan of `A Fair Go'. It is an interesting concept of a fair go that this Party of incentive believes that you give rich people incentive by giving them more and poor people incentive by giving them less. The slogan of `Fair go' is supposed to tap an important vein in the Australian consciousness. I hope also that it taps a vein within the Liberal Party. Certainly those groups of people who went to the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) and the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair) on the evening of 8 May believed in the concept of fair go. They said to the honourable member for Bennelong and the right honourable member for New England, `We will be fair and you can go', and certainly they went. There is an equally important Australian value that I think ought to be tapped as well, and that is the concept not of fair go but fair dinkum. The Australian people have shown over many elections that they will not vote for a party that is not fair dinkum. It is clear to me-it is clear to anybody who has observed politics for any length of time in this country-that the Liberal Party under the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock) since 9 May and the National Party under the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt) since 9 May, are simply not fair dinkum with the Australian public; they are not fair dinkum even with themselves.

Mr Deputy Speaker, it has been a great pleasure to take part in the debate on this the seventh of Labor's Budgets. I look forward at about the same time next year to participating in the debate on Labor's eighth consecutive Budget.

Instead of trying to torpedo Moody's Investors Service, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) would better serve the nation by taking action in concert with his colleagues to resolve the problems confronting the nation. Moody's said that `the persistence of structural weaknesses embedded in Australia's domestic and international position, such as intransigent rigidities in the local labour and transport market' were constraining international competition. They are right. We all know they are right. Whilst there has been a revolution in industrial relations in the rest of the world, we in Australia are stuck with a nineteenth century system. Our economy is being strangled by this Government's inability to initiate the changes necessary for the nation to shake off the shackles of our antiquated industrial relations system. Unless we immediately step up the rate of change and internationalise our economy we will confirm our position as a stagnant backwater in world trade.

The Government claims it has the runs on the board because it says, `Well, we deregulated the exchange rate and the banks'. But that is only one side of the coin. The Government has refused to go on with the job and allow our industries to internationalise through industrial relations reform. Moody's correctly pointed out that it is the continued slow pace of structural adjustment which makes Australia ill-positioned to weather the next downturn in the global business cycle without further large increases in the foreign currency debt. Further, it said there was insufficient progress in generating additional export earning capacity and in restructuring industry to achieve productivity gains. Moody's is right. Everyone but the Government admits it is right.

The Government's industrial relations record is a disaster. It started out with a policy of consensus which ensured the existing rigidities and inefficient work practices were maintained. Secret backroom deals between the Government and the unions were made with a premium on peace and little or no regard for our competitiveness. The result is that we have the worst balance of payments ever, the highest foreign debt ever, and our credit rating is on the slide. The real advances made in the industrial relations field have been made not with the Government's assistance but despite the Government. Where the Government has intervened it has been a disaster. This Labor Government's record has been to avoid significant changes and to maintain the status quo because its union mates have become comfortable and the last thing they want is change.

Nearly everyone in Australia now agrees that reform is necessary and nowhere is it more urgent than on the waterfront. Substantial featherbedding developed on the waterfront in a period when our great rural and resource exports were at their premium. The rorts are now so bad they are actually undermining our ability to compete. Urgent action is required. Instead of immediate remedial action the Government, unwilling to upset its union mates, has gone for a gradualist approach-the gradualist negotiated change approach. It is expensive and provides no guarantee that the much needed fundamental reform will be achieved.

A key issue to fundamental reform of the waterfront is that employers and employees must be free to negotiate their own pay and conditions. Until that is the case, pay and conditions will continue to be uniform among companies and competition will be restricted. Without real competition in all aspects of the operation of the waterfront there is no guarantee that improved cost effectiveness will be passed on to the users of waterfront services in the form of lower prices. An environment must be created wherein different companies are able to hire and fire employees, operate different work practices and rostering arrangements and eliminate artificial labour demarcation. This will require changes to industrial legislation. Those changes must allow for voluntary agreements, changes to union coverage arrangements, voluntary unionism, improved dispute resolution mechanisms, effective compliance provisions, essential services legislation, and secret ballots before strikes.

There should be greater competition between ports. Potential competitors are often run by the same port authority. For example, the Port of Melbourne Authority runs both Westernport and Melbourne. Port authorities should be operated under specifically commercial charters, run mainly by the users-the importers and exporters-who have vested interests in a cost effective, reliable operation. Within ports, there should be greater competition between companies providing the services, such as the stevedores and those who provide the towing services. That competition may have to be achieved by a tendering process, those tenders being for relatively short periods

The area with the greatest potential for improvement through competition is in the area of employment, and the role of the Waterside Workers Federation monopoly in this area is all important. Employers should be free to determine how many employees, including casuals, they require. They should not be required to recruit new employees from the Waterside Workers Federation registry. The Inter-State Commission and the Government's reform package anticipate a significant role for the Federal Government. A reform program that has to rely on government intervention to tackle directly such fundamental reform issues as the high level of disputation, restrictive work practices, manning levels, training arrangements or the level of redundancy payouts, is fundamentally flawed.

The most telling indication that the Government's reform program does not go to the root issues is its promise that, if the reform program does not result in lower costs to the users of the system, the Government will use its pricing authority to achieve that end. The waterfront does not need another set of regulations, even if those regulations are intended to produce cost reductions. The role of the Federal Government should be to provide an effective legal framework preventing an abuse of power and allowing forces of the marketplace and competition to prevail. The federal and port coordinating committees should be dismantled and the special jurisdiction of the Industrial Relations Commission in waterfront matters should be abolished. Cross-subsidisation between ports should be abolished by the elimination of the levy arrangements. Individual employers would then be directly responsible for the employment conditions to which they agreed in respect of their operations.

Because of the country's need to improve its trade situation there is a desperate demand for fundamental reform on the waterfront. The urgency is there. The Inter-State Commission has focused public attention on the abuses of the waterfront. The time and climate for fundamental reform are ideal. The various reports of the Inter-State Commission which analyse past attempts at reform on the waterfront show that negotiated changes and externally imposed programs may work for a little while, but the waterfront gradually reverts to the situation that we face today. In other words, once the heat and glare of the national spotlight are off, then overmanning and restrictive work practices are likely to re-emerge. Therefore, we should be funding a program of fundamental reform which does not rely on externally imposed measures and does not maintain the same structures which gave rise to the current problems. I fear that the $190m we are about to commit to waterfront reform will eventually be wasted and, what is worse, we will lose this opportunity for the reforms we so desperately need.

It is clear that the Hawke-Keating Government is backing away from meaningful reform on the waterfront. It opposes meaningful restructuring of our abattoirs and now it has inflamed and exacerbated the pilots dispute. Where is the great negotiator? Instead of consensus in bringing the pilots and airlines together, the Prime Minister has gone out of his way to set them apart-resulting in one of the most expensive industrial relations stand-offs this country has known. But then again, consistency in industrial relations is not the strong suit of this Government.

National interest and our international competitiveness play little part in the secret deals done by this Government with its union mates and, in some cases, its employer mates. They perpetuate a centralised wage fixing system which encourages flow-ons and secret deals, which are at the heart of our industrial chaos. The community is fed up with this outdated system where we seem to be on strike more often than not and where our standard of living suffers as a result. The old industrial relations system must go. The Sydney Morning Herald and the Age today both report on the loss of support for the existing industrial relations system. Let me quote from the Sydney Morning Herald. The headline reads `Support Falls for Industrial Commission'. It goes on:

There has been a significant decline in public support for the Arbitration Commission in the past eight years, the latest Saulwick Herald poll has found. Only half the voters believe the Commission, now called the Industrial Relations Commission, should continue to have a central role in fixing wages compared with 69 per cent of voters in a Herald poll conducted in 1981.
Further proof of the unravelling of the current system is evidenced in the Australian Financial Review report today which states:

The vulnerability of the wage fixing system has been exposed in the ACTU's postponement of a special unions conference for a week after failing to make sufficient headway with agreements in five key industrial awards.

We cannot go on trying to bandaid together this hopelessly irrelevant industrial relations system. Only when the existing system is replaced by meaningful employer-employee enterprise-based negotiations, with pay increases related to productivity, will we as a nation get back on our feet. Under Labor our industrial relations system has effectively conferred on the unions monopoly or near-monopoly power. These monopolies have sapped business of the much-needed will to innovate. They have made us internationally uncompetitive and they have institutionalised outrageous rorts, especially on the waterfront.

What is needed to lead the nation out of this morass is a program of reform which is radical and forward thinking enough to break down the barriers to competition and thrust us into the twenty-first century of world competition. This Government will never be capable of conceiving or implementing such a plan because it is tied to its union masters. The coalition has the policies, and after the next election it will implement those policies to achieve those goals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Howard The Hon J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The major flaw in this year's Budget was its failure to effectively address the long term need for restructuring and micro-economic reform of the Australian economy. Not surprisingly, I want to address my remarks on the Budget tonight to the searing effects on the Australian economy and on the livelihoods of many hundreds of thousands of Australians and their families of the crippling air pilots strike which has now been going on for almost three weeks. I have said on other occasions that the highest unclimbed peak of economic reform in Australia is the deregulation of our rigid centralised industrial relations system. I commend the remarks of the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter), not only in relation to the strangulation of our waterfront but also on the need to bring about industrial relations reform.

SPEECH.PARA: What is now happening with the pilots dispute is absolutely seminal to the future of industrial relations in this country. It is a watershed in the industrial relations experience of Australia, and the shriller the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) becomes, the more he shouts-and I am reminded of that beautiful comment of Patrick White of somebody screeching like a galah or a cocky when I hear the Prime Minister at Question Time-the more hectoring he becomes, the more convinced I am that he is in bother. There are many ironies about the pilots dispute, and the greatest irony of all, of course, is that the Prime Minister is now on a course of action that has as its almost inevitable consequence a fundamental weakening of an industrial relations system that he has spent all of his adult life championing, because bit by bit, day by day, abuse by abuse, he is driving the parties to a situation where this dispute can only be settled by voluntary agreements outside his beloved centralised wage fixation system.

There is no argument that the Prime Minister has deepened this dispute by his unreasoned and intemperate language. Not only was he needlessly abusive to airline pilots, but he was positively patronising to bus drivers. What earthly right has this man, who once led the trade union movement of Australia, to talk as though some occupation in life was so low that you could compare people that you were abusing with that occupation? But that is what he did.

But more seriously than that, the fatal flaw of the Prime Minister in this dispute has been to equate the national economic interest with preservation of the centralised wage fixation system. At every stage of the dispute the Prime Minister has put preserving the system above anything else. No system known to man is so perfect that it becomes an end in itself. An industrial relations system is not an end in itself; an industrial relations system is a means to procuring a more productive and a more competitive economy. When it cannot deliver the goods, one changes the system. One does not impose the system in a rigid fashion upon our economy.

I want to talk for a moment about the industrial relations policy of the Liberal and National parties. I have a copy of it in front of me. It is pretty relevant to this debate because it addresses this problem. Under the paragraph headed `Voluntary Agreements', the policy says:

A principal objective of this policy is to return the primary responsibility for industrial relations, including the determination of wages and conditions, to employers and employees at the workplace.

The Prime Minister ought to read that over and over again. When he does so, he might have some of the elements for understanding what is involved in this particular dispute. Our policy does not say that the system is more important than the economy. We do not say that we want to preserve a system irrespective of its consequences. We believe in allowing employers and employees to bargain at an enterprise level, because we believe that those bargains are more likely to produce productive outcomes.

It is a fallacy in modern industrial relations to believe that any given level of wage increase is unsustainable. It is only unsustainable if it cannot be afforded, if it is not matched by productivity gains. At the end of the day, I believe that this dispute will be settled on the basis of an increase for pilots in return for an increase in productivity. That, of course, is the industrial relations policy, not of R. J. L. Hawke or of Bill Kelty, or of the Australian Labor Party or of the Government of this country; that is the industrial relations policy of the Liberal and National parties. That is why this dispute is so supremely ironic. We have heard the Prime Minister shouting at the pilots. When one is a national leader and one has nothing left to do except shout, one has a real problem. That, of course, is the dilemma of the Prime Minister in this particular dispute.

That infamous German propaganda Minister, if he were around today would be proud of this infamous attempt by the Government to say that the dispute, the strike, is in some way the fault of the Opposition. No doubt the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous) will talk parrot-like about that. At every Question Time the Prime Minister says, `Oh, it's the Opposition that has caused this strike'. What an incredible proposition! This dispute, which is driving thousands of small businessmen bankrupt as I speak, is occurring because the Government's system has failed, and because the Prime Minister has failed in his responsibility of national leadership. We do not have it because of the policy of the Opposition. If the policy of the Opposition were listened to by the Government it might have created a better climate for solving the dispute than it has to date.

What is wrong with the pilots and the airlines talking directly? What is wrong, as suggested by Dr Henderson of the Sydney Institute, with the parties using a private negotiator or arbitrator? He suggested somebody of the standing of Sir Laurence Street, the former Chief Justice of New South Wales. Plenty of private arbitration and negotiating is done in the United States and in other parts of the world. Why can we not be imaginative enough and radical enough to embrace that as a solution? Why are we so hidebound and, on this issue, so conservative? I am a great conservative on certain things, but when it comes to cleaning up a rotten, crumbling industrial relations system, I am a radical, because I think we need changes to our system.

If we are to be part of the new Pacific rim, if we are to have a truly productive and competitive economy, we have to get a better industrial relations system that rewards people when they work harder and is based upon the principle that there is nothing wrong with a wage increase provided it is based on productivity. That is the fatal weakness of this Government. It cannot see that, and it is clinging to a demented legalism. For a non-lawyer, the Prime Minister has a manic preoccupation with form over substance. He has a total preoccupation with the form of the industrial relations system, to the detriment of the substance. That is why he has bungled this dispute from start to finish. That is why he has attempted, as a palliative, to misrepresent the policy of the Opposition.

The policy of the Opposition is built on two principles. It is built, first and foremost, on the practical recognition that we will never permanently and enduringly free the labour markets of this country until we permanently and enduringly reduce the unfair share of power held by the trade union movement. Any people who believe that we can have a decentralised industrial relations system without, at the same time, reducing the legal privileges of the trade union movement are kidding themselves; they are trying to have their cake and eat it, too. We have to take away the legal privileges of the trade union movement. We have to break the mentality of the report of the Hancock Committee of Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems that said that we cannot treat the trade unions like everybody else because they are too strong. What an incredible proposition! That, of course, is what the industrial relations system of the present Government is built on. The Prime Minister is not doing the bidding of the average Australian family in this dispute. He is not doing the bidding of the tourist industry. He is not doing the bidding of the airlines. He is doing the bidding of the mandarins of the industrial relations club. That is why he is taking the attitude that he is taking.

Our policy is built on two principles. It is built, firstly, on a recognition that to permanently and effectively free the labour markets of this country we will need to reduce the legal privileges enjoyed by the trade union movement. I am not wanting to exterminate the trade unions. The union movement has a legitimate role in the fabric of national life in Australia. But I will never accept the proposition that it is entitled to legal privileges that nobody else has. That is the situation we have at present. That is the first principle on which our policy is based.

The second principle on which we base our policy is that very simple and important Liberal notion of freedom; that is, that individuals should have the right to bargain in terms of how they make their arrangements. The only way we will have a more productive Australian nation is by allowing free men and women to work together and to have an industrial relations and wage fixation system that says that a wage increase that is earned is a wage increase justified and a wage increase that is not earned is not a justified wage increase. That should be the simple proposition of our industrial relations system. It ought not to be complicated. It ought not to be beyond the wit of men and women to ensure that over time a system like that can be worked towards.

That is why I regard this pilots dispute as being so important to the industrial relations future of this country. I do not think industrial relations in Australia will ever be the same again, as a result of this dispute. It will go down with the gaoling of Clarrie O'Shea and some other events as being one of the truly seminal occurrences in our industrial relations system, because what it has done is that it has exposed a fatal weakness in the system that has been the Holy Grail of this Government for 6 1/2 years.

What it has done also is propel the Prime Minister of this country on a course of action which is leading inexorably to the adoption of the very policy of the Opposition that he day by day despises. It is not the Opposition that is in the dock. It is not the Opposition that ought to be cross-examined and pilloried by the media on this matter. It is the Government. It is its system that spawned this strike. It is its system which has led to a state of affairs where people are going out of business. It is its Prime Minister who, by his intemperate and abusive language, has exacerbated an otherwise, in any event, very difficult and tragic dispute.

I say to the House that it is time, remembering a very important document in the political history of Australia, for plain thinking. The plain thinking that is needed in this dispute is to understand first of all that it is a product of the Hawke-Kelty-Keating centralised industrial relations system. It is not a product of the industrial relations policy of the Liberal and National parties. That is bit of plain thinking No. 1, The No. 2 bit of plain thinking is that the Prime Minister of this country, who won his spurs as the great conciliator and negotiator, bringing together bruised spirits and egos, has performed abysmally. He has forfeited the most precious gift of a national leader, and that is that capacity to retain an aloof detachment. He has forfeited the authority of his office by becoming so partisan and so hectoring and so involved that he is no longer trusted or believed by a large number of people who are involved in this dispute. The essential prerequisite, even if one does not like a Prime Minister because of his politics, is to believe that at the end of the day he will be an honest broker in the national interest. This man does not sound like nor does he act like an honest broker in the national interest in this dispute. He sounds like a screaming trade union official on the back of a truck, and that is a manifestly inadequate contribution to this dispute.

I conclude my remarks by saying that I regard this strike, this dispute, painful though it is for many tens of thousands of people, as a dispute that at the end of the day may provide a way out of a crumbling and increasingly flawed industrial relations system. I predict now that this dispute will end up as having been a landmark in the hard march towards a freer, more flexible industrial relations system. The supreme irony is that one of the great facilitators of that will have been the Prime Minister of Australia, who spent all of his adult life defending and preserving and championing an industrial relations system that is now crumbling in front of his eyes. Of course, the greatest irony of all is that I do not think he quite understands that that is what he is doing.
