TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, I came into the House hoping to hear the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) speak on the Budget. Instead I heard a raving speech about the pilots dispute and the industrial relations system. Therefore I am obliged on behalf of this side of the House to answer the various claims that were made by the honourable member for Bennelong. On every point the honourable member obviously has no historical memory. The industrial relations system which he wants to bring back is the one which destroyed this country in 1981-82 and led to half a million people being unemployed. The honourable member has forgotten about that. He has forgotten that it was the laissez-faire system that the Opposition is proposing now, getting rid of the Industrial Relations Commission, reducing the power of the Industrial Relations Commission--(Quorum formed). I was replying to the comments of the honourable member for Bennelong, who tried to lecture us on industrial relations in talking on the Budget and tried to tell us that we ought to adopt the Liberal-National Party policy, which is the very same policy that destroyed this country in 1981-82 and created half a million unemployed people. He said that the pilots should be allowed to go outside the system and to negotiate directly with the employers even if it means 30 per cent, 40 per cent, 50 per cent, whatever rise they might want. He said that it does not matter what the wage rise is; whatever rise people can gain from their employer. That is exactly what happened in 1981-82 when the then Government got rid of the centralised system and there were very big wage rises across the board, throughout the nation. Inflation went through the roof and unemployment rose, and it rose and it rose, and in one year half a million people were out of work. Unfortunately, Malcolm Fraser listened to the honourable member for Bennelong, John Howard, in those times. As a result, all those people suffered poverty and unemployment. The honourable member ought to be ashamed of himself for giving people lectures about economics after what happened in that period of his government.

SPEECH.PARA: I remember very clearly what was happening in our electorates at that time with all that unemployment and poverty. The honourable member comes into this House and says, `Let's do the same thing again. Let's bring in this industrial relations system. Let's destroy the nation'. That is not to mention the huge industrial disputation that occurred and all the lost time in productivity. The honourable member talked about productivity. Does he really think that if the unions are left in this situation of total across-the-board laissez faire, being able to argue with every employer, that will create some kind of industrial relations stability? It would create chaos in this country. The Opposition has only one recipe for the current economic situation, and that is a recession and a depression, with more and more unemployed people. That is what the honourable member for Bennelong is arguing for in putting forward this formula.

The honourable member talks about the pilots as if the situation they have brought about is totally justified. He did not say a single critical thing about the pilots. He did not say a single thing about the fact that what they are claiming, an increase of $30,000 a year, is equivalent to the average wage of the average Australian. The honourable member suggests that the pilots were entitled to argue with their employers. Of course, the employers in that circumstance, not having the protection of rules or of the Arbitration Commission, would probably have been forced to give in to them. Who would have suffered? The whole of the Australian community would have suffered, because the consumers of the airlines, the travelling public, the tourism industry and, of course, the ordinary consumer whose products have to be transported by air-everyone would have suffered because the cost of all these things would have increased. The honourable member for Bennelong dares to come in here and try to lecture the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and everyone else in this House about how to handle the pilots dispute, by referring to the Opposition's nonsensical industrial relations policy which has proved to be a disaster, as I mentioned, not only in Australia but overseas. The same policy was attempted by Margaret Thatcher in England and led to a situation where unemployment jumped from fewer than one million people to more than three million people. There are more than three million unemployed under that industrial relations policy in Britain, not to mention the huge level of industrial disputation that occurred in those early days when Margaret Thatcher was attempting to implement the policy. Of course, she finally gave it away as a bad joke. She has a different policy now.

What do we get from the Opposition? Ideas which are 10 to 15 years old, which have been abandoned in most countries of the world. They are put forward here by the honourable member for Bennelong and others as if they are original. If the honourable member for Bennelong thinks he is going to get back on the front bench by putting forward proposals like this, I say to the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) that it is time he rejected not only the honourable member for Bennelong, but also a lot of the policies which were drafted during the period when the honourable member for Bennelong was leader. The reason why the Opposition is down to a popularity rate of less than 20 per cent in the polls is that the Australian people do not want any of its policies. The Australian people understand what it stands for. It is not enough to change the face, to put in Andrew Peacock instead of John Howard. It is necessary also to change policies and to get some constructive alternatives. We are certainly not getting that from the Opposition at the moment.

The Prime Minister is absolutely correct on the pilots dispute. The Opposition is all over the place. The Leader of the Opposition says he does not support the pay claim. The honourable member for Bennelong says he does. Half of the front bench say they do; the other half say they do not. What is going on here? Is this a group that wants to govern Australia? What nonsense! The honourable member for Bennelong said, `Of course, we have to match pay rises with productivity gains'. Let me point out a couple of things. The policy of the Government and the Australian Council of Trade Unions-the accord-has provisions within it which allow for increases based on productivity. But the point is that one must show those to an independent commission. One must go to a commission and argue for a productivity increase. Under the proposals of the honourable member for Bennelong, all one would have to do is go to one's employer and say, `Look, we believe we have a productivity increase; give us the money or else'. That is what would happen in terms of industrial relations. One would not have to prove to anyone that one has any productivity increase.

If the airline pilots believe that they are capable of productivity increases, let them go before the Industrial Relations Commission or let them work out some way of going before the Commission. Even if we have to work out an intermediate process, the Government is willing to listen to proposals that are sensible in terms of the guidelines. If the pilots had, from the beginning, gone before the Commission and argued on the basis of productivity increases and on work value, they would have got some increase. There is no doubt about it. Instead, they chose a course which was intended to challenge the whole system of industrial relations.

We cannot afford to allow that system to break down, for the very important reason that it is the basis of the accord between the union movement, the Government and the employers which has allowed this country and this economy to be guided through some of the most difficult periods in its history. If it were not for that accord there would have been a recession as a result of the loss in consumer prices in 1986. We would definitely have fallen into a recession if it had not been for the cooperation of the trade union movement and the accord. If it had not been for the wage-tax trade-off for this year we would not have been in a position to achieve the kinds of gains which we will achieve as a result of this Budget. That is the point I wanted to talk about at the beginning of my remarks, before I referred to industrial relations issues.

In relation to what the honourable member for Bennelong said, let me say that the Government is not on a course of trying to break the pilots, bring them down or anything of that kind. It was the pilots who decided to go outside the system. It was the pilots who decided to resign en masse. They were not sacked; they resigned en masse. It was the pilots who decided to adopt a confrontationist tactic. That does not mean that we are totally inflexible and are not willing to discuss ways of resolving this situation. Of course we are. The Prime Minister indicated so yesterday and today. Let the pilots, through any medium they choose, indicate that they are prepared to go before the Commission and argue their case on the basis of productivity, as every other worker in this country has to do. They will be considered, and they may be able to achieve a wage increase-perhaps not 30 per cent, perhaps something less, but nevertheless something which is reasonable and which will allow for an increase in productivity.

Unless the pilots recognise this fact there can be no solution. The Government cannot allow a group to go totally outside the guidelines and demand a pay rise of 30 per cent, irrespective of productivity. To do that would be to undermine the very basis on which we have guided the economy in the last few years. That is not to say that workers will not get wage increases. Of course they will. We have in place the most revolutionary award restructuring process in the history of this country. This process not only will allow workers to enter higher categories of work; it will provide for more broadly based and more fulfilling work, and it will allow them a wage increase. That is what we have put in place. The award restructuring process is going on right now. So we are not opposed to wage increases.

Similarly, workers can go to the Commission and, if they can demonstrate productivity, get additional increases. All these things are possible within the system. As one nation we must be capable of working within the one system if we are going to be capable of guiding this economy through the present difficulties. And we are going to guide this economy through the present difficulties.

The Budget contains positive elements which will guide the economy through its recent difficulties. The economy will be slowed but, as most of the commentators are saying, the Treasurer will achieve a soft landing, something which the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard) could not do when he was Treasurer. Instead, every time he tried to slow down the economy, what happened? There was a recession. There was unemployment. There was not a slowing down process at all. We almost had a depression in 1981-82. We are going to achieve this soft landing without the creation of unemployment, without severe difficulties. When we do so we will be better able to deal with our present current account problems.

The most revolutionary changes that are taking place besides the award restructuring changes are the superannuation changes announced by the Treasurer. The honourable member for Bennelong did not even mention those changes. In fact, most of the speakers on the other side, commenting on the Budget, did not even mention the superannuation changes. What will those changes mean? In addition, as I said, to workers improving their position by getting wage increases, they will also receive additional superannuation payments. This Government is the first government in the history of Australia that has enabled every worker to go into a superannuation scheme. That is what we have done, through the agreement with the trade union movement.

What are we doing with this Budget? We are making major concessions to the superannuation funds to enable them to expand their schemes. The superannuation funds will increase in size and their role in the economy will become more important. Their capacity to deal with the savings problem will increase-a problem that was referred to by some members of the Opposition. But Opposition members had no suggestions. They had no ideas about how to deal with the problem of savings. We had a nonsensical idea from the Leader of the Opposition. He suggested that we might not tax part of the interest on savings. But when he was asked to give specifics on that matter, he ran away. He could not give specifics. Every specific he could come up with would have been disastrous. The scheme was not fundable, and the Leader of the Opposition was made to look a fool in the media because he could not come up with a scheme that was any good.

What have we done? With this Budget we have put into place revolutionary changes on superannuation which are going to increase the total net savings of the nation by a dramatic amount. That will be a very significant change for this country. What are we going to do as time goes on and we approach the next election? The changes announced in the Budget will bite and they will have a significant impact on the economy. The Australian people will be able to see a gradual reduction in interest rates, not as a result of some ad hoc policy but as a result of the macro-economic strategy that has been adopted by the Government, including the changes on superannuation. The people of this country will be able to see that they have in the medium and long term a very secure future in terms of the economy.

One of the things about the superannuation changes is that they are going to encourage superannuation companies to invest in Australian corporations and in Australian productive enterprises. That is one of the things which for many many years we have been saying need to be done, but nobody on the other side has done anything about it. During the period in office of those opposite half of Australia's manufacturing collapsed. We have been picking up Australian manufacturing in every part of Australia, and now with these changes there will be an even bigger boost in investment for manufacturing.

We totally reject the arguments of the honourable member for Bennelong. He should be ashamed to put forward those arguments in support of what the pilots have done in going outside the system. We call on the pilots to get back into the system and we will be ready to help them and to negotiate a solution as soon as possible. We certainly reject the outrageous claims being made about the Prime Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —The sterility and rigidity of the prejudices of the Labor Party have never been better demonstrated than in that sad speech by the honourable member for Calwell (Dr Theophanous). If he were of some consequence I would respond, but the point of it all is that unfortunately he echoes so much of the sentiments of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). Rather incredibly, without consultation, the honourable member for Barker (Mr Porter) and the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), who preceded me on our side of the House in this debate, have, as I see it, perceived what is the core of the absolute failure of the Budget on this Tuesday only three weeks after it was first presented. It is incredible that we have a strike, if one wishes to call it that, such as this. As I see it, we have a dispute that is now drawing its ever tightening reins around the whole economy and the Government is walking away from doing anything about it.

SPEECH.PARA: At Question Time today we heard the Prime Minister say they were prepared to do something within the system. They are not prepared to do anything outside the system. We have seen a climate where not only in the airlines but in the tourist industry and in all those who service the tourist industry unemployment is growing, casuals have already been stood down, and occupancy rates in hotels and motels are minimal. The whole of the system about which there were proud boasts by Government Ministers only a few weeks ago is now grinding to a halt. We have heard from successive members about the number of overseas tourist operators who cancelled their journeys to Australia. It is all happening while the Prime Minister sits back and says, `It's all too hard; it's all got to be dealt with within the system'.

In a few words on the Budget tonight I want to look at how I believe that dispute can be resolved. I also want to say that as far as I am concerned a significant part of the blame for the dispute and the deterioration of employment and the prejudice to Australia's present tourist income and its potential tourism in the future lies with the Prime Minister himself. There are three things the Prime Minister has done. First, he made that incredible statement about bus drivers, and we heard about that tonight from the honourable member for Bennelong. Not only was it belittling the bus drivers but also it was totally prejudicial to the highly sophisticated skills that airline pilots must have to pursue that very excellent safety record that is really something that we on this side of the House wish to maintain.

Secondly, he carried on about learning to fly in seven hours when he was at Oxford. The reality is that, whatever the Prime Minister did at Oxford, the difference between his level of flying skill and that of airline pilots is really as great as the demonstrable difference in skill that I can see between preceding Liberal-National Party Prime Ministers and the present Prime Minister. Unfortunately he was a high flier then and he has been pretty low flying ever since. The third thing he did was to exacerbate the whole of the dispute. In my view offering the carrot of compensation to the domestic airline operators was as catastrophic as the things he said about the airline pilots themselves.

The airline operators, if they believe that the Government-rightly or wrongly-is going to provide compensation, of course are going to feel that they can accept the dictates of the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and Bill Kelty. How incredible in this dispute to have the leader of the ACTU saying, `You cannot stand down any of those people who are affected by this airline dispute'. And why not? The only reason is that a carrot of compensation has been offered. Of course the Prime Minister has come in here and said, `No, we have not yet provided any compensation. We have not taken any decision'. There has been far more than a nod and a wink, and the media of Australia have trumpeted forth. What we have got to do in order to resolve the dispute is have a look at how we can overcome that situation which is specifically the responsibility of the Prime Minister, that is, his comments about the bus drivers, the Oxford comment, and the carrot of compensation.

What has he done? What he has done is just as bad as those stimuli to going out. The first thing was that he said, `We are going to have service pilots flying commercial aircraft'. That was stillborn. Even if the Prime Minister did not realise it, those who can fly one type of aircraft need to be accredited to another type of aircraft. Service pilots might have thousands of hours in other types of aircraft but they cannot automatically walk in and take over the controls of a modern commercial airliner.

But not only that, having offered Royal Australian Air Force (RAAF) planes he then found that there were problems about compensation. Unfortunately, as far as domestic airline operators are concerned, they cannot just put passengers on board and accept the disciplines that apply to the service aircraft. They had to introduce properly signed and agreed legislative offsets against the compensation that would be payable in the event of any sort of an accident happening. So 24 hours after he offered the RAAF aircraft, they were finally available. Then what happened? The RAAF is now carrying about 2 per cent of passengers.

What we have got to understand is that the offer of the Prime Minister with respect to the Australian Services did not pick up the equivalent of the ordinary commercial intermain trunk route services around Australia. All it did was provide some slight amelioration to a quite critical problem, and nobody travelling around Australia can rely on there being an aircraft to bring him back if he gets to that destination. So that was the second thing. Service pilots have failed, the RAAF was 24 hours late and it is carrying only 2 per cent of passengers. The Air Force does not pretend to be taking over the full passenger carrying capability of the commercial airlines. Thirdly, of course, he said that there would be interlining. Of course there has to be interlining. On this side of the House we welcome it. I understand it is carrying about 8 per cent of the passengers and beyond that it is something I am delighted to see that the pilots at last have also accepted.

Fourthly, he said he was going to advertise overseas for pilots. We heard today a little bit about it in Question Time, but the point is: how many pilots have accepted the offer? Are there any pilots now flying? Of course at this stage there are not any. So the advertisement really has not generated any resolution of the problem. The fifth thing is, of course, that he said there would be overseas charters. Apart from an airline operator that is carrying some freight-questions were asked here the other day and quite properly worries were expressed about the safety record of that airline company-there is in fact at the moment no overseas charter operator carrying passengers. We were told a Polish aircraft might come in, perhaps a Russian aircraft, but at the moment there is no overseas charter operator.

I wanted to say two things in talking about the airline dispute. The first is that people in this place need to understand that there is such a thing as an industrial reality. We hear a lot of this from the Prime Minister. He talks about ambit claims and things being on the table and all the rest of it. He grew up in the field of industrial relations but one would not know it from his mishandling of this dispute. In my mind there has never been a worse example of an intervention by a political leader of this country in an industrial dispute than that by Prime Minister Hawke in the airlines dispute. As far as I am concerned it is he and he alone who is now preventing any negotiations to try to resolve this dispute.

It is not just a matter of pilots having resigned, it is not just a matter of possible compensation for the airline companies, as one of my colleagues, the honourable member for Fadden (Mr Jull), said yesterday; it involves also the tourist operators, and all those who are involved in other sectors of the tourist industry. If we are going to give compensation, we have to give compensation to them. But the reality is none of that is on, and I put it to this place that if we were in government we would approach this entirely differently. I totally endorse the analysis of our industrial relations policy given by the honourable member for Bennelong a moment ago. The reality is there are things that could be done now, that should be done now, and if they were done we would get those trunk routes operating again.

There are three things I would like to put to you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The first is that the pilots should be told to resume flying-and they should resume their flying on exactly the same basis as applied when they went out and resigned-and they ought to be told that within one month a resolution will be found to their industrial claim. So we would then get the business of flying, the business of transport, going again. Ask those small businessmen who are the tourist operators. They do not give two hoots about the system-they care about going bankrupt, they care about unemployment, they care about going backwards, they care about trying to work for the tourist industry which over the last few years has augmented our gross export earnings so significantly. They care about trying to keep that tourist industry alive.

So what do we do? The first thing is we get the planes flying and we do that by telling the pilots that we are going to reinstate them on their old contracts at their present rates of pay and on present conditions of employment while we attempt to get a resolution, and we guarantee that we will get that resolution within one month. The second thing is we tell the airline operators and all those who are involved, whether they are tourist operators or anybody else, that there will be no taxpayer compensation available for them. It does not matter what sort of a nod and a wink has been given, that has to be put to one side. So the two parties are forced to negotiate and even if it is within the system at least they are not in a position where they feel themselves in some way insulated against the commercial pressures that should apply in the marketplace. The third thing we have to do is tell the employers-even if it is Australian Airlines, government owned as it is-to negotiate with the pilots. We have to get the airline operators and the pilots talking together on the basis of a pay claim based on a productivity gain.

We all accept that the pilots can apparently fly more hours. We all accept that seniority in rosters is prejudicial to the efficient operation of airline operations. But if we were to follow those three points and a productivity gain were offered in return for some increment in pilots' pay, in my view we would be in a position where the Government could say, `Look, we are doing what we can to restore profitability in our tourist industry; we are getting the Australian aircraft industry back where it should be'. Until those three things are done, we are not going to get anywhere.

I believe that if we were in government those things would have been done because our policy allows for that sort of negotiation. But we hear this nonsense from the Prime Minister, saying the system is more important. The point is that Australia is more important. The normal conduct of commercial operations in Australia is more important. The Prime Minister himself deserves to be condemned for not being prepared to understand that people get unemployed, people go broke, people lose their income, in circumstances where the Government through its prejudices is not prepared even to consider sympathetically a reasonable alternative. I put it to you, Mr Deputy Speaker, that that three-point plan, even within the system, would get Australia flying again.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner I was talking about matters pertaining to the Budget. Whether one is a rural Australian or a city Australian, the airlines strike is a mess. This morning, fifty years ago, Australia woke to the fact that it was at war. Today, we are still at war. This war is caused by the man who is sitting on the treasury benches next to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). He is to blame for the whole jolly thing. If he had the wit and wisdom, the comprehension and the understanding, there would have been a resolution of the problem. The front page of the Melbourne Herald says it all: `Solve it all now'.

Prior to the suspension of the sitting for dinner I told him how to resolve it. I put again to the House the three-point plan: Firstly, ask the pilots to resume work on their existing terms and conditions and assure them that there will be a resolution within a month. Secondly, tell the airline companies and the tourist industry that there will be no subsidies and any bets that were on as far as offering some sort of compensation are off. Thirdly, call in an independent arbitrator, as the honourable member for Bennelong said. Whether it is Mr Justice Street, the former Chief Justice of New South Wales, or whether it is the Chairman of the Industrial Relations Commission, Mr Justice Maddern, I do not mind.

The conciliation and arbitration commission system-the central wage fixation system-has failed. I believe that it would be better if it was scrapped, but I accept that the Government is committed to the `system' as the Prime Minister calls it and, in that climate, if he wishes he could get the Chairman of the Industrial Relations Commission, Mr Justice Maddern, to chair a meeting between airline operators and pilots and try to come to conditions of settlement which allow for productivity gains, disposal of the roster by seniority and a recognition that more hours at the stick could be achieved. That achievement could be matched with the productivity gains of the airline companies and some increment provided.

There are problems, however, that flow in other sectors. I am told that at the moment, for example, the commuter airlines that are providing an excellent service-many of them are still operating-have problems. I am told that the Civil Aviation Authority (CAA) has decided that it will try to police the regulations that exist in the civil aviation area to the last degree. Air Navigation Order 48 (1), for example, provides for the hours of duty of a pilot. I am told that it is being quite rigorous in refusing any normal dispensation that would be applied for as a matter of course. I suggest that the CAA is like the Tax Office: One cannot go beyond the limit of one's powers because one is trying to apply the rules, the letter, of the law, rather than the general concepts of the law. I think it is important that commuter airlines be given some additional flexibility to meet the needs of the public. The whole purpose of my proposition to the Parliament is that, unless one meets the needs of the public, the whole public suffers. The Prime Minister does not seem to be interested in people. He is more concerned with the system.

As far as the bush is concerned, micro-economic reform involves several areas. I have mentioned productivity and work gains. I totally endorse the idea of our freeing ourselves from the constraints of our centralised wage fixation process. But if the Prime Minister insists on living with the system, if we are to get the pilots and the aircraft flying and stop the unemployment and all the difficulties that will flow in the tourist industry, we have to follow the system. My three-point plan, I suggest, would meet that requirement.

In the bush we have a few other problems, such as wheat handling. I feel quite strongly that the Grains Council and the National Farmers Federation had the right message. I want to try to dispose of the unnecessarily restrictive work practices pursued by members of the Waterside Workers Federation in the Fishermans Island dispute in Brisbane the other week. I accept that the Australian Wheat Board has said that it is prepared to abide by these guaranteed modifications by 30 June 1990. They have to be achieved and unless they are achieved everybody in Australia will suffer. Not just the wheat growers but primary producers generally suffer, because of our goods handling procedures, which should be contrasted with goods handling procedures in every other competitive country. If we are going to try to achieve some sort of competitiveness, we must understand that until we do something in micro-economic reform, not just the agricultural sector, which at this time is providing our best cash flows in export earnings, will suffer; manufacturing and service industries will also suffer. We have been talking about the tourist industry, which also suffers.

There has to be a recognition that the accord has failed. This Budget has brought down record taxation revenue and a record level of overseas debt. It recognises that unemployment will increase and interest rates will continue to be the major arm of economic policy by this Government. We are not going to get anywhere until these problems are dealt with. What the Government must do is recognise that it must pursue micro-economic reform. It must get rid of restraints imposed by unduly excessive regulations in our community. I mentioned the difficulties in the commuter airline field. They apply equally in every field affecting the licensing and registration of small business. Unless we recognise the problems-whether it is in regard to wheat handling or the pilots dispute-as being a product of non-competitive practices, the chance of Australia again getting into the ball game of being internationally competitive and getting our economy in order is very slight indeed.

In rural Australia the Budget fails on a whole range of issues that I do not have time to address. Our roads are disastrous. I say to the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) that if he tries to drive around rural Australia at the moment he will not be able to get anywhere. Not enough Federal money is spent. State money is about to be spent to help improve roads in New South Wales, but they are disastrous.

The Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), who is at the table, is responsible for endorsing a decision by the tribunal determining entitlements to pharmacists. There is no doubt that, as far as the Pharmaceutical Benefits Remuneration Tribunal conclusions are concerned, in rural Australia many pharmacies will close. This will occur in the cities and suburbs. The Minister must accept responsibility for this. It is no use walking away from it. Pensioners, the aged and the infirm are the ones who will suffer. Pharmacists provide an alternative medical service. There are already 100,000 people on waiting lists for public hospitals. Public hospitals cannot provide the services. General practitioners are overworked; they cannot provide the service. Pharmacies are closing, and the Government has some concept that will provide some sort of supplementary aid for non-viable pharmacies. I tell the Minister that those pharmacies will close before they ever get any supplementary aid. Another fundamental problem that I would love to talk about is aggregation and what is happening in that regard. Channel 10 is a very good example of how this Government's broadcasting and television policy has gone mad. The Government has failed in every direction and so too has this Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: I was to have spoken on an earlier occasion in this debate on the 1989-90 Budget, but unfortunately, because of the tragic national airline strike that is on our hands, I was not able to do so. I would like to note the fact that 50 years ago last Sunday the Second World War commenced, and we have had a minute's silence in this House in remembrance. I did not have many family members who went to the war. I had an uncle, Mr Laurie Lahey, from Cadilla at Hannaford, where I was brought up, who was a Pathfinder and who spent a number of years in prison.

I remember as a small boy the troops returning from the war. I also remember the United States servicemen who helped us defend this country against the Japanese. At the property on which I lived at the time, west of Tara, we used to have the servicemen out for rest and recreation leave. Most of the products in Australia were rationed and we could not get sugar, but the servicemen used to bring us lumps of sugar which we would feed to our horses. They would do low level bombing runs over our property. We would go out and put a sheet on the front lawn and they would drop us chewing gum. I guess it was that sort of public relations goodwill that the Americans showed towards Australia at the time that allowed us to defeat the enemy. I think that is well worth mentioning at this time, remembering the many people in my electorate of Maranoa who paid the ultimate sacrifice. I have been very proud to represent members of the Returned Services League, and I attend many of their meetings.

Budgets come and go; unfortunately this is probably the last one I will speak on. The factions got at me in Queensland and I will not be continuing in the House. I think there will probably be a mini-Budget before the election, but this is probably the last annual Budget I will be speaking on. Unfortunately for us taxes continue to rise and we are now collecting $91.3 billion in this Budget. That is up 9.7 per cent, which is a real increase of about 2 1/2 per cent. For the Labor Party to tell us that taxes are not increasing is an absolute nonsense. It now has a record surplus. I have spent many years in local government and in the Federal Parliament, and I do not believe we ought to be running massive deficits or surpluses. Really, $9 billion is more than a 10 per cent surplus on the total figure of $91 billion. A $9 billion surplus is an enormous amount of money to drag out of the economy, and unnecessarily so.

However, I must congratulate the Government. Apparently it is its intention to pay back some of our debt, some of our borrowings, from past years. Most of the borrowings are the Government's, of course. When the Labor Party came into government it borrowed massive amounts. Gough Whitlam tried to do the same thing and he got turfed out of office. This Government learned a little from Whitlam's experience and it has done it through the back door and done it gradually and got away with it. It has borrowed huge amounts of money. The Government might argue that the Commonwealth itself has not done much of the borrowing, but what it has done is to force the States and the Commonwealth's statutory authorities as well as the States' statutory authorities, which have been starved of funds from the central government here in Canberra, to go out and borrow massive amounts of money.

This state of affairs continues because the States, local governments and statutory authorities, even the airlines, are desperate to raise capital to re-equip. The Government is saying that they cannot have any, so they have to borrow it.

The Government operates and owns Qantas Airways Ltd. Bob Hawke is the managing director and members of his Cabinet are directors. It is their responsibility at the end of the day to look after the interests of Australian Airlines and Qantas. They will not sell those companies off so that private enterprise and local people can put some revenue into the companies and they will not allow them to borrow the sorts of funds that are needed. So the companies are in a real quandary about what to do. Our policy on this side of the House is to involve employees and to sell off as much of the capital in those companies as possible so that they can get back on a decent footing and compete internationally as well as locally.

The total amount of personal tax is $51.3 billion, that is, up 8 per cent, which is a 0.5 per cent increase in real terms. On this side of the House the Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) put forward the suggestion that our savings should be indexed to inflation and that interest rates should also be indexed to inflation. But unfortunately the other equation he did not use and go on with was that personal tax should be indexed to inflation as well. I see the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), sitting there. It is a fact that the Department of the Treasury, the honourable member for Bennelong (Mr Howard), when he was Treasurer, and Malcolm Fraser in his day indexed personal tax to inflation but unfortunately for all Australians that lasted only about six months. There was an enormous loss of revenue at the time the Treasury hit the panic button and it did not continue.

All I would like to do is put forward to this House the facts. The indexation of interest payments perhaps should be carried into the company tax area, although I agree with some of the captains of industry who are now suggesting that company tax ought to be abolished. I support that concept. It does not pick up a lot of taxation in the overall sense. One might say that $11.3 billion is a lot of money, but the amount is up 10.7 per cent. In the overall equation I think that company tax could be abolished because so much tax is picked up from dividends and companies are desperate to get this nation up and running again. We are desperate for the exports that are needed to maintain, let alone increase, our standing of living.

The other thing that I said should happen is that we ought, if we are going to index savings and index interest, be indexing our taxation as well. It is amazing how governments are prepared to index all the expenditure. Every pension and every handout we like to name these days is being indexed to inflation, and that is the outgoings. All the outgoings are being indexed. Some of the taxes like excise are being indexed to inflation. Beer taxes and petrol taxes are all indexed. But when it comes to personal taxation-the fact is that government seems to need an ever-increasing share of our endeavour-the Government will not do it. I think it ought to be done. Fringe benefits tax amounts to $1.1 billion. It is up 13.2 per cent. As I mentioned, petrol and diesel excise is $5.6 billion. It is up 9.3 per cent.

I mention these figures because they are all in excess of the current inflation rate and they are all increases in taxation in real terms. Our policy, of course, in the National Party is to put at least 7c a litre of that excise back into roads. The previous speaker, the right honourable member for New England (Mr Sinclair), mentioned roads. It is one of the major problems that we have in this nation. If we are to continue to export and transfer the goods that we produce, then we have to keep our roads system in the best order possible. Australia is a huge land. It is very difficult for us. There are few of us and it is very expensive for us to maintain the large tracts of roads that we have running from inland to the ports, but we must do it.

The capital gains tax-the hidden death duties-that has been imposed by this Government has shown an enormous increase. Every Australian from a babe in arms onwards must understand that unfortunately once again parents are going to have to prepare themselves for this capital gains tax. It is a regressive tax. Capital gains tax is quite unnecessary in a new country like Australia where we are absolutely desperate for capital. This Government runs interest rates at 20 per cent and better to attract capital from overseas. There is a hue and cry about the Japanese, the Americans and the Europeans investing too much capital in this nation and yet here we have a capital gains tax. If one happens to make some money out of a capital transaction one is expected to pay a tax on it. There is no incentive for people to invest and to attempt to make a profit from capital.

We have seen an estimated 78 per cent increase in the amount of money that is expected to be collected in the next 12 months from capital gains tax-$500m. This Labor Government has the audacity to tell us that it has not increased taxes. What a lot of absolute nonsense.

Some speakers before the dinner break were saying what a great job the Government has done on superannuation. I would argue that there is no net gain in superannuation. Whatever encouragement the Government might be offering for people to take out superannuation, the Government will be taking it back by increasing taxation. All Australians must understand that they are going to be taxed 31 1/4 per cent on any bulk superannuation that they might take out at the end of their working life, on retirement. It is 30 per cent plus a 1 1/4 per cent Medicare levy. The superannuation tax is expected to raise $885m in 1988-89.

As I mentioned before, interest rates are an enormous burden on all forms of business in Australia. The present Treasurer, Mr Keating, is running an iniquitous interest rate policy. The ANZ Bankcard interest rate is at 24.75 per cent. It is an absolute abomination on the Australian people to expect them to survive when paying that interest rate. That is nearly 25 per cent. Most businesses are paying the prime rate now of over 20 per cent. In my electorate of Maranoa, most primary industries businesses are being charged a surcharge by the banks, which I think is an abomination on the part of the banks. I tell them so continually. One of the safest industries in this country, primary industry, which is exporting and earning more dollars than any other industry, is being asked to pay a surcharge of one per cent on the interest on their borrowings. Most farmers and small business people in Maranoa are paying at least 21 per cent interest. If the Treasurer could come in here tonight and tell me how those businesses can survive for more than 12 months when paying that sort of rate, he would be no businessman.

That is the trouble with the people who are in power. Any business that the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) ever touched went bankrupt. He will send the airlines bankrupt at the rate they are going. The pilots strike is probably the worst strike in terms of affecting Australians that we have had for many years, and we see it continuing, with no prospect of an end. I point out to the Prime Minister and his Cabinet, together with the Minister at the table, the Minister for Housing and Aged Care (Mr Staples), that they control Australian Airlines. Surely to goodness they could get it back to work. As I have mentioned before, the managing director and the directors of Australian Airlines should direct their company to negotiate with the pilots and get back to work.

If they cannot do that, obviously they have to find an arbitrator. If they have dirtied their fingers and stickied them too much in getting involved with this strike, then they ought to be looking around for some prominent Australian to be the mediator. Tonight Mr Justice Street has offered to play that role. I would even suggest Malcolm Fraser. The Labor Party seems to be happy with Malcolm Fraser. It is happy to support him in his candidacy for Commonwealth Secretary-General. He has been a Prime Minister and a very prominent Australian. He is the sort of person who should be asked to step in and help to get these two sides together-so that we can get back to work, for God's sake.

Australia needs work and production more than it ever has in its history. Our foreign debt now totals $130 billion. Our balance of payments deficit is estimated in this Budget to run at $18 1/2 billion. It is an absolute disgrace for any government to be suggesting we should be running at those sorts of deficits.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I have had some very prominent members of my electorate in the House today: Bill Copeland, who is the south-west local government region president and chairman of the Taroom Shire; John Waugh, who is chairman of the Waggamba Shire; and Mr Rex Smith, who is chairman of the Beardmore Shire. They have given up their time today. They could not fly here commercially; they had to charter a plane from Goondiwindi to fly to Canberra-and they have been here talking. I would like to thank the Minister for Land Transport and Shipping Support (Mr Robert Brown), the leader of the Liberal Party of Australia, the Leader of our Party, the honourable member for Richmond (Mr Blunt), and the honourable member for Murray (Mr Fife) for giving their time and talking to them today. I think we have had very fruitful discussions. Representing local government, they are very concerned about the lack of funding under the Labor Party-about the continuing cuts in real terms for our road building and for our general purpose grants to local government as well as, of course, the general purpose grants to the States. They all have a flow-on effect on all the people who live in these shires scattered throughout Australia.

It is interesting to run through some of the figures. In 1982, 67 per cent of fuel tax revenue was returned to roads. In 1987 only 27 per cent was returned to roads. They are the sorts of figures we have to look at. Personal income tax returned to local authorities has fallen to 1.46 per cent. When we were last in government we were prepared to return 2 per cent of personal taxation to local authorities. This Labor Government is prepared to return only a little under 1 1/2 per cent.

The gross value of rural production in this area-south-west Queensland; about 10 shires-is estimated to be $597m, with a population of 35,000. On the census figures put out by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, for every man, woman and child who lives in the rural areas there is a per capita income level of $34,900. So we can see the sort of income that these people are producing to keep this country as rich as it is. These figures do not include oil production from the area-the Jackson oilfield and the Moonie oilfield in the Roma area, which are estimated to be producing $470m a year. These people are very concerned because they are not getting enough of the funds back into that area. There is a bridge badly needed over Coopers Creek at Nappa Merry-I have mentioned this before in the House. Coopers Creek has been in full flood in the last couple of months. The oil exploration companies have to travel an extra 300 miles to service the oilfields in the Jackson area and in the Coopers Creek area, where they continue to find many small oilfields.

Mr Deputy Speaker, I think it is important that those on the Treasury bench look at devoting more funding to the road system in Australia, particularly to those areas such as in the south-west of Queensland that are badly in need of extra funding, because they are the areas that are earning the export income for this nation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hewson Dr J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will concentrate my remarks at the committee stage on the appropriations for the departments of the Treasury and Finance, in particular some of the money that has been obviously expended in those areas in relation to the exercise of forecasting and the preparation of the Budget figuring, per se. On 16 August, in a debate on a matter of public importance, I drew the attention of the House to the fairly innovative accounting of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and his Department in the preparation of this Budget.

SPEECH.PARA: In particular, I drew attention to the $9.1 billion surplus figure which was erected on the basis of pretty extensive increases in taxation, particularly bracket creep and sales tax excesses and, of course, massive increases in taxes on superannuation. But most particularly, I drew attention to the innovative accounting changes that exaggerated the extent of the $9.1 billion surplus figure in this year. Specifically, there is revenue brought from last year into this year; there is some prepayment of expenditure last year from this year; and there are some revenue changes in the Budget-the payment of company tax and the payment of PAYE tax-which had the effect of bringing forward revenue from next year into this year.

The Treasurer's response on that particular occasion in the debate on that matter of public importance was to suggest that my remarks were fraudulent, that I had somehow misled the Parliament and the people of Australia as to the extent of that innovative accounting. I thought it was worth drawing the attention of the House to the recently released statement of Commonwealth Government financial transactions for July 1989, which was published on 1 September by the Minister for Finance, Senator Walsh, in which he makes the point quite nicely for me. In particular, this document suggests:
the primary reason for the surplus in July is the receipt of $1016m from the sale of the Defence Service Homes Mortgage Portfolio to Westpac.

That was one of the items I drew attention to which could have been received in June. But receipt was delayed until the middle of the month of July, thereby boosting this year's Budget surplus figure by $1 billion relative to what would have been the case.

Similarly, on the second page of that document attention is drawn to a couple of other items which make a similar point. For example, the collections from non-PAYE other individuals tax during the month of July were $272m, which is a 260.3 per cent increase above the collections of July 1988. The relevant part of the document states:
This reflected some slippage into 1989-90 of collections which would normally have been collected in 1988-89.
Similarly, company tax collections for July were up 40.3 per cent on collections of July last year. Again the relevant quote is:
. . . reflecting some slippage of collections into 1989-90 as a result of the late issue of assessments last year.

The figure of $9.1 billion is a total fiction; it is based on a very significant reliance on innovative accounting. This is vindicated by the statement of the Minister for Finance about the delay in the receipt of revenue from last year, the prepayment of expenditure and the bringing forward of tax receipts from next year into this year. One of those in particular that I would like to draw attention to is the change in relation to the payment of company tax.

I doubt very much whether the Treasurer had any idea what he was doing in bringing forward the payment of company tax, particularly in circumstances where corporate cash flow this year is already going to be very tight, particularly in circumstances where, by his own admission, interest rates are unlikely to fall significantly in the course of this year, and particularly in circumstances when there is already a record number of corporate failures on the books at this time. He brings forward the payment of corporate tax in a way that obviously suits his revenue numbers and his Budget figuring but it will inflict an enormous amount of pain on the corporate sector as a whole, and in particular on the small business sector.

I will cite just one example of the way this tax will work in relation to companies that balance, let us say, on 30 November 1990 instead of June 1990. They will be required to pay 85 per cent of their notional tax on 15 July. They will be required to pay 85 per cent of their tax in relation to an income year of which they have had only eight months. The Budget Papers say that a penalty of 10 per cent will be imposed on that tax liability if they underestimate the extent of that tax liability. One can imagine the situation that puts companies in. The example I have cited is from the next financial year. That is an extreme version of the problem that will apply generally across the business community as businesses attempt to meet that increased tax burden. How will the business community meet that tax burden? We have estimated from the Budget Papers an interest saving of about $330m for the Government from that moving forward of corporate tax. If we add a reasonable margin for the difference between a private sector borrower and a government borrower, we are looking at the extent to which the interest bill of the corporate sector will be increased in struggling to pay that additional tax. This particular change is on this Treasurer's head. The pain in the small business community will be unbelievable and the number of small business failures in the course of this year will be quite significant relative to the expectations, which were bad enough, just a few months ago.

We should look particularly at the neglect and ignorance of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) in relation to the current pilots dispute and the impact that will have on a large part of the small business community, notably the tourist sector, which is an employer of some 500,000 Australians and a contributor of about $22 billion to our gross domestic product (GDP). The pain from this tax increase for small business in that sector in current circumstances will be staggering.

This will be my final comment in relation to this Budget figuring. The Prime Minister today made an amazing statement, as reported on Australian Associated Press, apparently in his briefing to Caucus, when he drew attention to the fact that the Government was still expecting a soft landing for the economy provided the pilots dispute did not affect the 7 per cent wages forecast in last month's Budget. The quote, carried on Reuters, that he was reported to have made is in the following terms: `This dispute is serious and as damaging as this dispute is it is nothing as to the disaster that would happen to the economy if we allowed their 29 per cent wage claim to go ahead'.

In making that statement the Prime Minister shows that he really does not understand very much about the current state of the Australian economy or the potential damage of the continuing pilots dispute. He is wrong on several counts. Firstly, the Budget growth forecasts admit the possibility of a significant fall-off in GDP in the second half of this year. In fact they are consistent with the possibility of a recession in the second half of this year. If Senator Walsh was right in his statements to the National Press Club last week that GDP will be revised upwards for 1989-90, there is already a very real possibility of a recession in the second half of this year. So if in the Budget figuring the economy is admitted to be teetering on the brink of a recession, what will be the effect of the pilots strike if it is allowed to continue?

Secondly, the quote from the Prime Minister refers to the wages growth forecast of 7 per cent. If he looks at the numbers, he will see that wages growth is already running well ahead of 7 per cent and is unlikely to be any less than 7 per cent in the circumstances that now exist in the economy. Finally, of course, given that the pilots are now claiming they are willing to negotiate wage increases on the basis of productivity improvements, if those productivity gains are genuine I find it hard to see how the wage increases on that basis would be a disaster for the economy. The real disaster is the Prime Minister. The real disaster is the accord. The real disaster is that the accord has locked our economy into unsustainable growth rates and given us across the board wage increases that are unrelated to productivity such that our inflation rate is now stuck at between 7 and 8 per cent on a fudge basis. The Prime Minister has obviously got no idea of the magnitude of the economic problem he has created for this country by letting this pilots dispute drift on and have its impact on the tourist sector.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cunningham Mr B.T.

TALK.START.PARA: -Having listened to the shadow Treasurer, the honourable member for Wentworth (Dr Hewson), in this chamber, it is understandable that the Opposition is in such disarray in relation to its policy position. In a 10-minute speech this evening he has spent half the time trying to make some capital out of what should have gone into last year's surplus Budget and what went into this year's surplus Budget, bearing in mind that both of those surplus Budgets are on record as the most appropriate response to Australia's economic situation that any government has ever put into place. Here we have a shadow Treasurer trying to make comments in relation to the fact that had last year's Budget been a fortnight earlier, the surplus would have been larger and had this year's Budget been a fortnight later, the surplus would have been slightly smaller. I am sure that is a major issue with the Australian public.

SPEECH.PARA: I think the Australian public knows and understands that this Government has created a climate where we have gone from massive deficit Budgets in the last three years, to surplus Budgets. That is the sort of economic strategy that every person in this nation would applaud the Treasurer (Mr Keating) for. One only has to look at the response of the money markets, of the investors of industry in Australia, to see that they fully appreciate that the policy positions put into place by the Treasurer certainly have the confidence of those who are making those sorts of decisions. Of course, if we were to look at the families in Australia, particularly the 1,500,000 families who now have jobs because of this policy development, they also would appreciate the fact that it does not really make a great deal of difference if it is a fortnight one way or a fortnight the other. The real crux of the matter is that we are running into a position of surplus Budgets and those surplus Budgets are the measures that are required for this nation at the present time.

The points that I want to go to deal with the person who leads the Opposition, and that is the honourable member for Kooyong (Mr Peacock), in relation to what he had to say in his response to the Budget. The item that I want to concentrate on in my short time is that in the taxation area he did make a couple of statements in relation to what the Opposition would do if it were able to persuade the public to give it a majority of votes at the next election. His sum total in that, of course, was that the major area that he was looking at-he listed it at No. 5-was that he would, in a desperate grab for votes, abolish the capital gains tax. Now surely if there is any issue in this nation today that has been put to rest and has been accepted by the community in Australia, it is that those who earn a profit-those who use the facilities and the assets of Australia for their own benefit and those who work hard to achieve it-have every right to make a profit. They have every right to make a good living. But certainly nobody has the right to take that profit as free capital gain and not pay his share of taxes.

Yet here we have the Leader of the Opposition standing before this Parliament and telling us that he would abolish the capital gains tax. It is of interest that in the last financial year collections from the capital gains tax grew by $180m above the Budget estimates. So $180m was collected from the profits of those industries which take their profits in capital gains. That $180m was over and above the $180m that was estimated. So we have a total of $281m collected, fairly, from those people who made a profit. But the Opposition is standing in this Parliament telling us that we believe that that sector of the economy-those people who took their profit by capital gains-have some privileged position, that they should be allowed to have their money, to earn it and not to pay their share of taxes.

They do not drive on our roads, do they? They do not use our schools. They do not need our hospitals. No, all they are entitled to, according to the Leader of the Opposition, is to have their profits free of tax. Why? Why, after seven years of hard slog by this Government, would any Opposition think it was going to win votes from the public of Australia by standing in this Parliament and telling the public that it is going to select a specific group of people and tell them that the income on which they paid $181m in tax-bearing in mind that they still had their fair share to live on and to spend for themselves-would be free of tax?

The estimate in the Budget papers for capital gains collections this financial year is now $500m. If we are going to talk about a figure of that nature, surely the Opposition on the Budget night should have told us just what it was going to do with it. What it is going to do with the $500m? It is not going to collect it, so if the $500m is not in the hands of those opposite but in their friends' hands, then somebody is going to miss out on the other side of the equation. The Opposition never said one word about that. It will not tell anybody just where it would cut in order to make that possible.

In the past the collections under the capital gains tax head of power were much more limited and there was dispute between the Government and the Opposition as to what exactly would be the cost of modifying this Government's capital gains tax legislation. We have largely removed this doubt by repealing section 26aaa, which did tax short term gains under a different head of power from our 1985 reform. We did have a capital gains tax under the Opposition in government but it was not a capital gains tax that generated any revenue; it was a capital gains tax that enabled people to avoid the system, to develop whatever they were involved in and wait a little while to avoid the tax. With that distinction removed, there is no disputing the $500m estimate in this Budget. In actual fact, collections truly attributable to the capital gains tax are probably even higher. It is beyond doubt that the existence of the capital gains tax legislation chases into the ordinary tax system revenue which in its absence would be taken as tax-free capital gain.

What do we mean by that? Quite simply, under the old system we had an industry in Australia, the tax evasion industry, whereby a lot of industries spent a lot of time and effort and paid for a lot of expertise to have their accountants develop a system to put them into the tax-free capital gains area. With the law as it is today, the Australian tax system has settled down and industry is developing its accounting and its methods of operation on the basis that there is little need to put a lot of effort into paying for very creative accountants. The system is clean and honest; it has everybody paying a fair share, so that a lot of the revenue today is going into the normal system whereas in the past it would have gone into capital gains.

There is still every reason why industry can take advantage of the benefits of having a capital gains tax, in the same say as it can take the benefits, when it suits, of a fringe benefits tax. But the taxing system now allows industry and those who are looking at the tax laws to take a position, bearing in mind their own industry, their own business, on whether they pay capital gains tax or company tax; whether they pay pay as you earn tax or are prepared to offer a package of fringe benefits to their employees. At least today, in comparison to the past, every individual who has a tax file number and who is earning an income is expected to pay his or her fair share towards our hospitals, our roads, our total package of services provided by the public sector.

In my last minute I want to make this one plea to the Opposition. Why is it that the Opposition wants to select a group of people who are to be entitled to earn income by capital gain and who are entitled when they earn that capital gain to get it tax free? Why would the Opposition expect anybody in Australia to accept that as a policy? I cannot understand why any Leader of the Opposition would put that to the Australian people and expect to get support. It has been rejected in the past. There is certainly no way in the world that the Australian people will go back to that position and redevelop that industry which was the only one developed by our predecessors-that is, the tax avoidance industry. We have a fair system and I believe that fair system must stay in place. I am sure that the Australian people will accept that and will vote accordingly when they get the chance at the next election.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aldred Mr K.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In this debate on the Appropriation Bill (No. 1) 1989-90 I wish to concentrate my remarks on the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet (DPMC). A total of $80,851,000 has been appropriated for the DPMC, down $7.9m from last year's actual expenditure-due in most part, of course, to the cessation of appropriations for the Australian Bicentennial Authority. However, the overall level of funding for DPMC has increased in line with this Government's big Commonwealth spending policies. I note particularly that the Office of National Assessments (ONA) has had an increase in its budget of $1,092,174, which is an increase equal to nearly one-third of its 1988-89 expenditure. Australia's strategic area of concern is becoming more and more dynamic. It is therefore important that we have in place organisations such as the ONA to enable us to at least try to remain on top of events in our ever changing regional situation.

SPEECH.PARA: As important as the strategic regional situation is our own domestic situation. The activities of hostile intelligence services and terrorist organisations within Australia are of as much importance as the dynamic forces reshaping our region. Having said that, the House will be aware that over recent weeks the Australian newspaper legitimately has been raising serious and quite disturbing matters concerning the activities of the Yugoslav Intelligence Service (YIS) in Australia. In 1977 some allegedly secret government files concerning the YIS were leaked and were subsequently published in the media. The documents say that the YIS consists of three separate organisations, one of which is the DB or state internal security service which even today is still commonly referred to as the UDBA although its name changed some time ago. The leaked documents said that there were five identified and 17 suspected YIS officers in Australia at that time. They further said that the YIS officers were operating under diplomatic and consular cover as well as trade and commercial enterprise cover. Importantly, the point was made that the YIS in Australia did not appear to have embarked upon classic KGB-type espionage activities; rather, it was concentrating on preserving and maintaining internal stability in Yugoslavia. That is, the YIS in Australia concentrates on monitoring Yugoslav migrants.

The documents identified three general strategies of the YIS in Australia: the acquisition of intelligence concerning the activities of the Yugoslav emigre community in Australia, with particular emphasis on Croatian nationalist groups; the employment of tactics designed to discredit anti-Yugoslav Government groups; and various activities designed to promote the image of the Yugoslav state. So, in effect, the YIS is mounting operations in Australia and against Australian residents.

A further important point that was emphasised was that Australian officials were surprised at how detailed was the Yugoslav Government's knowledge of the activities of prominent Yugoslavs in Australia. This has obviously not changed, because on 2 May 1987 Mr Jim Duncan, the Second Secretary at Australia's embassy in Yugoslavia, was reported as saying that charges laid by the Yugoslav Government against Mr Draya Pantelich for anti-Yugoslav Government activities within Australia raised the question of whether the Yugoslav Government was involved in espionage in Australia. It is alleged that at least two Croatian political organisations, the Croatian Liberation Movement, the HOP, and the Croatian Movement for Statehood, the HDP, are not in fact Croatian organisations but are organisations set up and run by the Yugoslav Intelligence Service for the purpose of penetrating the Croatian community and running agent provocateur operations.

Furthermore, the leaked documents raised the possibility that the bomb attacks and violent incidents perpetrated against official Yugoslav missions in Australia may have been carried out by the YIS in an attempt to discredit the various Croatian groups. In fact, police investigations of one shooting incident revealed that the ammunition used was of a type available only in Yugoslavia.
It is interesting to note that, at the document's conclusion, the summary of the YIS's activities in Australia says in part:
It can be expected that . . . the YIS will continue and intensify those activities.

In its 29-30 July 1989 edition, the Weekend Australian, in one of a series of articles on the YIS, identified one Yugoslav official currently serving in Australia, namely Mr Ivan Dronjic, as a Yugoslav intelligence officer operating as a consular official in Melbourne. The same article also alleged that dossiers on Croatians in Australia are held at YIS headquarters in Yugoslavia. These dossiers allegedly contain detailed reports on the activities of political organisations, and social, cultural and sporting clubs of numerous Croatian identities resident in Australia. The journalist became aware of these dossiers from a source inside the Yugoslav Department of Foreign Affairs in Belgrade.

Most disturbing of all, though, is that I am led to believe that several of these dossiers substantially originated from the Yugoslav Welfare Association based at Fitzroy in Melbourne. The Association ostensibly is a non-government community organisation catering for the welfare of Yugoslavs in Australia. Just exactly how these files containing details on Australian residents found their way from Fitzroy to Belgrade is a mystery, but it is a mystery that needs to be investigated as a matter of some urgency. Quite obviously some body or bodies facilitated their transfer to Yugoslavia.

Turning back to Mr Ivan Dronjic, it is clear from a series of newspaper articles and information provided to me from sources in the Yugoslav community that he has a large network of informers in the Australian Yugoslav community. It also seems apparent that he has one particularly well placed informer with whom he seems to work very closely. Indeed, the Australian of 30 August this year said that this informer is attempting to use his influence to block the application for permanent residency of the Yugoslav-born leader of the Footscray Islamic Society, Imam Azam Efindira. This same informant apparently also has a long-standing and close association with the Yugoslav Welfare Association, the records of which have ended up in Belgrade.

These are serious and disturbing allegations that need to be thoroughly investigated. It seems pointless to spend millions of dollars of taxpayers' money on maintaining organisations such as the Office of National Assessments if allegations such as those raised in the Australian are allowed to pass without any sort of investigation.

Finally, if for no other reason, a thorough investigation must be carried out due to the allegations raised by the Australian newspaper that an informer of Mr Ivan Dronjic is alleged to be a Federal Labor member.
