SPEECH.SPEAKER: Martin Mr S.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to concentrate also on the portfolio program area dealing with the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet, and in particular to talk about the allocation of funds under the 1989-90 Budget and beyond for women. It is important that this particular part of the Budget receive some attention, simply because, with honourable members' attention being directed at the superannuation package and a range of other areas, this very important part of the Budget and the decisions that have arisen out of the National Agenda for Women, which this Government launched last year, tend to be lost.

SPEECH.PARA: Honourable members will recall that more than two years of consultation with over 25,000 women underpin the Government's National Agenda for Women program which was released in February 1988. Since that time there has been an ongoing commitment by this Government, by a Federal Labor government, to improving the lot of women in our society by making appropriate contributions through the Budget processes and through the other fiscal and monetary processes available to government through April and May statements, just to ensure that the economic imperatives faced by women are addressed.

I will take the time of the House very briefly, just to remind honourable members of some of those particular things. For example, the latest labour force figures from June 1989 show that about 51.1 per cent of women aged between 15 and 65 now participate in the paid work force. That compares with about 44 per cent in April 1983. The women's unemployment rate has fallen from 10.4 per cent to 6.6 per cent over the same period. Women receiving pensions and benefits and those on low incomes have been assisted through the introduction of the family allowance supplement in December 1987. That payment, of course, provides additional untaxed assistance for low income families with children.

The April statement of 1989-the document that was the forerunner to the Budget that we are debating tonight-built upon the Government's commitment to the economic security of women and families. The wage-tax family package included considerable increases in family allowance payments, which I remind honourable members increased to $9 a week for each of the first three children, and $12 a week for the fourth and subsequent children, and an increase in the family allowance supplement. More importantly, of course, these benefits are to be increased annually as required and index-linked to the consumer price index. The tax cuts announced in the statement particularly benefit women workers. The reduction in the lowest tax rates is of most advantage to people on low pay, most of whom are women.

What we hear is cant and hypocrisy from honourable members opposite, who say that the coalition partners, the conservatives, are the ones that stand for the family; that they are the ones who look after the affairs of the family and the needs of women.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is a fantasy.

—Quite clearly, as my colleague the honourable member for Perth suggests, it is a fantasy; it is a fallacy and it is ridiculous in the extreme. The 1989 Budget highlights for women build on those measures that were announced in the April statement of this year. I will quickly refer to some of those. The women's health strategy will involve a total expenditure of some $43m from 1989-90 to 1992-93, including a number of cost sharing arrangements with States and Territories on the national women's health program. For example, there will be an increase of some $1m this year, increasing to $6 1/2m in 1991-92 and 1992-93. There will be an injection of funds in the birthing services proposed by this Government-$600,000 in 1989 and $5.84m over the next three years. They are significant contributions to those areas of concern to women in the development of the health strategy for this country.

SPEECH.PARA: Part and parcel of that is the ongoing commitment of this Government in respect of women in sport, to build on the success that has occurred at the Australian Institute of Sport. The Women's Sport Promotion Unit will receive an additional funding of $640,000 over the next four years. In particular that unit will further develop a campaign to promote sport for adolescent girls. It has been identified that those girls within our community need to be encouraged to develop in sport so that their awkwardness and their concerns as to how they fit into society and so on are overcome. This is very important to young women of that age. The problem, of course, in this area is not new; it is in fact old. So there will be some research and resources developed to show teenage girls what sport has to offer and to make sport available to them. Secondly, there will be a promotion and community campaign to make girls in the community aware of what they can do and what is available through this program. Those are just some of the things that have been done under the women's health strategy.

There will be increases of up to $7 a week in child-care fee relief for family day care and long day care centres and an annual indexation of fee relief in future years at a cost of $8.9m this year, rising to $16.5m in future years. There will also be outside school hours care. There will be an introduction of fee relief for low income families, subject to cost sharing arrangements with the States and Territories. Additionally, in rent assistance for pensioners, beneficiaries and low income families in private rental accommodation there will be increases of $5 a week in both December 1989 and September 1990, in addition to those announced last year, and future indexation. Again, all of these matters are particularly relevant to women and all go to the heart of this Government's attitude to social policy and the agenda for ensuring that those in our community less able to look after themselves receive appropriate levels of government assistance. Housing is one of the major issues of concern to all members of this chamber. Mortgage and public housing rent relief funding has been increased by $15m. It applies equally across the board, but nevertheless women are great beneficiaries of that program which has been developed in this Budget.

One area of great concern to women is the domestic violence education program. I was pleased to see that in the Budget this year there is additional funding of some $125,000, bringing total funding for this year to $953,000. I think all honourable members would agree that domestic violence in our society is repugnant. I am sure that they all support the Government in its endeavours to eradicate domestic violence and to undertake the appropriate education programs on this very sad aspect of our society. I commend the Government for providing a level of funding commensurate with that problem. As far as family planning is concerned, there has been an injection of $12.142m in the Budget this year. Finally, for family mediation and marriage counselling services $8.824m has been allocated this year.

Those are just some of the packages which fall within the portfolio responsibility of Prime Minister and Cabinet because the National Agenda for Women falls under the responsibility of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke). There are many others, however, and I would commend honourable members in this place, and indeed the women of Australia, to look at what this Government has done specifically for them. Too often we have heard those on the other side cry that this Government has lost its way, that it does not have any feeling, that it has lost its social responsibility, that it is not looking after those people that the Labor Party traditionally is supposed to look after. That is nonsense; it is proven consistently to be so, and the 1989-90 Budget clearly demonstrates that to be the case.

I have tried to go to some of the more important Budget highlights for women that have been developed by this Government. There are many others. I could have talked about bereavement packages, the rural multi-purpose health facilities program, the remote area social security client services, the labour market package, the reform package for client services at the Commonwealth Employment Service, training packages, the new social justice strategy, and so on. It is all part of the Hawke Labor Government's commitment to improving the lot in this community of people who need assistance and guidance. It is to be commended. It is a step in the direction of building on what this Government has done consistently over the last seven years, and I commend that particular section of the Budget Papers to all honourable members.

SPEECH.PARA: I have looked through the Estimates and it is very interesting to aggregate the support that this Government draws from the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet-in fact, the support and policy advice that the Prime Minister receives. Whilst the total Budget allocation for the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet is down, the policy advice division is up by 66 per cent. That is $1m a week for the type of government that we are getting. I think that that is very expensive, very costly, especially when the Prime Minister can make remarks about airline pilots being equivalent to bus drivers. If one were to extend that process one would say the support services that I have just outlined, for EPAC, policy, government support, machinery of government, the support services and public administration and accountability, should all certainly be part of the processes the Prime Minister, the Treasurer and other members of the Ministry have at their disposal to operate government.

One would not question the personal allocations to these Ministers, including the Prime Minister and the Treasurer, of cars, personal staff or residences; I think that is all perfectly appropriate. I then looked at the Prime Minister's salary and found that in fact he has available an amount of $56,931 a year in addition to the normal members' salary scale. I thought: Why does the Prime Minister actually need that additional personal wealth if he has a philosophy that pilots are like bus drivers? I am suggesting that the Prime Minister actually should keep these support services outlined in the estimates but not have that personal wealth, if that is his philosophy. I do not agree with it but it is the proposition that he puts to the Australian people, I believe much to the detriment of himself and his own good standing in the community.

Really, he is saying in regard to the airline strike, `The airline that I operate and that airline of my friend need to have special circumstances apply to the way in which the arrangements are made'. In fact, he is standing between the airlines and the pilots and saying, `I-with my policy advice, funding for which is 66 per cent up this year; with the $1m support for my Government on all of these things that we need-am going to stand between the airline of the Australian people and that of my friend and I am going to prevent these two parties from coming together'. There is one of two reasons that a Prime Minister may have received this policy advice and it may well be that, through the processes of the $9.3m of support for specific services to the Department of the Prime Minister and Cabinet for government, the Prime Minister has come to one of two conclusions on this issue. The first could be `I should not let the system fail'-and there may be a number of reasons for that-and the other could be `I and my friend need to have something gained from this process'. There can be no other reasons.

SPEECH.PARA: The logic of the circumstances is that the Prime Minister should withdraw from being between the two parties and allow them to resolve the issue. He has the policy advice; he has the Government support. We are debating that tonight. He and the Treasurer claim that they are running this country better than it was ever run before. The 66 per cent increase in policy advice may not be reflected in the current circumstances. On top of that, to think that in resolving the current dreadful situation Australia is in with the airline strike compensation should be paid to either the airlines or any of the other operators is crazy. The Government should get that idea off the agenda very quickly because that will mean that in every circumstance people will come to government. We will not have a Prime Minister and Cabinet estimate of $88m; we will have an estimate of thousands of millions of dollars, because that compensation will come from the Australian people. Tonight, as we look at these estimates, we look at the circumstances that have brought Australia to where it is. We see small expenditure by these departments compared with other departments, but they are being run to control other departments. They involve the collection of revenue and the tax laws, areas which are of significance to the Australian people. They are being run very badly because the Australian people are not being considered in this process.

It does not matter whether it is the airlines or whether it is the waterfront. We do not hear too much from the Government when there is a waterfront strike, yet there is more money lost in a waterfront stoppage than there is in this dispute. The Prime Minister has little regard for the average Australian or he would not have spoken about bus drivers in the way that he did. That is reflected in the policies of the Treasurer. He is remote and superior in his attitude. He has little regard for the people of Bankstown, Carlton, or anywhere else in Australia, or he would dramatically change the policies this Government has brought forward. It is time for the Prime Minister to stand aside from where he is in the airline dispute, to stand aside from policy decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: I did not want to raise the airline dispute tonight but it has been raised by a number of speakers in this debate. It goes to the question of micro-economic reform and efficiency in government. Every time we on this side of the House talk about deregulating, the great free enterprise merchants on the other side, the great deregulators, jump up and down and complain, whether the topic is wheat marketing deregulation or the airlines. Indeed, for the last two or three days in this place we have heard the honourable member for O'Connor (Mr Tuckey) complaining about the fact that the two airlines agreement is in place. What he needs to remember is that the previous Government conceived it and perpetuated it. This Government has sought to change it. While I do not always agree with the philosophical view of John Hyde, who is reported in the Australian today, I respect him for the accuracy and honesty of his intellectual argument. What does he have to say about this matter? I quote from his article in the Australian today:
The Two Airline Agreement is the underlying cause of the air pilots' dispute. Uncompetitive airlines which could pass costs on to a captive clientele all sorts of inefficiencies.
A militant, monopolistic pilots' union, representing pilots who fly only about half the hours of those in the United States, is but one example.
Had the Fraser Cabinet given notice in 1980 that it would repeal the Two Airline Agreement, we would not be going through this trauma now.

Indeed, that is the case. Every time we talk about efficiency and deregulation, the Opposition complains because some opportunistic group or somebody else gets to it and it sees a political advantage in the issue. I want to say only one more thing about the pilots dispute: there are many groups in Australia and many people in the gallery tonight who would like a 30 per cent increase in their wages without doing any more work, but there are very few groups, if any, except for the pilots, that would choose to bring the country to its knees in order to effect their avaricious claims. I think that is the point that needs to be made, and made very strongly, in this place.

If we look at the last 6 1/2 years of Budget management-indeed, as we are discussing the estimates for the Department of Finance I would like to focus on that tonight-what we see is a quantitative change in the bottom line of the Budget, one that is more significant than anyone would have believed possible 6 1/2 years ago. We have gone from a deficit of $9 billion to a surplus of $9 billion. Australia was borrowing $9 billion to pay all its bills 6 1/2 ago, and now we have a surplus of earnings over expenditure. That is a significant quantitative change.

More important than that, there has been a qualitative change in the composition of the Budget. Why have we been able to produce such a dramatic result? I admit there has been significant and continuous economic growth over this time. That has been part of the reason, and we are not totally responsible for that because the international situation has played a part. This surplus is a result of expenditure control, of a decrease in outlays, which has been more significant than ever before in the management of the economy of this country. There has been six percentage points of gross domestic product change in the outlays. We are back now to the spending levels of 1972 and 1973. In two more years, if we continue according to the Forward Estimates, we will be back to 1950 levels of government expenditure. While the Opposition has always talked about small government-it has had a very perverse interest in it-it has never been able to deliver the goods. Indeed, the question needs to be asked: Would it ever be able to? We have never seen it do so.

When the Opposition talks about program savings and significant cuts in expenditure, whenever some interest group complains, it jumps on the bandwagon and finds a reason not to implement it. There has been significant rigour by this Government when it comes to our scrutiny of outlays. I want to give one or two examples of the sort of savings that I am talking about. The Department of Finance, which has played a most significant part in this program, deserves the credit for it.

The first example is that in 1981 the Liberal Government, under the guise of making savings, abolished the requirement for people to lodge personally with the Commonwealth Employment Service (CES) fortnightly continuation of benefit forms. In order to receive unemployment benefits it had been the case that fortnightly one had to lodge a form personally with the CES office. That requirement was removed in 1981 under the guise of savings. At the time, the ratio between unemployment benefit recipients and people who were actively seeking full time work was 98 : 100. So for every 98 unemployment benefit recipients there were 100 people actively seeking work. By June of 1985 that ratio had blown out so that there were 125 people receiving unemployment benefits for every 100 people who were actively seeking work. There was a lack of rigour, a lack of scrutiny over government expenditure as a result of that change initiated by the Liberal Government in 1981.

This Government re-introduced the personal continuation benefit form lodgment and it tightened up a number of other areas under which unemployment benefits were administered. We introduced 20 mobile unemployment benefit review teams and this Budget provides for a further 10 teams to be added to that group. We introduced work intention forms so that only people genuinely seeking work were eligible for unemployment benefits. We made it necessary for applicants to get a certificate from their employer stating the reason and the date on which they lost their job. So no longer was the system able to be rorted and we now find that that ratio, which was 98 : 100, which blew out to 125 : 100, is now back to its original figure. If one does the sums one finds that there will be a cost saving to the Government of $1 billion in this Budget on unemployment benefits that are not being paid now as a result of that financial rigour, as a result of the control over that program exercised by the Department of Finance.

If we look at another area-the assets test-which was opposed by the Opposition for puny political reasons, we see it is completely outside any economic rationale at all. What did Opposition members say? Prior to its introduction the proportion of old people who were of pensionable age, that is receiving pensions, was 82 per cent. Since we introduced the assets test that has dropped by 5 per cent. There were millionaires receiving pensions. There were all sorts of people receiving pensions who did not need that assistance from the Government. We look at the saving level within this year's Budget and we find that the saving is $600m. There we have $1.6 billion of savings in this year's Budget as a result of just two programs in which there has been significant rigour provided by the Government. That significant rigour has brought about significant savings, changed the structure that was put in place by the Opposition and made for more efficiency and for more effective targeting of our outlays.

It is because of that sort of rigour that we now find ourselves in the position where we have a significant Budget surplus. What do we get from the Opposition? Every time that we try to introduce something that is fair and balanced and sensible and efficient, we get hypocrisy, we get carping criticism, we get negativism, we get inconsistency because there may be some puny political advantage for the Opposition in opposing it. There may be some pensioners out there who have been copping plenty, who have got plenty, who are receiving a pension and may be concerned.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to talk about the allocations to the Department of the Treasury and specifically the allocations that relate to the Foreign Investment Review Board which were obviously very small allocations. In that context I shall say something about the attitude of the Government and, more particularly, the general attitude of the Australian community, to the issue of foreign investment. There is no doubt that over many years foreign investment in Australia has been a very emotional issue. Everyone knows that and people on the other side of the chamber have been particularly enthusiastic over the last 30 or 40 years in promoting that debate on foreign investment. I may not be very old by the standards of this House but I can well remember the 1960s when the Australian Labor Party criticised American investment in Australia including, curiously, the investment by the Americans in General Motors-Holden's Ltd. The defence of that American investment in Australia and therefore in Australian jobs with the development of technology in an Australian car industry was put forward by the Liberal Party and the then Country Party.

SPEECH.PARA: We on this side of the chamber know that foreign investment is vastly important to Australia. That has never been truer than it is today during a time of current account crisis for our country. We have an extraordinarily serious current account and balance of payments situation. We have an extraordinarily serious foreign debt situation in Australia as well. Budget Paper No. 1 shows how that foreign debt situation is getting progressively worse. Net external liabilities, Budget Paper No. 1 points out, are now 41 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP), which is really an extraordinary figure. The net external liability servicing ratio is 22 per cent of goods and services exported from Australia whereas in the early 1980s when the Fraser Government was in office the figure was only 11 per cent. This is extremely relevant to the issue of foreign investment because foreign investment-capital imports if you like-act as an important offset to this serious current account and balance of payments problem.

What I do not think is often recognised is that the net position in Australia in terms of capital flows is deteriorating. I am a great believer in free-flowing capital markets, including Australian companies investing abroad. I note that Australian revenue from investments abroad constitutes about 5 per cent of our export earnings, so it is becoming increasingly an important part of our international activity. But Australian investment abroad over recent years has grown by 27.6 per cent in 1984-85, 25.9 per cent in 1985-86, 40.2 per cent in 1986-87 and 16.1 per cent in 1987-88. Total Australian investment abroad by June 1987, which seems to be the latest time for which figures are available, was $60.2 billion as against foreign investment in Australia of $174 billion. So, when people go around saying we have got to put the brakes on foreign investment in Australia, they forget that the net position in terms of investment, in terms of capital flows, while still positive, is deteriorating. If they want to put the brakes on foreign investment in Australia through strengthening the powers of the Foreign Investment Review Board and the like, they will simply exacerbate the economic catastrophe of our balance of payments situation.

Everyone knows we are a resource rich country and a capital poor country. Our savings are too small; that is an important part of the current debate in the community today. It is worth noting that since 1960 there have been only three years when domestic savings have been greater than total investment. In 1960 savings were about 25 per cent of our GDP; today they are about 17 per cent of our GDP. So we have declining savings. The Government argues that we spend 6 per cent more than we produce, so we need more investment in order to produce more in order to reduce our balance of payments problems. Yet there are people going around in the community, and being aided and abetted by a large number of members of this House, and saying that we need to restrict foreign investment-if you like, restrict investment. Those are the sorts of people who forget that 70 per cent of new manufacturing jobs created in Australia since World War II were created by foreign investment. I have already referred to perhaps the best-known foreign investor, General Motors Holden's Ltd.

The latest debate in Australia on the issue of foreign investment is a peculiarly sad debate because not only is it intellectually and economically wrong-I hope I have in five minutes briefly alluded to that-but it is based on bad intentions because it is generated by anti-Japanese feeling. There are some people who say we have too much Japanese investment in Australia. They are not worried about British, American, Italian, Greek or German investment; they apparently are worried about Japanese investment. Some people even run the incredible argument that it is not discrimination to say that Japanese investment is not wanted but British investment is fine. The fact is that capital, which is what this money is, is owned by somebody. That is how it becomes known as Japanese investment. If people are going to go out into the community and argue that we should restrict Japanese investment, that means they are specifically discriminating against Japanese people, and that I must say is something I find peculiarly abhorrent.

When we look at the figures on foreign investment in any case we find that 34 per cent of foreign investment in Australia comes from America; 29.6 per cent from Britain; only 9 per cent from Japan; and 8.5 per cent from other European Community countries. So whilst Japanese investment has increased very substantially in recent years-but, by the way, not by as much as British investment did over the last year-the fact is that Japanese investment still represents a small proportion of total investment in this country. So I think this has been a very sad reflection on the intellectual debate in this country and the political expedience of some in this House, including the Treasurer (Mr Keating), who have given some sort of tacit and in other cases active support to the feelings against Japanese investment, which are feelings based more on racism than on economic logic or intellectual credibility.

I think it is fair enough for the Australian community to have some understanding of where investment is taking place in the area of land, and I have no difference with those people who argue that the States should set up land registers of foreign investment. I do not mind that at all. But I do think it is important that we not overreact to that community feeling against Japanese investment and strengthen the powers of the Foreign Investment Review Board and end up simply by first of all discriminating, I think in an abhorrent way, against investment from one particular country; and, secondly, doing something which in the longer term will do this country very real economic damage.

I go back to what I said earlier: the fact is this country needs foreign investment and it needs it desperately to try to build up its economy, to build up the infrastructure it needs, to build up the capital it needs, to produce more and to do it more efficiently and more effectively in order to become competitive in the international marketplace. If we are going to say that we do not want foreign investment, or we are half-hearted about foreign investment, or foreign investment is all right from Britain and America but is not too good from Japan, then the simple message we will be telegraphing to the rest of the world is that we are equivocal about foreign investment. We will live to regret the day we were equivocal about foreign investment because those investors will go to other parts of the world, and increasingly they are starting to do that. They will go into the fast growing, fast developing dynamic European Community. They will go to countries such as the United States, if they are Japanese, or Japan if they are from the United States. They will go to countries such as Canada. They will be the beneficiaries of foreign investment and this country will pay a terrible price for that.

We have to remember we are in the international marketplace to compete for investment, and if we can attract foreign investment in this country that is a sure way of helping us get out of the very serious economic problems we face. I hope that members of this place will in future go out into the community and argue the case for foreign investment, even though it is not popular in some sections of the community, and show a bit of courage, a bit of leadership, and persuade those people in the community that their sentiments-on whatever those sentiments are based-are sentiments that if implemented in terms of policy would do this country very real and very lasting damage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spender Mr J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I wish to say a few things as the opportunity arises to address some of the broad issues of the day. One of the broad issues of the day is taxation reform. We talk a great deal about taxation reform in this country but we tend to do very little about it. I am very glad to see that the Opposition has firmly nailed its colours to the mast of taxation reform. The Leader of the Opposition (Mr Peacock) has stated that it is the Opposition's intention in government to have a flatter, two-level tax system and a top rate of 39c in the dollar. The reason for that is that it will bring the top marginal rate for individuals down to the company rate. The very obvious reason for that is that so long as there is a differential between the top marginal personal rate and the company rate of taxation, of course, there is the opportunity and the desire to minimise taxation by engaging in schemes which would divert income from individuals into companies. That is so obvious that blind Freddy would understand it, yet apparently this Government does not.

SPEECH.PARA: There is another subject which we have not focused on; that is, the subject of indirect tax. We have a taxation scheme which for the most part relies upon direct tax. We have wholesale sales tax, excise taxes and others, but we do not have anything in the nature of a value-added tax, a consumer tax or a turnover tax, in short, a broad-based indirect tax.

What are the reasons why we do not have such a tax? In the first place, we seem to be dissuaded from even talking about the subject because on both sides of the House it is regarded as the poisoned chalice. Think about it. Even mention it and one's opponents will say that one is out to rob old ladies, the indigent-everybody who is defenceless-and to change the taxation system so that the rich profit. But is it not a curious thing that, in many other countries where there is great concern for social justice, such an indirect taxation system exists? It exists alongside a direct system of taxation.

I am not arguing for increases in the overall burden of tax; quite to the contrary. I believe that the overall tax burden needs to be brought down. But it is worthwhile looking at the efficiencies and equity-and I stress the word `equity'-of indirect tax. There are, around the country, hundreds of thousands of people who pay little or no tax, not because they do not earn an income, but because they do not return it, because they take their income in cash, put it in their pockets and thumb their noses at the taxation system. It is impossible to estimate the size of the black economy. Some people say it would be 10 per cent; others would give an estimate of 15 or 20 per cent. One thing we know is that it is large. Anybody who has any understanding of life in Australia knows that the black economy is alive and well and growing.

How do you catch people in the black economy? Forget about doing it through the Income Tax Assessment Act. Forget about adding penalties. The Australian Taxation Office is not particularly concerned, and does not have the resources to chase after the small people, the medium-sized people, who are ripping off the economy-ripping off all of us, because we all suffer-and who are doing it in cash. Resources have to be directed towards the bigger and easier targets. But with an indirect system of taxation, which would be designed to supplement the direct system of taxation and, at the same time, reduce the overall burden, we would bring into the taxation net those who are presently outside it. Is that not equitable? Is it not just that those who are escaping from the taxation burden should be brought into the net? I believe that it is. I think it would be a very good thing for this country if we could have an honest, open, public debate, devoid of misrepresentation, examining the issue of taxation and of how the system worked. On both sides of the House we should have the decency to say, `We do not have all the wisdom on our side, and we understand that everybody here in their own way is trying to get things just a little better for Australians'.

So the thought that I would drop quietly into the pool this evening is that the time for that debate is overdue. This country sometimes appears to be in a time warp. It is as though we believe we should be debating issues about 20 years behind the rest of the world, in the field of tax, in the field of industrial relations, in the field of reform of our transportation systems. We are in that time warp. It is time that we moved out of it.

It troubles me greatly that on the several occasions that the Prime Minister has spoken about this question he has sought to inject a political element into this discussion. The so-called immigration debate of recent times has done Australia and Australians-including Asian Australians-no good at all. Under a new Opposition leadership, however, I think-
I emphasise those words `I think'-
we are on the road back towards a bipartisan immigration policy that is genuinely free of any hint of racial prejudice or preference.

I do not know how the Prime Minister can utter those words `I think', when we look at the clear and unambiguous statement of the Leader of the Opposition when he was first appointed by these parties. And let me say what a tragic loss it is that the bipartisanship on this issue that had so positively and so constructively characterised Australian politics for so many years no longer exists at the Federal level.

I believe the Prime Minister made that statement to inject a partisan element into the matter. The way in which that launch was conducted was a peculiarly partisan exercise. Yet it is quite clear from statements made by the Leader of the Opposition and me that, in terms of the endorsement of multiculturalism in the way in which it is defined in the agenda, there was absolutely no problem with that for the Opposition. The Leader of the Opposition had this to say of the Prime Minister's statement on multiculturalism:
While welcoming elements of the Prime Minister's statement on Multiculturalism, the Opposition is disappointed that Mr Hawke is playing politics on a sensitive policy area.

Particularly since the Second World War, Australia has become increasingly a multicultural and a cosmopolitan society composed of people with different ethnic and language backgrounds. As a result we are all the richer.

I want to take the opportunity tonight to put on record again my own statements in relation to the National Agenda for a Multicultural Australia. I said when it was launched that we in the Opposition saw the definition of multiculturalism as totally unexceptional. In the statement `What is Multiculturalism?' in the agenda there has been a marked change in attitude on the Government's part, which has not been acknowledged by the Prime Minister in any public way or by Government spokesmen but which I am quite prepared to acknowledge with approval. TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Speaker, in the other place yesterday Senator Newman made certain remarks which I feel require a response. The good senator said, speaking of a request she made to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) to provide an aircraft to bring a delegation to Canberra to speak to the Prime Minister:

SPEECH.PARA: It is interesting that Mr Hawke is not prepared to send a plane to pick them up, but he is prepared to send a plane to Hobart to pick up a group of disabled children to send them on a skiing holiday, provided that the honourable member for Denison (Mr Kerr) is shown on television as a quid pro quo.
Senator Cook interjected:

Senator Newman continued:
It is absolutely factual.

The only thing that was absolutely factual was her assent to Senator Cook's proposition that it was indeed a disgusting allegation. I suppose in the good senator's fervid imagination she can conceive of the Prime Minister ringing the Australian Broadcasting Corporation and the Channel 6 local television station in Tasmania and saying, `Look, we will put on this plane to take disabled children who for three years have been planning a trip to the snowfields under the supervision of a number of aides, provided you will televise Duncan Kerr appearing with them'. I suppose the good senator in her fervid imagination, and in terms of what she no doubt conceives to be some small political advantage, could have reached such a conclusion. But only in the most obtuse of minds could such a conclusion have suggested itself, and it is patently false.

The reality is that shortly after the pilots strike was coming into effect the organisers of a rehabilitation recreation program in Tasmania contacted my office to say that they had six disabled people, three with spina-bifida, one with some limbs missing, another with some intellectual disability and another disabled person, who needed to get to the mainland. For three years they had been planning, as part of a process of normalisation to make sure that those with disabilities in the community are able to live a full life, a trip to the snowfields on the mainland. This was obviously a case where I thought a compassionate intervention was warranted. I contacted the Minister for Transport and Communications (Mr Willis) and the Minister for Defence (Mr Beazley). I ultimately reached the position whereby a plane which had come down to Tasmania to bring Senator Richardson, Senator Tate and other members of Parliament was able, on the return flight when it was travelling with less than full capacity, to pick up those six disabled persons and the three people who were to be their aides for the duration of the trip and enable them to undertake the program that had been three years in the planning. Frankly, it is a disgusting and quite baseless allegation that Senator Newman has made. Senator Newman has developed a reputation for making baseless allegations. In this instance it does neither her nor the process of the Parliament any credit to have made such a false and foolish allegation.

TALK.START.PARA: —I was very interested, indeed anxious, to hear exactly what the honourable member for Parkes (Mr Cobb) was going to say. I must say it does not alter anything I said in the House the other day. We are clearly dealing here with two separate issues. One, of course, is a question which, as the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) properly pointed out this morning, is a matter now for the Federal Police to investigate. The other goes to the integrity of the source selection process for the frigate. What was described here was clearly part of an intense lobbying process, not part of the source selection process of the frigate.

SPEECH.PARA: The source selection process of the frigate is based not on what lobbying may be done of me, what lobbying may be done of individual members of parliament; it is based on the documentation which is presented to the Royal Australian Navy and taken from the Royal Australian Navy to other sections of the Department of Defence, which consider it. It is taken from those sections of the Department of Defence and the Royal Australian Navy and placed then before several committees of the Department of Defence, which include representatives of not only the Department of Defence but also the Attorney-General's Department and the Department of Finance. After proceeding through that process it goes to a committee which effectively consists of the chiefs of the defence forces and the Secretary to the Department of Defence. What emerges from that is a Cabinet submission which is presented to government. On the basis of those recommendations, the Government considers what course it might follow.

At every stage of that process-this is one of the most clear cut source selection decisions I have seen in the years that I have been Minister for Defence-the recommendations came forward for the eventual decision that was taken by the Government. I know there have been rumours to the contrary. I know there are constantly suggestions of influence here and there or whatever, but to cast doubt on the source selection process that produced that set of recommendations to go to the Cabinet does not cast doubt on my integrity as Minister for Defence or on the integrity of any other Minister of this Government. It casts doubt on the integrity of the Royal Australian Navy personnel who consider this process, the huge number of people who go through that process of analysis before it finally arrives at government.

This is not a decision which has welled up from this process to the Government, then on the basis of lobbying to be overturned. This is a decision which is a product of a persistent series of investigations and studies of a mass of documentation-hundreds and hundreds of pages, thousands of documents-a process which in the end produces that recommendation for government. The Government did not vary one jot or tittle the recommendation which came from the Navy and from the Defence Department and those augmented committee processes. It came forward from them to the Government and was decided by the Government.

What happens when anything is about to be considered by the Government is that vast numbers of people believe they can influence the project. In the course of the project consideration I, as Minister for Defence, had many meetings not only with the various consortia that were involved-Australian Marine Engineering Consolidated Ltd (AMECON) and Australian Warship Systems (AWS)-but also with the principals of the consortia, parts of the companies associated with the consortia, at different points of time the trade union leadership of Newcastle, the Lord Mayor of Newcastle, the Premier of Victoria, Ministers from Victoria, and Mr John Halfpenny on numerous occasions. In that process it was absolutely no different from any other tender process which I preside over as Minister for Defence. I do not sit in an ivory tower. I am open to anybody who wants to approach me on those matters that are before the Department of Defence to discuss those things with me. If I were not to give access to all sides--

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The Minister's time has expired. As no other Minister is rising, the Minister may continue.

—If I were not to give access to all the companies in that particular process, then the complaints would start to roll in in a big way. If people are going to try to demonstrate in this particular instance some sort of change or altered part of that process, I really think that, in a situation where some political intervention has caused the intensely detailed and well-respected processes of the naval establishment and also the Department of Defence to intervene, they have to get into that process in a gremlin-like fashion, and overturn it over hundreds and hundreds of people.

SPEECH.PARA: Of course there is always debate within the Department of Defence, with the Navy, on exactly what weight should be given to this or that factor. There is never going to be unanimity on this or that factor. The fact of the matter is that on every single committee level at which this was considered, the recommendation came forward to the next level that the eventually successful tenderers should be the people who got it. It does no credit to the process to try to have it smeared in this way. I suppose that if there had been the estranged wife or somebody else associated with the AWS bid or, for that matter, anyone else associated with any of the other many equipment purchases which we undertake on which lobbying is done of us, one would be able to tease out the same set of discussions. One would be able to sit down and hear one group of companies say to another, `Look, we really ought to get into Canberra to lobby Beazley', or `We really ought to get into Canberra to lobby the Chairman of the Caucus Industrial Committee'-`or to lobby the Opposition or to lobby someone else'; because they do. They turn up at our committees. They turn up in my office. They send us documentation on all this material, and they go and openly advocate their wares.

The fact of the matter is that in connection with the AMECON bid, the Victorian Government, the Victorian Trades Hall Council, the Victorian union movement, the companies associated with the Williamstown Naval Dockyard, all of them got together to lobby here, to lobby in New Zealand, to lobby elsewhere, around Newcastle, to lobby around the country, not disguised at any point of time. Halfpenny and all sorts of other people were up in New Zealand at public forums, along with AMECON and other representatives, making the case for the frigate and particularly making the case for their own particular set of objectives. This is a perfectly normal part of the process. People pursue these contracts passionately.

Whatever might happen to be a question of any particular relationship that Mr Halfpenny might have with any particular company or anyone else involved in the process of the eventually successful tenderer, is, I suppose, along with all those other allegations, a matter now for the Australian Federal Police to consider. But what is not arguable in this process is that it was a process of integrity. The way in which the lobbying was done, the way in which a company might be formed, the way in which a bid might be undertaken, is an issue separate from the integrity of the process by which a decision is ultimately taken.

I am not the only one lobbied. Of course people in the Department of Defence are lobbied too, all the time. What has to be demonstrated, if people want to go down that road, is that that process was corrupted. Of course, it was not. The Chief of the Naval Staff, the admirals, the commodore who ran the program, the various individuals in the Department of Defence and who brought that recommendation up to the Government, are not corrupted individuals. That recommendation arrived at the Government from these sources. It was not varied by the Government. The Government agreed with the decision that was put before it. It was a clear-cut winner in this particular case. It was in the end a very easy decision for Government to take.
